webTitle: Come clean about who gets a stake

fields.headline: Come clean about who gets a stake
fields.trailText: 'The stakeholder pension is the centrepiece of the Government's plan for shifting responsibility for pensions from the state to the individual.'
fields.body:
It's cheap, it's cheerful and it's here. The stakeholder pension is launched on Friday. It is the centrepiece of the Government's plan for shifting responsibility for pensions from the state to the individual. But will it work?

There are already encouraging signs that the stakeholder appeals to the reasonably well-off. But if you focus on the group the Government originally intended as beneficiaries - people earning between £10,000 and £20,000 a year - the prospects are not so good. For a start, few in this group will feel they can afford a stakeholder pension, particularly if they get no subsidy from an employer - which will usually be the case since stakeholders are aimed at people without access to existing employers' schemes.

But even if they can scrape together the money, many could fall foul of means testing when they come to reap rewards for their 'prudence'.

The Government has, up to a point, acknowledged this and dreamt up the pension credit which will 'reward' saving by giving a state credit of 60p for every pound of income up to a certain level. But to actuaries and accountants, this is a form of taxation - and at a punitive rate of 40 per cent.

Deborah Cooper, a member of the pensions task force at the Institute of Actuaries, says someone on median earnings - currently £13,000 a year - and planning to retire in 2020 will need a fund of £100,000 to generate private income sufficient to take them out of the means-testing trap.

There is scant information available from government agencies on means testing and stakeholders. More is needed, and if stakeholder is really best suited to the middle-income earner with good prospects for earnings growth, the Government should come clean about it.

Stakeholder pensions are among the first products to be sold by a new breed of financial adviser, who is neither fully independent nor linked to one firm. This is the beginning of the end for a 10-year-old regime that pro moted the idea of independent advice. Consumers face a new era of confusion over the status of their advisers, and independence is being watered down.

The Government should be looking at ways to elevate the status of truly independent advisers as professionals so that they can stand out from the crowd.

webTitle: Wealthcheck: Covering the cracks in savings plans

fields.headline: Covering the cracks in savings plans
fields.standfirst: Ceramics restorer Bridget Syms worries about her endowment and a lack of funds, says  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Ceramics restorer Bridget Syms worries about her endowment and a lack of funds, says Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
Bridget Syms
Age 46
Lives in South Buckinghamshire
Occupation Self-employed ceramics restorer
Earns £14,500
Mortgage £30,000
Debts £700 on credit card, £2,500 car loan
Investments £4,000 in shares, £500 in instant access acount, £100 a month ISA savings
Pension Personal pension
Aims To reduce debts and build up short term and long term savings.

Bridget's experience as a dental technician in the airforce, combined with her knowledge of antiques and art, stood her in good stead when she set up as a ceramics restorer 12 years ago. The job was intended to be one she could do from home while her children were young, but she has continued with it, although her son and daughter are now in their twenties - her son is in his final year at university.

She is not short of work. Much of her business comes from the antiques trade, but she also takes private commissions, restoring all manner of damaged ceramics such as figurines, jardinières, plates and jugs.

But Bridget would like to feel more secure. 'I can live quite well on my earnings until something happens which ruins my well-laid plans, such as the car breaking down, the washing machine needing mending or my son needing a new suit,' she says.

She is worried about getting further into debt. 'The more debt you have, the easier it becomes to think another hundred pounds doesn't matter.'

Although Bridget has £500 in a Tesco instant access account for emergencies, she is not sure when she should use that money and when she should take out credit. At present she is paying off her credit card bill at around £200 a month and hopes to clear it in about three months, unless something else crops up. Her car loan should also be cleared in just under a year.

Her endowment mortgage has been one of her greatest financial worries. She has a low-start policy with Eagle Star which, in the worst-case scenario, could pay off only 50 per cent of her outstanding mortgage in 14 years' time. Indeed, she has managed to get £4,000 in compensation for having been mis-sold the policy.

She has invested this money in a small portfolio of shares. She is planning to leave these untouched until her endowment matures in the hope that they will help to make up the shortfall. As an extra protection, she is also saving £100 a month in a Legal & General index tracker Isa.

Her mortgage is with Bristol & West and she is paying a variable mortgage rate. As she was self-employed when she took it out, it had to be on a non-status basis.

Although she has thought about remortgaging, she feels it is unlikely another lender would consider her for a new loan on her low earnings.

Bridget's main aim is to build up a larger cash cushion both for now and for retirement. Although she really enjoys her work, she realises she won't always be able to cope with the volume of jobs she handles now.

Adviser 1: Gillian Cardy

Bridget should try to build up a greater cash reserve so that she avoids making emergency purchases on credit cards or other expensive forms of borrowing. To this end she may like to consider putting her Legal & General Isa on hold for a few months and save the money into a mini-cash Isa instead.

Meanwhile, she may do well to adjust her finances to make the most of the cash she has available. Transferring her credit card balance to a cheaper card would be of benefit.

She has chosen to invest her compensation from her mis-sold endowment into even higher-risk investments. She may find it useful to work out how much the shares need to increase in value each year on average to cover the shortfall.

It would have been preferable to put the shares into an Isa, which would have been more tax-efficient. However, transferring them now will not be particularly cost-effective. She should be careful about the possible impact of capital gains tax on the sale of the shares in future.

She could consider putting some of her mortgage on to a repayment basis to deal with the problem of the endowment shortfall in a lower-risk way.

She should not assume a remortgage would be difficult. A review of her pension planning options may also be advisable.

Gillian Cardy works for financial adviser Professional Partnerships.

Adviser 2: Andrew Jones

Bridget is doing the right thing by paying off her loans as soon as possible, although it would have been better to repay these before investing her endowment compensation, especially in the light of recent stock-market falls.

She is wrong to think lenders would consider her income too low for a re-mortgage. However, this option may not be cost-effective, so she should see if Bristol & West will offer an improved deal based on her established earnings record.

Her pension contributions are low, and she could consider increasing these when funds allow. Or she could put additional savings into an Isa in the same way as her pension plan, and use the capital accumulated to supplement her pension.

She should also consider her state pension. Her Nat-ional Insurance record may be incomplete and she should apply for a pension forecast from the DSS. It can often be worthwhile making up any shortfall with voluntary contributions.

Then there is ill-health provision. Bridget should take out an income replacement policy. A policy paying £800 per month and ceasing at age 60 would cost around £85 per month.

Or she could buy a lump-sum critical illness policy. A lump sum of £50,000 would cost about £33.50 a month. It would repay her mortgage and leave some money to live on.

Andrew Jones works for accountant Blick Rothenberg

Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: cash@observer.co.uk. You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

webTitle: What's the catch?

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: MBNA's Platinum Plus Visa Card.
fields.body:
The advert for MBNA's Platinum Plus Visa Card boldly claims that you can save £486 in five months if you take advantage of its 2.7 per cent interest rate for balance transfers.

However, this is only when compared with one store card, the FraserCard, which has an exceptionally high APR, of 29.3 per cent. It also assumes someone is transferring £5,000 from FraserCard to MBNA and then only making the minimum monthly payment. MBNA says: 'We do get a lot of people transferring from store cards and this is where you often get the biggest saving.'

Other cardholders will make much more modest savings. Transferring £1,000 from the HSBC Platinum credit card will net a saving of just £47.

Purchases and balance transfers after five months will attract a rate of 15.9 per cent, which the adverts describe as 'very competitive'. But anyone looking to take advantage of promotional offers can do better elsewhere. For example, Nationwide is offering 3.5 per cent for six months on balance transfers and purchases. Thereafter, the purchase rate beats MBA at 14.6 per cent. The advert also states prominently: 'No annual fee'. Yet of the 154 credit cards listed in the March issue of Moneyfacts , only 22 charge an annual fee.

 Seen an offer or advertisement which sounds too good to be true? Then write to What's the Catch? The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

webTitle: Make it a happy new tax year

fields.headline: Make it a happy new tax year
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean offers a guide on how to organise now - and save money
fields.trailText: Neasa MacErlean offers a guide on how to organise now - and save money.
fields.body:
Seeing in a new year is usually a cause for uncorking bottles and celebrating. The big exception is the start of the new fiscal year - not even accountants will be throwing parties when the 2001/02 tax year dawns on Friday.

But the day will be marked by the Inland Revenue sending out tax returns to 8,654,869 individuals. Here are some tips on how to handle your tax affairs, whether or not you hear from the Revenue.

 Check your tax coding. About 20 per cent of them are wrong, estimates accountant Richard Murphy. If yours is one of them, incorrect amounts of Pay As You Earn tax will be deducted from your pay. By looking at the coding you receive, you should be able to see if the figures are at least roughly right - whether, for example, you are still receiving the company car or other 'benefit in kind' which should show up on the coding.

 Get to work on your tax return now. 'Start collecting the information you need, if you can stand it,' says Jane Moore of charity TaxAid. Keep those bits of paper that you will need - for instance, the P60 from your employer detailing your pay and tax paid for 2000/01, which you should receive by the end of May at the latest.

Keep all your bank statements safely, especially if you are self-employed, since the Revenue has the right to see them if it investigates your affairs. If you get your return done early, you may be able to negotiate a discount with an accountant, says Murphy. But you will not be able to do that if you leave it until to the 31 January 2002 deadline for filing your return.

 Claim the new children's tax credit if you have not done so yet. Worth a maximum of £10 a week (£520 a year), this is available to working families with a child under 16. The amount is tapered down if one parent is a higher-rate taxpayer, and it disappears completely if the main breadwinner earns more than £42,000 a year. You need to fill in a form to claim it.

 Don't forget about the working families' tax credit (WFTC) if you have children and one parent is working. This credit should ensure that a family where one parent works full time has a minimum income of £225 a week by October. It is mainly aimed at low- income households, but some households with income of £30,000 can benefit, depending on their circumstances. Fairly complicated calculations are needed to see whether you are eligible, but organisations such as the Maternity Alliance (020 7588 8582) will help, as will the Government's WFTC helpline (0800 597 5976).

 Think of making your individual savings account (Isa) or other tax-efficient investments at the start, rather than the end, of the tax year. Understandably, many people are worried about putting money into equity Isas because of uncertainty over the value of shares, but if you have decided to get a cash Isa you will get an extra year of tax relief by investing now rather than next March.

 Remember that there are two years left for the self-employed to claim 100 per cent tax relief in the year of purchase on computers, software and internet-enabled mobile phones. This concession started on 6 April 2000 for a three-year period, but many people may not be aware of it.

 Do not get caught out by National Insurance. Make sure that you are paying enough if you are self-employed: it's a flat rate of £2 a week plus 7 per cent of profits between £4,535 and £29,900 in the tax year. If you are an employee, there are some system changes which could affect you. The NI threshold is being raised to align it with the personal allowance for income tax - £4,535 for 2001/02. Employees will therefore not have to pay NI if they earn less than this, which is equal to £87 a week.

 Remember that it is usually very worthwhile for 40 per cent taxpayers to make maximum pension contributions since you get the benefit of relief at that percentage, rather than the 22 per cent basic rate. The new stakeholder pension will be of interest to many lower earners - see our lead feature.

Tax facts for 2001/02

Personal allowances

General £4,535

Aged 65-74 £5,990

Aged 75+ £6,260

Taxable bands

Starting rate 10% £0-£1,880

Basic rate 22% £1,881-£29,400

Higher rate 40% £29,400+

Capital gains tax

Annual exemption £7,500

Inheritance tax

Tax-free threshold for estate on death: £242,000

webTitle: Five days to get in your last-minute Isa

fields.headline: Five days to get in your last-minute Isa
fields.standfirst: Take the plunge while the stock market is down, writes  Jill Insley
fields.trailText: Take the plunge while the stock market is down, writes Jill Insley.
fields.body:
The end of the tax year looms in five days' time. But you still have time to apply for an Isa if you get your skates on.

Many investors have been deterred from using their annual £7,000 Isa al-lowance by the turmoil on the stock markets in the past few weeks.

Jason Hollands of London independent financial ad-viser Bestinvest says the expected last-minute surge in Isa applications simply has not happened this year. 'People are reading about "the crash" and it does frighten them off,' he says.

However, he argues that now is exactly the right time to invest. 'If you buy into a weak market, you generally get the best returns long term. I'm not saying the market will recover straight away - it probably won't start to really improve until the fourth quarter. But if you can get in at these levels and invest for at least five years, you will be doing yourself a favour.'

Don Clark of Midlands discount broker TQ Direct says investment levels for the industry are down by about 70 per cent this week compared with the same time a year ago. He says that about one in every eight customers using TQ Direct is opting for its phasing service (also available through FundsNetwork, Bestinvest and Chase de Vere).

Phasing enables you to invest a lump sum now, making use of this tax year's Isa allowance, but spreading the investment of that money into funds over six months. This does not guarantee that you will do any better than investors who put all their money into the stock market now, but it may appeal to those who believe it has further to fall.

Some independent financial advisers are suggesting corporate-bond funds as an alternative for those wanting to make use of their Isa allowances, giving them the option of switching into equity funds when the market improves. But Hollands warns: 'You will still be trying to call the market, speculating on when it has bottomed out.'

Remember that if you are nervous about the stock market, or have limited funds to invest, you can put up to £3,000 into a mini cash Isa by 5 April (see page 16 for the best rates).

If you want a stock market Isa, the cheapest and most flexible way to invest is through one of the fund supermarkets or discount brokers (discount brokers are not allowed to handle clients' money so are re-stricted to online transactions). These rebate some, if not all, of the initial commission and allow you to invest in the funds of more than one fund manager. Providers include:

 Fidelity - has set up 41 Isa centres across the UK to give investors free internet access to its fund supermarket (Funds-Network.co.uk) until midnight, and drop-off points at hotels in 11 cities. Call 0800 41 41 71 for venues and opening times.

 Egg - will accept online applications until 11.30pm from customers who are already Egg savings account holders, or they can deliver completed forms to Egg's offices in London, Dudley and Derby until 5pm. Call 0870 010 7400 for details.

 Inter-Alliance - will take online applications for the Norwich Union until 9.30pm, Edinburgh up to 11pm, Aberdeen and M&G until 11.30pm, Johnson Fry 11.59pm, Britannic, Gartmore, Investec, Jupiter, Legal & General, and Royal & SunAlliance midnight.

 TQ Direct - will accept applications online until midnight or paper applications with cheques to its office at St Marks, Chapel Ash, Wolverhampton until 2pm.

 Bestinvest - will take online applications until midnight, or paper-based applications and cheques at 20 Mason's Yard, London SW1, until 4pm.

 Chase de Vere Investments - will take online applications until midnight, or paper-based applications through its offices in Bath, London and Leeds until 5pm. Call 0845 609 2001 for addresses.

Several fund managers have also made arrangements to receive very last-minute applications on 5 April.

Remember, they will be able to accept only applications for their own funds or cash deposits, and you will not benefit from a rebate in initial commission.

Aberdeen, ABN Amro, Cofunds, Henderson, In-vesco, M&G, Perpetual, Schroders and Threadneedle have combined forces to set up 12 collection points around the UK, open until 6pm. Call 0800 353737 for details.

Firms have also set up individual last-minute facilities for extra flexibility when making delivery arrangements:

 ABN Amro is running an 'Isa Cafe' at its offices at 82 Bishopsgate, London EC2, until 8pm. Staff will be on hand to help complete forms and answer any questions.

 Aberdeen Asset Management will accept applications online to its website until 11.30pm, or phone applications (0800 262443) until midnight.

 Alliance & Leicester building society (cash and equity Isas) is keeping six branches (in Belfast, Edinburgh, Leicester, Crawley, Croydon and Bath) open until midnight. Others will stay open until 8pm. Call 0800 412214 for details.

 Close Fund Management will accept applications at its admin offices - 9th Floor, 155 Bishopsgate, London EC2M 3XY, until 5pm and at Mellon Fund Administration, Mellon House, Ingrave Road, Brentwood, Essex CM15 8TG - until midnight.

webTitle: Annuities without the tears

fields.headline: Annuities without the tears
fields.standfirst: Tracey Boles looks at a new product for well-off pensioners
fields.trailText: Tracey Boles looks at a new product for well-off pensioners.
fields.body:
Annuities have been dogged by criticism, but the Prudential believes its new product could be a winner for more well-off pensioners.

An annuity provides a guaranteed income for life in return for a lump sum payment. If you have a personal pension or are part of your employer's money purchase scheme you must buy an annuity when you want to draw your pension or put off doing this by buying an income drawdown scheme, which is riskier.

Under present govern ment rules you must turn your pension pot into an income from an annuity before you reach 75, which many people find unfair. They argue that they should be able to do what they like with their pension money.

The Prime Minister's wife, Cherie Booth QC, will take the Government to court on behalf of Preston pensioner Joe Singer to challenge this under the European Convention on Human Rights, which outlaws prejudice on the grounds of age.

There were high hopes before the Budget that the Chancellor would relax the annuity rules, but Brown rejected this.

Other concerns about annuities include lack of investment flexibility, lack of transparency and lack of death benefits - when you die the funds in the annuity pass to the insurance company. The fall in yields on government stock, on which annuity rates are based, has also meant that present annuity payouts are much lower than in the past.

Experts say the new Prudential product, the Flexible Lifetime Annuity, goes some way towards addressing these concerns. At one level it works like a traditional annuity, paying an income for life in retirement. But instead of committing all of your funds to buying the annuity when you retire, you can leave money invested to continue growing. You can choose the level of income you receive annually from between upper and lower limits, which the Pru resets every three years after reviewing the progress of your investments.

Your money can be invested in the stock market via 14 different funds from a selection of investment managers, including Schroders, Perpetual and Merrill Lynch. There are three investment strategies to choose from - cautious, standard and adventurous. Policyholders can make six free fund switches a year. The idea is that investment returns feed into the fund while you draw income.

When members of the fund die, the money they have not ring-fenced for their family (they can ring-fence up to 80 per cent to pay an income to their family for 10 years after their death) is redistributed among the other people in the pool for what it calls a lifetime bonus. Prudential says the bonus enables it to guarantee income. Income levels are guaranteed never to fall below half the original starting amount.

You can switch all of the money to an ordinary fixed annuity at any time, but do not have to do so until you are 90.

This is a complex product and must be purchased through an independent financial adviser.

The Pru annuity may be more flexible and transparent than a traditional prod uct but has not addressed the death benefit issue. And the minimum investment is £100,000, while the average annuity purchase is £30,000. It is also unsuitable for those who need an impaired life annuity because of poor health.

Once you have chosen an annuity you cannot change it, so it is vital to scour the market and consider your options carefully. All annuities have some common features: the older you are the more money you receive, and women typically get less because their life expectancy is longer. But there are many different types of annuity. These range from straightforward level annuities to investment-linked and escalating annuities.

Level annuities pay the same income year after year. You have certainty but they are vulnerable to inflation.

Most people buy this kind of annuity, according to Peter Quinton of the Annuity Bureau, because it delivers the maximum income on a small pot - at first. 'The drop from salary upon retirement is huge, so people often take this option. But what they don't realise is that it is like having a fixed salary for 20 years-plus.'

To make sure your fund increases in line with inflation, you could choose an escalating annuity, where your income increases at a fixed rate. But initially these tend to pay out a lower income than level annuities.

Investment-style annuities - such as with-profits and unit-linked varieties - have the potential to offer a higher income, but your pension pot will be exposed to the ups and downs of the stock market.

 The Annuity Bureau produces a fact sheet on the Prudential annuity. Ring 020 7902 2300.

webTitle: What is a bear market?

fields.headline: What is a bear market?
fields.trailText: What is a bear market?
fields.body:
If you have taken but a passing interest in what has happened in the stock market of late you will probably be able to tell friends in the pub that we're in a 'bear' market. But would you be able to explain exactly what it means?

A bear market is commonly held to be one where a particular index falls by at least 20 per cent over a particular period. A bull market is one that shows a corresponding rise. But the terms are sometimes used more loosely to mean simply a good or bad trend in share prices.

The terms 'bear' and 'bull' first appeared in the 1880s, when 'bearskin jobbers' were known for selling bear skins that they did not own - the bears had not yet been caught. The word bear was eventually used to describe short sellers - speculators who sold shares they did not own, bought after a price drop. A bull was understood as the opposite of a bear - bulls were people who bought in the expectation that a stock price would rise, not fall.

The market regularly experiences bull and bear phases, but in the long term it tends to be bullish, outperforming cash and gilts. The past 10 years have been a long bull run, with equities rising by on average 11.8 per cent .

A crash is generally more dramatic than the rise in a bear market. It involves a fall of between 25 and 30 per cent, normally over a few days or weeks. In the Wall Street crash of 1929, 48 per cent was wiped off the value of shares between 3 September and 13 November. Over three years the market fell by 90 per cent, obliterating the savings of millions. Black Monday in 1987 also qualifies as a crash. The US Dow fell more than 550 points, or 22.6 per cent, in a day. The FTSE All-Share index fell 20 per cent in two days.

Another term you may encounter is 'correction' - a fall of 10 to 15 per cent over a few weeks or months. According to Barclays Stockbrokers, the current underperformance marks it out as a bear market - and a buying opportunity for long-term investors. The market is depressed by more than is justified by the outlook, Barclays says, and should therefore correct itself over time. If you buy in now and it goes up, you will gain.

webTitle: Take your mouse for a drive - and find a bargain

fields.headline: Take your mouse for a drive - and find a bargain
fields.standfirst: Buying on the net can pay off, writes  Julian Tyndale-Biscoe
fields.trailText: Buying on the net can pay off, writes Julian Tyndale-Biscoe.
fields.body:
This time last year, as extravagant parties hailed one online launch after another, the internet's champions predicted that one day everything would be bought online. No more traffic jams or queues at the tills - instead, everything from groceries to clothes and even cars would be available via the humble PC.

A year later, the prospect of buying a new car online seems a little more daunting as fears about internet security have made many consumers think twice about spending tens, let alone thousands, of pounds online. If the internet banks can't get it right, what chance does anyone else have?

Car manufacturers haven't helped either. They have been predictably slow at adapting to the net, many regarding it purely as a marketing tool and chary of upsetting their dealer networks. Most manufacturers' sites are full of clever graphics juxtaposed with classy photographs that take for ever to download, but the only practical advice they offer is help to find your nearest dealer.

You can't buy online at BMW, Rover, Toyota or Nissan, for example. And Nissan was obviously slow off the mark when it came to registering a domain name - try www.nissan.com and you reach the homepage of a humble American computer-sales company.

Nevertheless, there are several valid reasons for considering the internet when buying a car - and more people are doing so. A survey by Cap Gemini Ernst & Young last year revealed that while just 0.1 per cent of the UK population were willing to buy a car online, the figure would rise to 8 per cent over the following three years.

Ultimately, what most consumers want to know is whether they can save money by buying online. For UK drivers, this is a pressing need, given that car makers seem bent on charging us more than anyone else in Europe. Anecdotal evidence of this has been confirmed by the European Commission. In a survey published earlier this year, it said that a Mazda 323, for example, sells for £5,307 in Denmark a staggering £11,106 here.

The good news for UK consumers is that it is cheaper to buy online. In some cases, you can save up to 30 per cent on the list price of a new car. The key, however, is to tread carefully.

The first thing to point out is that there are several types of site. Some will let you compare prices without actually allowing you to buy, others will help you import new cars from the continent, and there are also several purely online retailers, as well as the car dealers' sites.

Fish4.co.uk, carprice-check.com, autobytel and autotrader all allow you to search for but not buy cars on sale in your area. Type in a make and model of car and where you live, and the sites will try to come up with a list to suit. They will also put you in touch with a dealer which has the car you want so that you can arrange a test drive. Price comparison sites are usually independent, but they will try to push other services, such as insurance and finance packages.

Inchcape-owned autobytel.co.uk launched last April and refers customers to accredited dealers. It claims to have sold more than 6,000 cars. Fish4 is a broader comparison site that also finds jobs and houses.

But the major problem with all the price comparison sites is that they are just large directories relying on dealers for up-to-date information. It is conceivable that you will find the right car at the right price, only to be told by the dealer that it was sold last week.

The best deals on price typically come from sites that specialise in importing cars from the continent. They source and import the car of your choice, taking advantage of the price differentials between UK and Europe.

OneSwoop.com, which claims to be the leader in matching buyers with imported models on the internet, has been making a great deal of noise about 'rip-off Britain'. Marketing director Tom Buehlmann says: 'The much-publicised price cuts by manufacturers have failed to filter through to the forecourt. When we launched the site we averaged savings of 35-40 per cent off UK list prices. Now it is more like 20 per cent, but it is still a significant price gap.'

Buehlmann predicts that this year more British buyers than ever before will look to the continent for their new Y-registered car.

Our trawl of OneSwoop found, for example, a Ford Mondeo 1.8i 16v LX for £12,166, compared with a UK list price of £14,595 - a saving of almost 17 per cent. The UK list price of a Volkswagen Golf 1.9 GT Tdi is £12,329 - 14 per cent higher than the cost of importing through OneSwoop.

The drawback with sites that import cars is that you may face a considerable wait for the vehicle - sometimes as long as six months. OneSwoop says it can sometimes deliver within four weeks but admits that manufacturers are being increasingly difficult about supplying right-hand drive cars from the continent.

The other potential fear for a would-be importer is that imports carry a one-year warranty compared with a typical three years on UK-sourced cars. Buehlmann puts this down to simple scaremongering by UK-based dealers since most sites will offer extended warranties - all OneSwoop cars come with a three-year warranty. A bigger worry with imports is the price you will be able to get in the second-hand market. Many dealers will try to buy them for less.

Importers, though, are not the only online players that can offer big discounts. Retail sites such as Virgin Cars and Direct Line's jamjar.com also claim to offer savings of up to 30 per cent - by cutting out dealers. Virgin Cars imports and sources from select UK dealers. At launch it promised savings of between 10 and 30 per cent. Jamjar sells imports but is also in partnership with Dixon Motors and promises discounts of 20-30 per cent.

One plus is that jamjar claims 100 per cent availability of all makes and models, guarantees online part exchange and makes the delivery to your door within days. However, discounts vary between makes of car, and in some cases Jamjar can offer no saving at all.

It is also fair to say that several car dealers offer cars at competitive prices online. Paul Dixon, chief executive of Dixon Motors, the third biggest dealer in the UK, operates a chain of dealerships in the north of England and has been actively adapting its business to the internet.

'We sold 1,000 cars in the first two months of the year via the internet,' he says. But even Dixon simply puts you in touch with the listed dealer - you can't actually transact online.

A quick search on Dixon's site for a Ford Focus brought up a list of eight cars, all over six months old. The newest was a 1.6 hatchback with one mile on the clock and priced at £10,695. But Dixon believes that because his site lists both second-hand and new cars, he appeals to a wider market.

Certainly the second-hand and nearly-new market is huge and while most online retailers list second-hand cars, there are few that specialise in them. Both the AA and the RAC have spotted a gap in the market that they are rushing to fill. The AA is finalising discussions with several car providers, including UK car dealers.

The RAC, meanwhile, has just signed a strategic partnership with Yourauto choice.com, which claims to be the leading online retailer of nearly new cars.

A joint venture between car rental company Avis and US firm Navidec, it claims to have the widest range of cars in the UK, typically 20-40 per cent cheaper than new - and it offers free home delivery.

If you're serious about buying online, visit as many sites as possible for the best price. Read terms and conditions carefully. Every online retailer should offer to call you or put you in touch with a telesales operator. If they can't, they're not worth dealing with, even if it looks as if you'll be saving thousands. In the long run, it could end up costing more.

A bigger worry with imports is the price you will be able to get in the second-hand market. Many dealers will try to buy them for less. Importers, though, are not the only online players that can offer big discounts. Retail sites such as Virgin Cars and Direct Line's jamjar.com also claim to offer savings of up to 30 per cent - by cutting out dealers. Virgin Cars imports and sources from select UK dealers. At launch it promised savings of between 10 and 30 per cent. Jamjar sells imports but is also in partnership with Dixon Motors and promises discounts of 20-30 per cent. One plus is that jamjar claims 100 per cent availability of all makes and models, guarantees online part exchange and makes the delivery to your door within days. However, discounts vary between makes of car, and in some cases Jamjar can offer no saving at all. It is also fair to say that several car dealers offer cars at competitive prices online. Paul Dixon, chief executive of Dixon Motors, the third biggest dealer in the UK, operates a chain of dealerships in the north of England and has been actively adapting its business to the internet. 'We sold 1,000 cars in the first two months of the year via the internet,' he says. But even Dixon simply puts you in touch with the listed dealer - you can't actually transact online. A quick search on Dixon's site for a Ford Focus brought up a list of eight cars, all over six months old. The newest was a 1.6 hatchback with one mile on the clock and priced at £10,695. But Dixon believes that because his site lists both second-hand and new cars, he appeals to a wider market. Every online retailer should offer to call you or put you in touch with a telesales operator. If they can't, they're not worth dealing with, even if it looks as if you'll be saving thousands. webTitle: People's pension - a primer

fields.headline: People's pension - a primer
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about a flexible new friend
fields.trailText: All you need to know about a flexible new friend.
fields.body:
 Stakeholder pensions are stock market-invested savings schemes for retirement.

 They are aimed at those with no existing private pension, particularly the self-employed and anyone else who does not have access to a company pension scheme.

The original target group was people earning between £10,000 and £20,000 but it will also appeal - possibly more - to higher earners.

 Three-quarters of the fund you build up must be used to buy an annuity (see page 6) and annuity rates will determine the final value of your pension.

 Tax relief is available on contributions at up to 40 per cent. You can contribute £3,600 a year, which will cost a basic-rate taxpayer £2,808 (contributions are net of basic tax, and higher-rate taxpayers collect extra relief through tax returns).

 You may be able to contribute more, depending on your age and earnings; between 17.5 per cent of earnings up to age 35, and 40 per cent of earnings between 61 and 74

 You can have a stakeholder pension if you are not working and can stop and start payments at will. The Trades Union Congress says this flexibility makes them ideal for women

 Parents and grandparents can buy stakeholder pensions for children and grandchildren, although tax relief is limited to the basic rate.

 Husbands and wives can buy them for non-working spouses; again tax relief is restricted to the basic rate.

 If you earned less than £30,000 in any one of the last five tax years you can have a stakeholder pension while also contributing to a company scheme. A stakeholder could be used instead of, or as well as, an additional voluntary contribution company top-up scheme

 When you retire you can take a quarter of your accumulated fund as cash. The rest must be used to buy an annuity (see page 7). This is more flexible than AVC rules, where all of the fund must be used to buy a pension.

 Charges will be limited to 1 per cent a year but may be lower. Marks & Spencer has launched a fund charging 0.7 per cent. Others, such as Legal & General and Standard Life will operate tiered charging structures with much lower charges on larger funds.

 Employers with five workers or more must designate a scheme by October this year but companies don't have to contribute to workers' pensions.

The pensions will be available from employers or direct from insurance companies, through banks and building societies and 'affinity' groups. The TUC has set one up through Prudential which employers can use as their designated scheme

 You can switch jobs and still contribute to a stakeholder you took out with your previous employer.

 Insurers will offer a range of low to medium-risk funds and must provide a 'default' fund for investors who do not want to choose a fund for themselves

 If the investment performance of a plan is unsatisfactory you can switch without penalty

 If you have a personal pension you can swap to a stakeholder if the charges are lower. Many insurers are cutting charges on personal pensions because of this. Take great care if you are switching from a personal pension as there could be penalties (this will be dealt with in a future article in our series).

 People on low incomes, or who make only small payments into a stakeholder pension, should be aware that entitlement to means-tested state pensions could be affected by stakeholder pensions. (More on this in a future article).

Wedding belle signs

Georgina Jones, 24, is thinking of starting a stakeholder pension through her employer, Confetti.co.uk, an internet wedding accessory retailer.

Jones, the firm's office manager, who is in her mid-twenties, had not considered starting a pension until the new scheme came along.

'I have got to the age when I and colleagues of the same age think we need to do something. It does make sense that there is a savings plan that is constantly building up.'

Confetti will be offering staff a stakeholder plan through insurer Legal & General. Jones says: 'I wouldn't invest a huge amount at this time, but at least it is a start, and you can take it with you from job to job.'

She is thinking of starting her plan with a contribution equivalent to 3 per cent of her salary. She is not expecting a contribution from her employer.

The stakeholder scheme seems straightforward, she says. 'It is an easy decision to make as to who you go with and how you go about it.'

Help is at hand

It may be hard to get impartial advice about stakeholder pensions. Unscrupulous independent financial advisers may avoid recommending them because the charges on them are low, which makes the commission low, too. But the Government says the schemes are so simple that individuals can make their own judgments, helped by information from official sources such as those below:

The Financial Services Authority, which regulates the pensions industry, has free leaflets on stakeholder plans. These include a series of 'decision trees' to help you work out whether a stakeholder is suitable for you and how much to save. Tel: 0845 606 1234.

The taxman is lending a hand, too. The Inland Revenue website includes information on stakeholder pensions.

The Department of Social Security has a guide. These are available at www.pensionguide.gov.uk. Tel: 0845 7313233

The Trades Union Congress has published a free guide for female workers, entitled Stakeholder Pensions for Women . Tel: 020 7467 1294.

The Pensions Advisory Service, (known as Opas), which is jointly funded by the Government and the Financial Services Authority, has a helpline, on 0845 601 2923. It is open between 8.30am and 6.30pm from Monday to Friday.

webTitle: Who's taking your stake?

fields.headline: Who's taking your stake?
fields.standfirst: Pensions aimed at the poor could help the well-off most, says  Maria Scott
fields.trailText: Pensions aimed at the poor could help the well-off most, says Maria Scott
fields.body:
The stakeholder pensions to be launched by the Government on Friday are a new type of savings plan for retirement. A key element of the Labour Party's pension strategy is that more people will pay their own way in old age.

Up to 6.6 million people will be eligible for these schemes, which are aimed at people on low-to-middle incomes who cannot save through employers' pension plans. This includes staff of companies without schemes and the self-employed.

There is nothing revolutionary about the basic struc ture of the stakeholder pension: it is a long-term savings plan where contributions go into the stock market. The aim is to build a fund that can be used at retirement to buy an income. In that sense, it is a reinvention of the Conservatives' discredited personal pension. But the Government has gone to some lengths to make its version user-friendly.

Charges are restricted to 1 per cent a year, there will be no transfer penalties and you will be able to save in a stakeholder plan yourself - or for someone else - even if you are not working.

Most people in the pensions industry say this is an improvement on what has been available before. Accountant PricewaterhouseCoopers says: 'The high cost of retail pensions has for decades been an embarrassment.

'Commission and other costs can easily eat up 2 per cent a year, reducing a healthy 7 per cent return to 5 per cent and effectively nullifying the tax reliefs.'

Another difference between the stakeholder and the personal pension is that employers with at least five workers will be obliged to nominate one of the new plans for their staff if they do not already have a company pension. Employers won't have to contribute, but they will have to arrange for payments to be collected from salaries.

Yet doubts remain about how successful the stakeholder will be. Several recent surveys show that the public barely understands what the scheme is, and many employers are unaware of their responsibility to offer access to one.

One of the most recent surveys, by a company offering support services to small businesses, shows that nearly a third of small and medium-sized firms have yet to do anything about it, even though fines for failing to obey the new rules go up to £50,000.

This research, by IS4Profit.com, shows that one in five small firms is still uncertain whether they need to supply a stakeholder pension. Another 9 per cent cent know of their obligation to do so, but have done nothing about it yet.

A poll published last week by IFA Promotion, the organisation that promotes independent financial advice, found that less than half the population knew what a stakeholder pension was. Awareness was low among groups targeted by the Government as potential purchasers of stakeholder plans: women, young people and those on low incomes.

Another survey found that, only a month before the launch, three-quarters of adults had not heard of the new scheme.

The Government stated when it outlined plans for the stakeholder that it would be aimed at people earning from around £10,000 to £20,000 a year. But there are already fears that the scheme will miss its target.

Instead, calls to independent financial advisers suggest that well-informed, well-heeled clients are planning to add the stakeholder pension to their list of tax-free investments.

The new schemes can be used by:

 People who are already members of company schemes to save extra.

 By well-off spouses to buy pensions for partners.

 And by parents and grandparents to start plans for children from babyhood onwards.

Jon Briggs of Chartwell Investment Management says: 'We have had a lot of inquiries from clients wanting to take one out for a child or grandchild. It's likely to appeal to people who don't really need it.'

Yet many people in the original target groups won't be able to afford to contribute, says John Turton, pensions specialist at adviser Best Investment.

Stakeholder pensions will accept monthly savings of as little as £20 but Turton questions whether such small sums will build worthwhile pensions.

'For under £100 a month, what will it do to your lifestyle [in old age]?' he asks.

Turton believes stakeholder pensions will be popular but with a different group from the ones the Government had in mind: 'I would call them the middle-wealthy, earning somewhere between £25,000 and £40,000. Where stakeholders will go well will be among the young upwardly mobile.'

There are lingering concerns among experts about whether small stakeholder savers will find themselves penalised by the state when they retire when entitlements to state pensions can be cut by means testing.

The Government plans a system of pension credits to reward small savers for taking out private plans. But, as the Institute of Actuaries points out, it is virtually impossible for them to work out in advance whether, or by how much, this will help.

Many pension providers and analysts believe the take-up of stakeholder pensions will be so low that the Government will be forced to make pension contributions compulsory. Anyone without a company scheme would have to buy a stakeholder plan.

Labour is nervous about compulsion, fearing it would be seen as a backdoor tax rise, but don't be surprised if such a move appears during a second Tony Blair-led government.

Pension scheme makes for good PR

Spin Media is a three-year-old public relations company with no staff pension scheme. But founder Andy Spinoza is setting one up to comply with obligations under the stakeholder pension regime and - even though he does not have to contribute for staff - has decided to pay in the equivalent of 3 per cent of staff salaries.

Spinoza, 39, says: 'Public relations is known for its revolving door when it comes to staff retention. I am aware it [the pension] is portable, but we wanted to show employees that we were taking an ethical approach. I am really happy with the people I've got, and I don't want to lose them.'

Spinoza says he is not particularly concerned that schemes are beginning during a stock market crash: 'I've got to have faith that the market will pick up.'

Lyndsey Evans, 23, a senior account executive at the Manchester-based firm, hopes that by starting a pension now she will eventually be able to retire early. She is 'not very good at money management', and hopes it will give her more control of her finances.

webTitle: Investment trusts geared up for a fall

fields.headline: Investment trusts geared up for a fall
fields.standfirst: Jill Insley  on how the collapse of NetNet serves a timely warning
fields.trailText: Jill Insley on how the collapse of NetNet serves a timely warning.
fields.body:
Just when you thought things couldn't get worse in the technology market, Framlington sells nearly all the assets in its NetNet investment trust to pay off bank debts. Investors who put £60m into the trust were left last week with a portfolio worth just £8m.

The investors were predominantly institutional - Aberdeen Asset Management and Legg Mason to name but two - but the fate of their money serves as a timely warning for private investors, who are turning to split capital investment trust shares to boost their income.

The trust, a split capital fund (not to be confused with the NetNet unit trust) launched last March at the peak of the technology boom and borrowed a further £40m from Bank of Scotland.

This borrowing, known in the investment trust industry as gearing, was designed to enable the trust to buy more assets - and produce a high-income yield. After 10 years the trust's manager, Chris Bell, would sell the portfolio and use the cash to pay off the £40m bank loan and pay income shareholders 40p a share. Any capital left over was to be paid to capital shareholders.

Bank of Scotland lent the money on the grounds that the loan could be called in if the ratio of assets to loan fell to 1.7. At outset the ratio was 2.5 (£100m in assets divided by £40m in debt), but as soon as Bell started investing the trust's money, the technology market began to slide. Last week the ratio came much closer to the 1.7 cut-off point.

Craig Walton, Framlington's marketing director, says: 'The board considered that if there was another leg down [in share prices], it would break its covenant. The board thought it better to repay the debt and leave it as an ungeared trust.'

The trust's directors will ask shareholders whether they want to leave the remaining £8m in place, but the trust is now likely to be wound up.

Few retail investors will have suffered from the NetNet trust's downfall, but Alan Durrant, investment director of Bristol independent financial adviser Hargreaves Lansdown, warns: 'All investment trusts that are geared by bank loans carry this risk.'

Even if a trust does not breach its agreed ratio of assets to bank loan, gearing can be dangerous for shareholders. Gearing is beneficial in a rising market as it enables investors to buy more assets and enjoy more gains than their capital would otherwise allow. But in a falling market any losses are magnified. All invest ment trusts are allowed to gear, but the effect can be extreme in the highly geared ordinary and income shares of split capital investment trusts.

These shares benefit from most, if not all, of the income produced by the trust's assets, but when the trust is eventually wound up, first call on capital goes to zero dividend preference shares. If the trust has gearing and its assets have fallen in value, there may be little capital left over for income shareholders.

If you are interested in buying shares in a particular trust you can check its level of gearing in the AITC's monthly statistics guide (call 0800 0858520 for a free copy) or visit its website (www.itsonline.co.uk). Subtract 100 from the published gearing figure to get the percentage of gearing. Some of the gearing percentages are enormous: Aberdeen Preferred Income's income shares are yielding 19 per cent, but it has gearing of 191 per cent.

Chris Macdonald of Lon don independent adviser Brooks Macdonald Gayer says the gearing effect can be magnified still further in trusts that buy the geared income shares of other split capital investment trusts, such as BFS Income & Growth. 'The only way to find out the full amount of gearing is to ask the fund manager,' he says.

webTitle: Future is boding well for Johnnie's mail-order firm

fields.headline: Future is boding well for Johnnie's mail-order firm
fields.standfirst: Boden and Mini-Boden are a way of life for their creator and his young brood, he tells Jill Insley
fields.trailText: Boden and Mini-Boden are a way of life for their creator and his young brood, he tells Jill Insley.
fields.body:
Boden-World is a relaxed, middle-class place of glamourous, twenty- and thirty-somethings who probably have a Labrador in a basket by the Aga, and a Volvo on the drive. At least this is the image encouraged by Johnnie Boden, who launched his catalogue company in 1992 from a one-bedroom flat, and now runs a business with 250 employees, 250,000 customers and a turnover of £29 million in 2000.

Boden writes the chatty copy for his catalogues - Boden and Mini Boden - himself ('Every time I see this skirt on, I can't help letting out a sigh of pleasure. And then I'm told I have to take it off. Juuust joking.') and still uses friends and contacts as models.

His life revolves around work and his family - wife Sophie and daughters Anna, 6, Kate, 4, and Stella, one. 'I work from 8.30am to 7pm, and get home just in time to read them a story. Then I work for a couple of hours in the evening.'

Boden went to Eton and Oxford, and ended up working for Warburgs as an institutional stockbroker on £100,000 a year. Then, while on a posting to New York in 1988, he discovered the world of mail order. US catalogues were light years ahead of the UK's, selling good-quality, classic clothes at competitive prices. He decided to try the same formula, investing £200,000 of his own money in launching a menswear catalogue. Two years later he expanded to womenswear, and in 1996 to children's.

His career change had a severe effect on his income. He owns 60 per cent of the business, but any plans to sell or float are a long way off. 'If there's anything I miss about the City, it's the money. All my friends think I'm loaded, but like any other businessman I can only pay myself a reasonable salary. If you want to build up good management, it's very demotivating to be seen with your snout in the trough.'

He is a great believer in his product, and he and his family wear little else. While being interviewed he was wearing Stanleys (suede shoes) and moleskin flat-fronted trousers from last Autumn's catalogue - 'and I wouldn't dream of wearing any other company's boxer shorts'.

The company offers about 500 different styles and there have been mistakes. 'The worst was towelling shorts in orange. I think we ordered 500 pairs and sold 10.'

Boden says he is not a big spender. The family live in a fairly expensive - but not the most expensive - part of West London, their daughters go to private school, but the couple don't go out that much. Their main luxury is a second home in Dorset which they have used for all their family holidays so far.

Boden is quite organised when it comes to personal finances. 'A friend advised me to buy Quicken [financial management software] and it has revolutionised my finances. I can now see where I'm spending.'

He has a £250,000 mortgage, and says: 'The best thing I have done is use a mortgage broker. I'm very pleased with my deal, a discounted loan with the Portman Building Society.'

He has a personal pension with Skandia, which allows him to pick funds from a wide range of managers.'I read the FT every weekend and follow its allocation recommendations. I don't have the time or expertise to invest directly in stocks.'

webTitle: Million old people neglect to claim

fields.headline: Million old people neglect to claim
fields.trailText: More than a million older people are expected to be missing out on means-tested state benefits by the time new payments are introduced on 6 April.
fields.body:
More than a million older people are expected to be missing out on means-tested state benefits by the time new, more generous payments are introduced on 6 April.

Age Concern's Your Rights Week, launched last Friday, aims to rectify this situation. It intends to inform pensioners about all the money they are entitled to.

In April income support for poorer pensioners, otherwise known as the minimum income guarantee, will rise from £78.45 to £92.15 for a single person. This means that pensioners with savings under £6,000 will have their basic state pension topped up by £19.75. Those with savings of up to £12,000 will get slightly less.

However, 670,000 pensioners do not claim the income support they could, and a further 100,000 will become eligible under the rule changes. Even more neglect to claim means-tested council tax benefit, because they do not realise they are eligible or are too proud to claim.

To find out more about your benefit rights ring Age Concern on 0800 00 99 66.

webTitle: Put your back into it...

fields.headline: Put your back into it...
fields.standfirst: Workers must fight for proper seating - it could save £3.8 billion, says Jim Pollard
fields.trailText: Add the population of Paris to the population of London and what do you get? Slightly fewer people than the total number of back pain victims in the UK right now. Over the past few years, it may have been eclipsed by stress, depression and long hours in discussions about occupational health, but for 16 million sufferers, back pain has never gone away. It is still the biggest physical reason for sick days - the Trades Union Congress estimates it costs the economy £3.8billion a year - and there is evidence it may be getting worse.
fields.body:
Add the population of Paris to the population of London and what do you get? Slightly fewer people than the total number of back pain victims in the UK right now. Over the past few years, it may have been eclipsed by stress, depression and long hours in discussions about occupational health, but for 16 million sufferers, back pain has never gone away. It is still the biggest physical reason for sick days - the Trades Union Congress estimates it costs the economy £3.8billion a year - and there is evidence it may be getting worse.

'Our increasingly sedentary lifestyles may be partly to blame,' says ergonomic consultant Dr Kevin Tesh. 'Driving, sitting statically in front of the computer, slouching in front of the TV - all increase our risk of back pain.'

Younger workers may assume that it takes many years of this sort of abuse before back problems develop. Not so. The nature of their work may be putting young people at greater risk.

Last month the TUC published a survey showing that more than half of people aged 16-24 work in 'awkward or tiring positions' (against 45 per cent of the total workforce); 78 per cent have jobs involving repetitive movements (compared with 65 per cent); and 71 per cent have to work quickly (60 per cent). In fact, on all the major risk factors in the survey, young workers scored highest. Back strain is also more common in small firms than larger ones, says the TUC, with seven out of 10 companies employing fewer than 20 people reporting problems. New working methods are creating new back problems. 'The proliferation of lap-tops is a big worry,' says Tesh. 'The problems can be worse than at a conventional set-up because either the screen or the keyboard is always in the wrong place.' Home offices are also a concern. Back pain may well develop over time but it can also flare up worryingly quickly. In Joanne Kerr's case, serious problems developed in just two months. 'I was at a City law firm working on publications,' she says. 'I needed a deep desk because my job required a big computer screen. So two desks were pushed together to make an L shape and I worked at the junction of the two. Because of the desk legs, I either had to sit with one of my legs at right angles or twist my legs around the desk legs. It was very uncomfortable.

'One day at home, when I bent over to pick up a towel, my back locked and I couldn't stand up. I had complained about the desk from day one but it wasn't until I came in doubled over with a prolapsed disc that they did anything about it. And even then they only removed the offending desk legs.'

Kerr needed two weeks off work on such strong pain killers and muscle relaxants that she could barely function. 'Luckily, in my health authority there was a fast-track system for lumbar problems and I saw a physiotherapist within the week.' Treatment was twice-weekly physiotherapy, traction and an exercise programme of 20 minutes, twice a day. Kerr is now back at work but still does 10 minutes of stretching daily. Prompt treatment is vital, says Tesh. 'The longer you go without, the more the muscles deteriorate. You need to keep active.' Many people with more serious back problems may, with a GP's referral, be entitled under the DfEE's Access To Work scheme to help with specialist equipment to get them back to work, including desks and chairs. 'Many doctors and patients don't realise this because backache has traditionally not been taken seriously,' says Julia Brown-Dow, disability consultant with Back Care.

'Because of the regulations, many employers now provide decent chairs,' says Tesh, 'but that's no good if they don't show staff how they work. Then there are working conditions. Mental strain leads to muscle strain. People under pressure and lacking job satisfaction are far more likely to have back and upper limb disorders.' Indeed, taken together, stress and musculo-skeletal disorders, including back pain and repetitive strain injuries, now account for 85 per cent of ill health and injury at work, says trade union MSF.

'The firm charged clients hundreds of pounds an hour so I'd like to think they just didn't know about adjustable workstations rather than that they were too mean to buy me one,' says Kerr. 'I certainly didn't know. I assumed my problem was just bad luck. Later I realised it was the cumulative effect of my working position.'

Tesh says: 'Ergonomists need to be involved when offices are designed. That's when we can have maximum impact at minimum cost.' This rarely happens but firms that don't make their workplaces safe have no excuse. The rules have been in place since 1992.

Mike Dixon, MSF's health, safety and environment officer, says: 'Employers must carry out a risk assessment at each workstation for each user. The workstation should allow each task to be carried out safely and comfortably at a suitable height.'

Theoretically, the Health and Safety Executive or environmental health departments can place improvement notices on dangerous workstations but this is seldom done. 'The regulations are there but there's a reluctance to enforce them,' says Dixon.

So it's down to you.

Call Back Care on 020 8977 5474

Spinal trap: How to avoid injury and discomfort

The chair
 The law says chairs used at workstations must be stable, comfortable, allow freedom of movement and be adjustable in both height and tilt

 This usually means a five-legged star shape base with a back that moves independently of the seat and supports the back so that it maintains its natural S shape (you can find where your back curves by running your knuckles up your spine) - if your chair doesn't provide support here, you may need a lumbar cushion.

Sitting at the desk
 Adjust the height of your chair so that when you use your keyboard, arms and shoulders are relaxed, elbows at right angles and forearms parallel to the floor. Thighs should also be parallel to the floor or inclined forward with a 3-5cm gap between the edge of your seat and your knees

 If you are tall you need a height-adjustable desk. Failing that put the desk on blocks.

 If your legs dangle over the chair, use a footrest

 Armrests should not get in the way of any of the above. If they do, move or remove them.

Display screen
 Site as large a screen as possible an arm's length away with the top of the screen at eye-level. Clean it frequently and make sure the type size, colour contrast and office lighting allow you to read it without squinting or leaning forward

Desk layout
There should be space between the keyboard and the edge of your desk to rest your wrists. Use a wrist-rest if it helps

 Keep the things you use frequently - especially the mouse - close by so you're not constantly stretching and reaching.

Using equipment
 Use the mouse and keyboard with gentle movements using the whole arm, keeping wrists horizontal.

 Don't shoulder-cradle the phone. Use a headset when talking and typing at the same time.

Working-habits
 Stop every 20 minutes. Employers must provide breaks - many short ones are better than a couple of long ones.

Lap-tops
 All the above applies to lap-tops, which is why they are best kept for occasional use. If you do use one in the office, use a separate screen.

Three easy exercises
 Pull chin and turn head slowly side to side.

 Raise shoulders to ears and back.

 Stand up feet slightly apart and knees bent. With hands in small of back, push hips forward and shoulders back. Repeat each five times every so often throughout the day.

webTitle: Job cuts that kill, not cure

fields.headline: Job cuts that kill, not cure
fields.standfirst:
Redundancies show Disney's chiefs to be mice, not men. By Simon Caulkin

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Redundancies show Disney's chiefs to be mice, not men. By Simon Caulkin
fields.body:
Here we go again. It seems barely five minutes since employees were the ostensible winners of the 'war for talent', soothed with lullabies extolling 'greatest assets' and courted with perks such as 'in-desk massage' and groceries delivered to your workstation.

Well, now they are hearing a less melodic tune. It is called 'Sorry, only some of our employees are our greatest assets'. As the US lurches out of the bubble into economic reality, companies on both sides of the Atlantic are launching a round of competitive job cuts.

Last week Disney joined giants such as Procter & Gamble, Cisco, Nortel and almost all the large US technology firms in announcing large redundancies - in this case 4,000 'cast members', the biggest-ever cast cuts carried out by the suddenly not-so-magic kingdom.

The unspoken truth is that beyond the ugly corporate-speak ('we need to face up to the pressing challenges of the softening economic environment,' quoth chief mouse Michael Eisner), the job carnage has almost nothing to do with the real health of the company and almost everything to do with the share price - and the chief executive's share options.

Prominent management educator and thinker Henry Mintzberg is appalled. 'It's insane,' he says. 'You have Nortel announcing that it's only going to grow 15 per cent this year instead of 30 per cent - so it starts firing people. This is the future of the company they're jeopardising!

'Managers at another big firm tell me they're having to cut everything - hospitality, stationery, phone bills, everything - and the boss earned $100 million last year, $85m in stock options. Every time the financial community says jump, companies just cut thousands of jobs. It's sick.'

Look a little closer at the Disney announcement. It isn't going to grow much this year - single-digit percentage points, it warned last month - but given its net profits of $1.1 billion last year, it is hardly down to its last lump of cheese. Yet sure enough 'we must also uphold investors' confidence in our future while maintaining our core commitment to quality and creativity,' as Eisner lectured his staff in an email last week,

Eisner addressed Disney employees as 'fellow cast members'. Soon-to-be-resting actors may feel that fellowship doesn't quite describe a company where the leading player has pocketed $636 million in the past three years, one-and-a-half times more than the annual savings of the current cull. Says Mintzberg: 'A real leader would be more concerned with the effect on the organisation than the amount of money paid to shareholders. This just destroys any identification with the company. It's getting worse and worse.'

The bitter irony in all this is that in the long term these needless job cuts are doubly self-subverting, satisfying neither markets nor companies' own needs.

As we should have learnt from the last bout of job-cutting in the mid-Nineties, downsizing by itself ('the process by which people who barely know what's going on get rid of those who do,' according to Mintzberg) is worthless. It doesn't make companies cleverer - just smaller. As gurus Gary Hamel and CK Prahalad have caustically observed: 'However lean and mean the company, it still needs a brain.'

Usually, of course, the issue isn't about mere size at all. And markets recognise this: they habitually downsize the shares of shrinking companies after the initial positive effect has worn off. At that point, the first attack on the payroll is apt to be followed by another. A good example is another recent firer, P&G. Two years ago the consumer goods giant declared it was pruning 15,000 jobs in its 'Organisation 2005' restructuring plan. The CEO who decreed those cuts, Dirk Jager, was subsequently ousted because, it was said, he had tried to go too far, too fast. Now, apparently, it was not far or fast enough: P&G is to take another 9,600 redundancies in the months ahead. What's the betting it won't work? According to Mercer Management Consulting, two-thirds of 120 US companies that concentrated on cost-cutting in the last recession failed to grow in the subsequent fat years.

All too often, execution (literally) gets decoupled from strategy, notes Linda Holbeche, director of Roffey Park Management College, which has done many studies of people management and its effects on corporate change programmes. While the rhetoric is of consolidation and growth, in reality the cull is invariably carried out by a small group of financially driven hitmen, says Holbeche. Just when they ought to be thinking outwards to the strategic needs in the recovery (in most downturns not more than 18 months away), they retreat behind closed doors and narrow the agenda.

She adds: 'They often cut themselves off at the knees in ways that prevent any future recovery. They've lost the art of learning from their own history - or that of others.'

The effect is compounded because most companies overestimate the benefits of job-cutting in exact proportion to the extent that they underestimate the costs. When redundancies are in the air, innovation comes to a halt, quality suffers and sales often stop dead. The company's 'relational wealth' - the intangible resources bound up in relationships of trust between the actors - may be severely, sometimes permanently, undermined.

Most of these things don't show up in the accounts, with the result that companies don't know where they can safely make cuts and where they can't. This is why across-the-board cuts are almost always self-defeating. All costs aren't alike, so that, as Mercer puts it, 10 per cent cuts in a crucial area (say after-sales service) can destroy 100 per cent of the value proposition.

Far from being a 'safe' option, large-scale retrenchments should usually be seen as a signal of trouble ahead - a sign that the company is in thrall to the market, and of weak, not strong, leadership. 'We need some leaders to stand up to this,' says Mintzberg. 'Just imagine the effect if a CEO said he refused to mortgage the company's future for the short-term satisfaction of the stock market. But it's not likely. The awful thing is that the board would probably fire him if he did.'
