Now, apparently, it was not far or fast enough: P&G is to take another 9,600 redundancies in the months ahead. What's the betting it won't work? According to Mercer Management Consulting, two-thirds of 120 US companies that concentrated on cost-cutting in the last recession failed to grow in the subsequent fat years. All too often, execution (literally) gets decoupled from strategy, notes Linda Holbeche, director of Roffey Park Management College, which has done many studies of people management and its effects on corporate change programmes. While the rhetoric is of consolidation and growth, in reality the cull is invariably carried out by a small group of financially driven hitmen, says Holbeche. Just when they ought to be thinking outwards to the strategic needs in the recovery (in most downturns not more than 18 months away), they retreat behind closed doors and narrow the agenda. She adds: 'They often cut themselves off at the knees in ways that prevent any future recovery. They've lost the art of learning from their own history - or that of others.' The effect is compounded because most companies overestimate the benefits of job-cutting in exact proportion to the extent that they underestimate the costs. When redundancies are in the air, innovation comes to a halt, quality suffers and sales often stop dead. The company's 'relational wealth' - the intangible resources bound up in relationships of trust between the actors - may be severely, sometimes permanently, undermined. Most of these things don't show up in the accounts, with the result that companies don't know where they can safely make cuts and where they can't. This is why across-the-board cuts are almost always self-defeating. All costs aren't alike, so that, as Mercer puts it, 10 per cent cuts in a crucial area (say after-sales service) can destroy 100 per cent of the value proposition. Far from being a 'safe' option, large-scale retrenchments should usually be seen as a signal of trouble ahead - a sign that the company is in thrall to the market, and of weak, not strong, leadership. 'We need some leaders to stand up to this,' says Mintzberg. 'Just imagine the effect if a CEO said he refused to mortgage the company's future for the short-term satisfaction of the stock market. But it's not likely. The awful thing is that the board would probably fire him if he did.' simon.caulkin@observer.co.uk

webTitle: That pay rise could be taxing

fields.headline: That pay rise could be taxing
fields.standfirst: Maria Scott offers a guide for newcomers to the higher-rate club
fields.trailText: Maria Scott offers a guide for newcomers to the higher-rate club.
fields.body:
A pay rise or promotion may be a bittersweet triumph if it turns you into a higher-rate taxpayer. This will be the fate of tens of thousands of people whose earnings rise in the forthcoming tax year.

In certain circles, becoming a 40 per cent tax payer might be viewed as a status symbol. But this club is not as exclusive as it was: More people are drawn into the 40 per cent tax bracket because the income threshold for triggering higher-rate tax has lagged behind earnings.

When Labour came to power in 1997 there were just over 2 million higher- rate taxpayers. By 1999/ 2000 there were 2.3 million.

This year, higher-rate tax will hit people with incomes of around £34,000. Each tax-payer has a personal allowance of £4,535, and the the first £1,880 of income beyond that will be taxed at 10 per cent. The next £27,520 is taxed at the basic rate of 22 per cent. The 40 per cent rate kicks in at earnings (after the personal allowance) of £29,400.

To be a higher-rate tax payer, therefore, you need to be earning little more than one-and-a-half times the national average earnings, which were £21,842 in April 2000.

Yet people on salaries of £34,000 or more - which now includes some senior teachers and nurses - would probably not consider themselves wealthy.

The Conservative Party plans to focus on higher-rate taxpayers during the general election campaign. If it wins, it will aim to lift the threshold towards the second half of the next Parliament to a level that would remove all those who have begun paying 40 per cent since Labour came to power.

If you become a higher-rate taxpayer you will have more dealings with the Inland Revenue because you will receive a return each year. When you first move into this bracket, your employer will normally collect the extra tax automatically. But you will also become liable to pay an extra 20 per cent on interest from bank and building society accounts, as well as 22.5 per cent more tax on share dividends.

You have until 5 October, following the end of the tax year in which you became a higher-rate payer to notify the Revenue. It is up to you to contact the tax office.

'You have to join the club,' explains Sharon Linnard, personal financial services partner at accountant KPMG. She points out that if you get your tax return in by 30 September and the amount owed is less than £2,000, you can have it deducted from your pay in the following tax year through your tax code.

Mike Warburton of accountant Grant Thornton points out that allowances once valuable to higher-rate taxpayers have been abolished. The married couple's allowance and mortgage tax relief were originally avail able at up to 40 per cent. Higher-rate taxpayers can benefit from the children's tax credit, which is a partial replacement for the married couple's allowance, but this is aimed only at couples with children. It is reduced on earnings of more than £30,000 and phased out completely at £40,000.

In a household with one higher-rate taxpayer and a non earning partner, there will be no credit if the earner has a salary of more than £40,000. But in a home with two £30,000 earners the full credit will be given.

Despite the disadvantages of being a higher-rate tax payer there are some benefits and several ways in which you can reduce your tax bills:

 You receive 40 per cent tax relief on contributions to pensions. Anyone in this tax group looking for investment opportunities should look first at their retirement funds. Warburton says: 'The first thing you do is your pension.'

 If you give to charity through the Government's Gift Aid scheme, you can reclaim the difference between basic-rate tax, at 22 per cent, and the higher rate of 18 per cent.

 Repaying mortgage debt becomes particularly worthwhile. Depending on your mortgage rate you can achieve the equivalent of double-figure returns.

 You may be able to cut your tax bills by putting investments in the name of a spouse or partner who pays a lower rate, or no tax at all.

 Tax free investments, primarily individual savings accounts (Isas) become particularly worthwhile.

 National Savings certificates may be attractive, despite their low nominal rates. A higher-rate taxpayer would have to earn 6.08 per cent on a taxable product to better the nominal 3.65 per cent fixed rate on National Savings two-year certificates.

 There are some investment opportunities such as venture capital trusts that may appeal to higher-rate tax payers with a taste for some risk.

webTitle: How to work with one who dislikes you

fields.headline: How to work with one who dislikes you
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: 1 Don't be upset if colleagues seem not to like you when they first meet you. Many people are scared of change - and you could trigger an automatic dislike if you are a bright young thing joining a workplace backwater, for instance. Like the children in The Sound of Music, however, colleagues could soon become very attached to you. Far more worrying is the reverse, where people go off you when they know you well.
fields.body:
1 Don't be upset if colleagues seem not to like you when they first meet you. Many people are scared of change - and you could trigger an automatic dislike if you are a bright young thing joining a workplace backwater, for instance. Like the children in The Sound of Music, however, colleagues could soon become very attached to you. Far more worrying is the reverse, where people go off you when they know you well.

2 Try to coax them into friendship in the usual low-key ways - helping them out, taking an interest in them and just being generally affable and telling jokes. If that does not work, you may be able to shrug off the issue: Gilbert and Sullivan, for example, were not great friends but still managed to produce the goods. If, however, your work is going to suffer, you need to consider raising the issue.

3 Choose a quiet and private moment to broach the subject, suggests management consultant Terry Gillen. 'The way you raise the subject is all important,' he says. 'Keep the focus on yourself.' If you say 'You don't like me' you are putting the focus on them in a way that will probably sound aggressive and elicit an unproductive response. If you say something like 'I may have the wrong end of the stick, but I wonder if there is something I do that bothers you' you are more likely to get a useful answer.

'The trick is to probe,' says Gillen. By asking questions like 'Do I do that often?' or 'Tell me why that bothers you?', you are more likely to get information you can act on. Try to listen without immediately jumping in to defend yourself.

4 Don't let yourself be undermined if hostilities persist. 'You need strong emotional support from friends and family,' says Jo Bond of Right management consultancy. It is often the most considerate people who question their own judgment when subjected to bullying. Try to get the views of friends if your colleague continues to make life difficult.

5 Think carefully about raising the issue with your boss - perhaps only if your department's work is being disturbed by the personality clash. Gillen says: 'Most bosses don't want to get involved in that sort of thing.'

You may end up feeling even more humiliated if you are just told to pull yourself together. So if you go to the boss, go as an adult with a suggested solution to the problem - rather than as a child wanting retribution for a playground spat.

webTitle: Ferguson fighting to match Liverpool's finest vintage

fields.headline: Ferguson fighting to match Liverpool's finest vintage
fields.trailText: Is this Manchester United team the greatest club side ever? Jim White compares Old Trafford's current crop with the great Liverpool teams of the past as Sir Alex Ferguson seeks to cement his side's place in history.
fields.body:
Back in January, after Manchester United destroyed West Ham 3-1 in the Premiership, several of the more seasoned members of the press box declared the performance the finest they had seen by a British club side. Sure-footed, quick, resolute, Sir Alex Ferguson's team played football of a brilliance that reduced their gifted opponents to the role of slack-jawed bystanders. Never, Andy Gray suggested on television, can such ascendancy have been witnessed in domestic football.

Such euphoria raised eyebrows on Merseyside more rapidly than at a Roger Moore lookalike convention. Despite the decade of success for the Manchester Reds, in the stands at Anfield they believe Fergie's mob still have some way to go before they match the dominance of Liverpool at their best. As the banner once unfurled in the Kop at a Liverpool-Manchester United match attested: "Form is temporary, class is permanent."

Much as Ferguson enjoys a football argument, there is no doubt he wants to end this one before he retires. United's manager would like to be remembered as the man who built the finest ever British club team. Another landmark to posterity is almost in his grasp, as United look certain to join Arsenal, Huddersfield and Liverpool in recording a hat-trick of consecutive championship wins.

At their strongest United can claim to possess the finest club midfield in the world, built around the genius of Roy Keane. Their speed of counter-attack, allied to four top-drawer strikers, is enough to petrify any defence. Nevertheless the real test of their historical mettle remains unanswered: do they measure up to the greatest ever Liverpool team?

It is a curious anomaly that the most successful Anfield side in terms of trophy accumulation was managed not by Bill Shankly, Bob Paisley or even Kenny Dalglish, but by Joe Fagan. Having graduated from the legendary Liverpool boot room in 1983, his first of only two seasons in charge, Fagan presided over a treble of his own: the championship, the European Cup and the League Cup. And he did it with a side who, though lacking the beauty of Dalglish's 1988 team or the drive of Paisley's 1977 outfit, have a claim to being the most efficient of them all.

Even so, if Fagan's Liverpool side were transported to the present day to take on Ferguson's United, there is no question who would win. Propelled by medically monitored diets, unencumbered by midweek alcohol binges, and with injuries treated by scientifically observed rest and recuperation rather than industrial quantities of cortisone, Keane and his boys would wallop the time travellers. Fitter, quicker and stronger, they are also infinitely better prepared.

Training ethos

Looking back on the way Fagan's Liverpool team approached the game, you wonder how they won anything. In 1984 their right-back Phil Neal played much of the season with a broken toe, an injury he didn't dare report for fear of losing his place. These days, the moment Ryan Giggs touches the back of his thigh, a fully qualified physiotherapy staff of nine is scrambled to massage his tender hamstrings back into shape.

Plus there is a much more sophisticated training ethos at United's Carrington complex. Back then Liverpool largely prepared on a diet of five-a-sides. The coaching staff would not presume to tell the players how to approach free-kicks, say, or corners. Actually they would not tell them very much at all. Kenny Dalglish was the first Liverpool manager to pay any heed to the opposition, the first to alter tactics and team selection to address opponents' strengths or weaknesses. Until then players were left to their own devices.

Jan Molby, who arrived in the summer of 1984 from Ajax, was amazed at the lack of instruction he received at Anfield. Used to the Ajax method of intensive one-to-one sessions with coaches, as he strapped on his boots before making his debut he realised no one at his new club had told him anything about how they wanted to him to play. So he cornered Fagan and asked what he should do.

"Don't worry, lad," said Fagan. "We've watched you play, we know you're good. Just go out there and try and fit in."

Amateurish though their preparation may seem, Liverpool then were a product of their times, and should be judged by the way they dominated them. After all, they won a few games. And in many ways, even though in 1983-84 Fagan became the first manager in history to win the championship in his first season (an achievement his successor, Dalglish, was soon to match), the players did it largely by managing themselves.

"Much of the leadership and organisation essentially came from within the dressing room," says Professor John Williams, the football academic and author of Passing Rhythms, an examination of Liverpool's era of dominance. "Dalglish sorted out the front end of the team, Alan Hansen the back. And Fagan would never have presumed to instruct the players how to behave off the field either. That responsibility was left to the senior players. And you only have to look at Ian Rush's autobiography to see that serious drinking sessions were frequent."

Such behaviour would not be tolerated at Ferguson's United (or, indeed, Gerard Houllier's Liverpool). But there is no question that the one-for-all, all-for-one mentality generated in the Anfield dressing room was the engine that drove the great team. And team is the operative word. With players such as Alan Kennedy, John Wark, Sammy Lee and Craig Johnston, nobody could claim this as a collection of top-notch operators in the manner, say, of the current Real Madrid. Every week, though, the team played as an entity greater than the sum of its parts.

"There is no argument that, if you are comparing squads, the current United one wins hands down," Williams says. "But if you are looking for a team, that Liverpool would be hard to touch."

It is all there in the statistics. In 1983-84, in the days when rotation was something feudal farmers did, Liverpool used 15 players in 42 league games. So far this season, in 30 matches, United have used 23. In 1984 Bruce Grobbelaar, Kennedy and Mark Lawrenson played every league game; Rush and Neal (broken toe and all) played in every game bar one. The closest United have to an ever-present is Gary Neville, who has missed only one of their league games this season; Giggs, meanwhile, has started only 19 times in the Premiership.

That Liverpool familiarity led to an almost telepathic ability with a pass. And a collective ruthlessness which was not always pretty to watch.

Pass masters

"People forget how terribly dull they could be away from home," Williams says. "They weren't interested in scoring, just winning. I'm not sure you could get away with that these days. There is much more public scrutiny, there's live television coverage from the most obscure European destination. You can't have that hidden away stuff. United now go away and try to win well in a way Liverpool then didn't need to."

However they did it (they were masters of the back-pass to the keeper), perhaps the best measure of Fagan's Liverpool side was that, in the European Cup in 1984, they won away in the quarter-final against Benfica, away in the semi-finals in Bucharest and, to all intents, away in the final against Roma, as it was played in the Italians' stadium.

"The fact that game was won in Rome on penalties is perhaps an even greater achievement," says Kevin Sampson, the novelist and Liverpool follower. "The penalties took place at the Roma end but they weren't intimidated and just did their job."

That was the night Grobbelaar, with his comedy wobbly-knees act, personified Liverpool's attitude: "Watching that side you had the definite feeling of impregnability," Sampson says. "You'd look at that spine of Lawrenson, Hansen, Souness, Rush and Dalglish, and just couldn't see how they would be beaten.

"Dalglish is the greatest Liverpool player ever. Who comes into the next category is more contentious, but Dalglish is unequivocally the best. He relished scoring beautiful goals, and putting through those passes to Rush. You look at the present United team: Giggs, Keane, Beckham - all world class. And you could make a case for Paul Scholes. But could you really see Andy Cole getting past Hansen?"

Maybe not, but Beckham would have roasted Kennedy. Indeed, with Dalglish against Jaap Stam, Giggs against Neal and - reach for the crash helmets - Keane against Souness, a game between the two greats would be mouth-watering. But whoever won the subjective battle, United fans would have this comfort: Anfield regulars might be able to argue the merits of past Liverpool sides, but United's excellence is in the present.

For Sven-Goran Eriksson's latest game in charge of the national side, seven United players were on the field at the final whistle; Liverpool could boast only one. Even in the halcyon days of 1984, Neal and Lee were the only Merseyside Reds to wear three lions on his chest - although Liverpool fans will point out that the rest of the side did all play international football, the majority for Scotland.

How long United's superiority will last is the question. This lunchtime's match may be the least anticipated clash for years, but the balance of power between the two clubs stands at an intriguing junction.

Back in 1986, Alex Ferguson arrived at Old Trafford to find a squad of underachieving, over-drinking dilettantes. He immediately focused their minds on the great winning machine down the road: outperform Liverpool, he told them, and you will outperform everyone. His first success was in cups, where he injected the victory habit into the dressing room, ready for a league challenge. But he was helped immeasurably when, four years in, Liverpool messed up their management succession and imploded.

Sound familiar? Well, in 1998 Houllier arrived at Liverpool to find a squad of underachieving, over-drinking socialites. He immediately focused their minds on the great team down the road - beat Manchester United and you'll beat everyone - and is now beginning to instil a winning habit via cup competitions. Whether the next stage opens up for him, however, is largely down to the United board.

"For every Liverpool fan the day of Ferguson's retirement cannot come soon enough," says Sampson. "He is the man, and we all pray he takes the recipe with him."

In football, history is in the past. It is the future that counts.

Fabien Barthez

When he keeps his arms down, the best in the Premiership. 8

Gary Neville

Driven, committed and uncompromising, the soul of United. With an excellent attacking touch. 7

Mickael Silvestre

Once seen as the weakest link, now developing into some player. Not yet Paolo Maldini. One day, maybe. 6

Jaap Stam

Bald bulwark who terrifies the opposition. And that's just during the warm-up. This season, though, spoiled by injury. 7

Wes Brown

England's greatest defensive prospect since Bobby Moore. But still learning. 7

David Beckham

Off colour of late, but no one can gainsay his excellence. 8

Roy Keane

Astonishing appetite, strength and football brain. World class. 10

Paul Scholes

The nearest thing to a present-day Dalglish: quick feet, quick mind, with power coming from a backside the size of Salford. 9

Ryan Giggs

His speed makes him untouchable. When he's fit. 8

Andy Cole

Emphatic in United colours, whatever he does in the white of England. 7

Teddy Sheringham

Enjoying a 20-goal Indian summer. According to Glenn Hoddle, the first two yards are in his brain. Which explains the big head. 7

Total: 84

Bruce Grobbelaar

What was seen as eccentricity now compromised by allegations of match fixing. Good shot stopper, though. 6

Phil Neal

Strong, reliable, great with a penalty. And a broken toe. 7

Alan Kennedy

On paper a limited player, but he thrived in the company of greatness. 6

Mark Lawrenson

Quick, slick, skilful. Blessed with apparently telescopic legs. 8

Alan Hansen

As above, only more so. Plus, as relaxed on the pitch as he is in the television studio. 9

Sammy Lee

Small, chirpy and non-stop. Now on the Anfield coaching staff, seemingly not having aged at all. 7

Graeme Souness

Fearsome, ruthless, yet extravagantly skilful. The stiletto in a silk glove. 9

John Wark

Midfield workhorse, signed halfway through the season and slotted in as if he had been born on the Mersey. 6

Craig Johnston

The original Aussie with attitude. Underestimated at opponents' peril. 7

Kenny Dalglish

The man who made the difference. 10

Ian Rush

Scored 32 league goals that year, mainly gorging on Dalglish passes. 9

"Much of the leadership and organisation essentially came from within the dressing room," says Professor John Williams, the football academic and author of Passing Rhythms, an examination of Liverpool's era of dominance. "Dalglish sorted out the front end of the team, Alan Hansen the back. And Fagan would never have presumed to instruct the players how to behave off the field either. That responsibility was left to the senior players. And you only have to look at Ian Rush's autobiography to see that serious drinking sessions were frequent." Such behaviour would not be tolerated at Ferguson's United (or, indeed, Gerard Houllier's Liverpool). But there is no question that the one-for-all, all-for-one mentality generated in the Anfield dressing room was the engine that drove the great team. And team is the operative word. With players such as Alan Kennedy, John Wark, Sammy Lee and Craig Johnston, nobody could claim this as a collection of top-notch operators in the manner, say, of the current Real Madrid. Every week, though, the team played as an entity greater than the sum of its parts. "There is no argument that, if you are comparing squads, the current United one wins hands down," Williams says. "But if you are looking for a team, that Liverpool would be hard to touch." It is all there in the statistics. In 1983-84, in the days when rotation was something feudal farmers did, Liverpool used 15 players in 42 league games. So far this season, in 30 matches, United have used 23. In 1984 Bruce Grobbelaar, Kennedy and Mark Lawrenson played every league game; Rush and Neal (broken toe and all) played in every game bar one. The closest United have to an ever-present is Gary Neville, who has missed only one of their league games this season; Giggs, meanwhile, has started only 19 times in the Premiership. That Liverpool familiarity led to an almost telepathic ability with a pass. And a collective ruthlessness which was not always pretty to watch. Pass masters "People forget how terribly dull they could be away from home," Williams says. "They weren't interested in scoring, just winning. I'm not sure you could get away with that these days. There is much more public scrutiny, there's live television coverage from the most obscure European destination. You can't have that hidden away stuff. United now go away and try to win well in a way Liverpool then didn't need to." However they did it (they were masters of the back-pass to the keeper), perhaps the best measure of Fagan's Liverpool side was that, in the European Cup in 1984, they won away in the quarter-final against Benfica, away in the semi-finals in Bucharest and, to all intents, away in the final against Roma, as it was played in the Italians' stadium. "The fact that game was won in Rome on penalties is perhaps an even greater achievement," says Kevin Sampson, the novelist and Liverpool follower. "The penalties took place at the Roma end but they weren't intimidated and just did their job." That was the night Grobbelaar, with his comedy wobbly-knees act, personified Liverpool's attitude: "Watching that side you had the definite feeling of impregnability," Sampson says. "You'd look at that spine of Lawrenson, Hansen, Souness, Rush and Dalglish, and just couldn't see how they would be beaten. "Dalglish is the greatest Liverpool player ever. Who comes into the next category is more contentious, but Dalglish is unequivocally the best. He relished scoring beautiful goals, and putting through those passes to Rush. You look at the present United team: Giggs, Keane, Beckham - all world class. And you could make a case for Paul Scholes. But could you really see Andy Cole getting past Hansen?" Maybe not, but Beckham would have roasted Kennedy. Indeed, with Dalglish against Jaap Stam, Giggs against Neal and - reach for the crash helmets - Keane against Souness, a game between the two greats would be mouth-watering. But whoever won the subjective battle, United fans would have this comfort: Anfield regulars might be able to argue the merits of past Liverpool sides, but United's excellence is in the present. For Sven-Goran Eriksson's latest game in charge of the national side, seven United players were on the field at the final whistle; Liverpool could boast only one. Even in the halcyon days of 1984, Neal and Lee were the only Merseyside Reds to wear three lions on his chest - although Liverpool fans will point out that the rest of the side did all play international football, the majority for Scotland. How long United's superiority will last is the question. This lunchtime's match may be the least anticipated clash for years, but the balance of power between the two clubs stands at an intriguing junction. Back in 1986, Alex Ferguson arrived at Old Trafford to find a squad of underachieving, over-drinking dilettantes. He immediately focused their minds on the great winning machine down the road: outperform Liverpool, he told them, and you will outperform everyone. His first success was in cups, where he injected the victory habit into the dressing room, ready for a league challenge. But he was helped immeasurably when, four years in, Liverpool messed up their management succession and imploded. Sound familiar? Well, in 1998 Houllier arrived at Liverpool to find a squad of underachieving, over-drinking socialites. He immediately focused their minds on the great team down the road - beat Manchester United and you'll beat everyone - and is now beginning to instil a winning habit via cup competitions. Whether the next stage opens up for him, however, is largely down to the United board. "For every Liverpool fan the day of Ferguson's retirement cannot come soon enough," says Sampson. "He is the man, and we all pray he takes the recipe with him." In football, history is in the past. It is the future that counts. With an excellent attacking touch. 7 Mickael Silvestre Once seen as the weakest link, now developing into some player. Not yet Paolo Maldini. One day, maybe. 6 Jaap Stam Bald bulwark who terrifies the opposition. And that's just during the warm-up. This season, though, spoiled by injury. 7 Wes Brown England's greatest defensive prospect since Bobby Moore. But still learning. 7 David Beckham Off colour of late, but no one can gainsay his excellence. 8 Roy Keane Astonishing appetite, strength and football brain. World class. 10 Paul Scholes The nearest thing to a present-day Dalglish: quick feet, quick mind, with power coming from a backside the size of Salford. 9 Ryan Giggs His speed makes him untouchable. When he's fit. 8 Andy Cole Emphatic in United colours, whatever he does in the white of England. 7 Teddy Sheringham Enjoying a 20-goal Indian summer. According to Glenn Hoddle, the first two yards are in his brain. Which explains the big head. 7 Total: 84 Bruce Grobbelaar What was seen as eccentricity now compromised by allegations of match fixing. Good shot stopper, though. 6 Phil Neal Strong, reliable, great with a penalty. And a broken toe. 7 Alan Kennedy On paper a limited player, but he thrived in the company of greatness. 6 Mark Lawrenson Quick, slick, skilful. Blessed with apparently telescopic legs. 8 Alan Hansen As above, only more so. Plus, as relaxed on the pitch as he is in the television studio. 9 Sammy Lee Small, chirpy and non-stop. Now on the Anfield coaching staff, seemingly not having aged at all. 7 Graeme Souness Fearsome, ruthless, yet extravagantly skilful. The stiletto in a silk glove. 9 John Wark Midfield workhorse, signed halfway through the season and slotted in as if he had been born on the Mersey. 6 Craig Johnston The original Aussie with attitude. Underestimated at opponents' peril. 7 Kenny Dalglish The man who made the difference. 10 Ian Rush Scored 32 league goals that year, mainly gorging on Dalglish passes. 9 Total: 84

webTitle: Impatient fans can expect Hod-carriers before glory

fields.headline: Impatient fans can expect graft before the glory days
fields.trailText: Appointing a memory to manage a myth smacks of a gambling instinct not readily associated with the new pennywise owners of Tottenham Hotspur.
fields.body:
Appointing a memory to manage a myth smacks of a gambling instinct not readily associated with the new pennywise owners of Tottenham Hotspur. Recollections of Glenn Hoddle are fresh and invigorating but the idea that as a club Spurs are sleeping beauties waiting to be reawakened by a kiss is fanciful.

This did not concern Spurs supporters last night as they greeted Hoddle's return to White Hart Lane as manager just in time for two tilts at Arsenal, one in the FA Cup semi-finals. But do the club's new owners Enic really know the man any more than they know the club?

Fourteen years ago Hoddle scored his last league goal for Tottenham in a manner etched on the minds of those who have clamoured for his recall as manager. As Hoddle took the ball from the halfway line through the straggled ranks of Oxford United he sold enough dummies to stock a creche.

That moment, however, was hardly typical of Hoddle. After one prolific season for Spurs he scored less and less often, and usually from free-kicks. He was content to pass the ammunition while no doubt praising the Lord. Providing chances for others was his stock-in-trade.

As a player Hoddle was never a cavalier. When it came to forward runs he tended to err on the side of caution. In any case why run 50 yards when you can achieve a better effect with a 40-yard pass?

As a manager, with Swindon, Chelsea, England or Southampton, his approach has been much the same: get the team right at the back, then use this as an attacking base. So far he has produced sides more efficient than spectacular, worthy rather than wonderful, and with wing-backs instead of full-backs.

Hoddle is as much of a pragmatist as George Graham and his arrival will not insulate Tottenham against goalless draws. It will be surprising, however, if his Spurs team have four in a row, the sequence which two months ago had fans at White Hart Line pining for the halcyon days of Christian Gross.

Enic has brought in Hoddle by popular demand. Graham might not have been sacked in a similar spirit but his dismissal, following the leakage of private meetings with directors to the press, did carry a hint of opportunism.

The immediate effect of Hoddle's second coming at Spurs will surely be to persuade Sol Campbell and Darren Anderton to stay. Campbell is an essential figure in defence, a totem around which the foundations of the next side can be dug. Anderton's future may again rest in the warm hands of Eileen Drewery, who helped the injury-prone winger before the 1998 World Cup.

At least everyone now knows what Hoddle is about. As Tottenham manager he can hardly face headlines any more bizarre than those which led to his downfall as England coach. The only reincarnation concerning Spurs supporters is the guise in which the next team will appear.

The one thing it will not contain is another Hoddle since he himself has admitted that the day of the midfield general is long gone. Modern football is largely about counter-attacking from the kind of solid platform Hoddle achieved when England were qualifying for the last World Cup. It demands from players athleticism, technique and imagination, and few footballers have all these qualities in equal measure.

Sven-Goran Eriksson played three of the Manchester United midfield in Albania on Wednesday but did not have an English Roy Keane at his disposal. Hoddle may not be at Tottenham very long before he wishes he had another Steve Perryman; no Keane, certainly, but perhaps a humbler version of Lothar Matthaus.

If distance lends disenchantment the worst favour Danny Blanchflower ever did Spurs was to declare that football was about glory. Ever since then several generations of players, managers and fans have hunted the same amid growing disillusionment.

Now a situation has been reached in which the club are striving to recapture the past much as the Monty Python team sought the Holy Grail; a cut-price quest which had a man imitating horses' hooves with coconut shells.

Coconuts but hardly peanuts. Enic are reportedly ready to provide £50m for new players, yet even that is not going to buy much success, whatever the form the next transfer system takes. In any case soaring wages rather than rising fees are now the nub of the argument.

Just how glorious were the old days at White Hart Lane anyway? To those fortunate enough to have watched Tottenham just before, during and immediately after the Double season of 1960-61 there was certainly a transient glory in the way the Spurs of Blanchflower, Dave Mackay, Bobby Smith and, a little later, Jimmy Greaves, put the standard of English First Division football on to a footing comparable with the exciting developments on the European mainland. But it did not last long.

Bill Nicholson's Double winners came together over a 10-year period following the 1951 championship triumph of Arthur Rowe's push-and-run team. Thereafter the idea of Tottenham replacing Arsenal as London's most likely league champions steadily receded with just a few cups amid the hiccups, but at least a sense of style persisted.

Between 1953 and 1989 the title went to Highbury only once, and that was when Bertie Mee and Don Howe's team won the Double in 1971. Since then Arsenal, first under Graham and then Arsene Wenger, have won the championship three more times while Tottenham have got through six managers and turned mediocrity into a fine art.

Terry Venables fell out with his chairman Alan Sugar, who sought to satisfy the fans by bringing back another Spurs favourite, Ossie Ardiles, whose team attacked like demons but defended like cherubs. So the commonsense of Gerry Francis was harnessed to the class of Jurgen Klinsmann, who left after one season never to return - at least not in recognisable form.

Francis gave way to Gross, who turned out to be Herbert Lom playing Napoleon after Waterloo, which brought in Graham, whom the supporters never forgave for being an Arsenal man.

Maybe Tottenham's fortunes are about to turn full circle. They enjoyed their greatest days under a former player, Nicholson, a dour but kindly figure, and were run by a board rarely seen or heard. Now they are about to be managed by Hoddle, a distant but decent bloke, and the directors are anonymous accountants. So Glory, Glory, Hallelujah then, although Arsenal will still face a team of hod-carriers in the semi-finals.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Travel insurance

fields.headline: Be sure you're covered, unlike Posh Spice
fields.trailText: As thousands of Britons prepare for a trip to the European sunspots over Easter, many will neglect travel insurance from their holiday checklist.
fields.body:
As thousands of Britons prepare for a trip to the European sunspots over Easter, many will neglect travel insurance from their holiday checklist.

Research from American Express reveals that 19% of Britons who take short breaks do not bother with travel insurance. However, whether you are jetting off for a few days or a few weeks, if you lose your luggage or fall ill while abroad, the cost of buying another set of clothes or emergency medical bills will take the gloss off the holiday.

And if, like Victoria Beckham, you have cases packed tight with expensive gear, then you need to shop around for a policy that will pay up when your co-ordinated Gucci luggage and contents go walkies. Basic off-the-shelf travel cover could leave you seriously under-insured, as such policies have strict limits on the amount that can be claimed for personal possessions.

Despite their best efforts, most holidaymakers will find themselves under-insured, like Posh Spice, especially if they are travelling with children or skiing equipment.

If you are travelling en famille, buying a family travel insurance package can be a good moneysaver. It works out much cheaper than purchasing individual policies, but the trouble is that, like sociologists, travel insurers seldom agree how many adults and how many children constitute a family. Nor can they agree on what age limits apply to children.

Each insurer's take on the number of children covered, their ages and their relationship to the adults vary widely between travel policies.

Some insurers still have the classic idea of a nuclear family with two adults and two kids, while others cover an unlimited number of children travelling with the adults. The message is read the fine print before signing up.

However, some more enlightened insurers are making special allowances for single-parent families or same-sex partners, but, as ever, prices vary widely. Parents with four or more children can save a fortune by picking the right policy.

Club Direct is launching an annual multiple trip travel policy next week, with premiums ranging from £39.25 for a single person travelling to Europe and £75.75 for a Europe-bound family that covers an unlimited number of youngsters, including foster children. The premium for a single-parent family holidaying in Europe is set at £58.75 a year. Further details and quotes form its freephone helpline 0800 074 4556.

For those who like to let their mouse do the shopping, Moneynet.co.uk is offering travel insurance deals with yearly premiums ranging from £32.51 to £97.69.

webTitle: Routes of passage

fields.headline: Routes of passage
fields.standfirst: From Cornwall to Edinburgh, there are some countryside walks that have escaped the clampdown.  Roly Smith leads the way
fields.trailText: From Cornwall to Edinburgh, there are some countryside walks that have escaped the clampdown. Roly Smith leads the way
fields.body:
There'll always be an England
While there's a country lane.

The Dunkirk spirit of Hughie Charles's Second World War song seems to echo the current situation on walking in the countryside during the foot and mouth crisis.

Britain is blessed with an abundance of country lanes, and, as long as walkers abide by the rule of the road - avoid the dangerous "rat-runs" increasingly used by nouveau-rural, 4x4-mounted townies, they should be safe.

In addition to lane and village walking, there are also still some areas of parkland, coast and open country which have remained open to walkers.

Here are some suggestions:

Castleton, Derbyshire

Castleton stands on the Great Divide of Peak District geology - on the junction between the limestone White Peak and the gritstone Dark Peak. It also boasts two of the Peak's ancient Seven Wonders, first extolled in the 17th century - Peak Cavern, the largest cave entrance in Britain, and Mam Tor, the "Shivering Mountain" on the outskirts of the village, which is at present still barred from access.

But there is much more to Castleton than its "Wonders," as this short village walk will show. Starting from the main car park, turn left into Cross Street and then right opposite the Bull's Head pub into Castle Street. A few yards up here on the left is the gateway to St Edmund's Parish Church, one of the oldest and most interesting in the Peak. The zig-zag decorated Norman chancel arch echoes exactly that of the entrance to Peveril Castle, on the crag above, perhaps indicating the same architect.

From the church, walk up to the Market Place, where a path in the corner (signposted) leads up a steep path to Peveril Castle, built by William Peveril shortly after the Conquest to oversee his hunting and lead mining interests in the Royal Forest of the Peak. Unfortunately, as access leads through grazing land, the castle remains closed.

Turn right down the lane to Goosehill Bridge, turning left on to the path which leads to the yawning entrance of Peak Cavern.

Recommended pub: The Castle, Castle Street, Castleton. Further information from: Castleton Information Centre, Castle Street, Castleton (01433 620679). Peak District National Park helpline: 01433 670207, www.peakdistrict-tourism.gov.uk

Coniston and Brantwood, Lake District

This is a walk with a difference, because it combines a trip across Coniston Water, scene of the recent raising of Donald Campbell's Bluebird, a visit to John Ruskin's spiritual home and a pleasant lane walk back to the village. It is one of a series of 12 which have been produced by the Lake District National Park Authority in a "Right Here, Right Now!" pack, which includes local attractions, events and activities still open in the National Park.

From the main car park in the centre of Coniston, take Lake Road down to the Pier and Landing Stage where the Coniston Launch Company offers a 20-minute cruise across the lake to John Ruskin's former home at Brantwood, on the eastern shore. Later in the season, the National Trust's ornate Victorian steam-driven launch, the Gondola, will provide a similar service. You can buy an inclusive ticket for £6.70.

Alighting at the pier at Brantwood, allow plenty of time to explore Ruskin's home from 1872 to his death in 1900. Take the lake-side lane which leads north from Brantwood towards Hawkshead, and which provides similar spectacular views over the lake towards the brooding shape of the Old Man. After about a mile, turn left just past How Head and descend by a minor lane to the head of the lake, passing a car park on your right. There are good views down the five-mile length of the lake before you join the B5385 and turn left, leaving the lake at Kirby Quay, back into Coniston village by Bannock Stone Bridge over Yewdale Beck.

Recommended restaurant: The Jumping Jenny (named after Ruskin's boat) at Brantwood. For further information, contact: Coniston Information Centre, Ruskin Avenue, Coniston (015394 41533); the Coniston Launch (Tel: 015394 36216)

Arthur's Seat, Edinburgh

The 640 acres of Holyrood Park, topped by the extinct volcanic plug of the 251m-high Arthur's Seat to the south east of Edinburgh city centre, has long been a health-giving "lung" for the wheezing residents of "Auld Reekie".

With no grazing animals allowed in the park for many years, it offers an ideal opportunity for a taste of hill walking, a stone's throw from the end of the cobbled Royal Mile. Our route starts from the car park in Holyrood Park Road, where you walk up towards the impressive volcanic sill formations of Salisbury Crags. Take the track leading off to the right and known as the Radical Road, suggested for public enjoyment by Sir Walter Scott, which leads up under the crags, the haunt of a colony of stiff-winged fulmars.

Eventually, the road descends towards the ancient Palace of Holyrood House, with, beyond it, the ultra-modern buildings of the new Scottish Assembly.

From St Anthony's Well, take the faint path that leads up below Haggis Knowe (also known as Fairies' Knowe or the Cockleshell), where a rocky path leads up to the 15th-century ruins of St Anthony's Chapel. Bear right and the path leads into a grassy valley called the Dry Dam, with Pulpit Rock away to your left.

Follow the path that leads up the centre of the gorse-covered valley, finally bearing right to join the steep, direct ascent to the summit of Arthur's Seat. After admiring the view, descend over the grassy former cultivation terraces east of Crow Hill to reach The Queen's Drive car park at the foot of Dunsapie Crag. From here take the 209 steps known as Jacob's Ladder down to the park gates at Duddingston and a well-earned pint at The Sheep Heid Inn - which claims to be the oldest pub in Edinburgh. From here it is a short step along Duddingston Road back to Holyrood Park Road.

Recommended pub: The Sheep Heid Inn (est 1320), Duddingston Village, Edinburgh. Further information from: Holyrood Park Information Centre ( 0131-556 1761).

Robin Hood's Bay, North Yorkshire

The impressive sweeping "scars" of Robin Hood's Bay, on the coastal fringe of the North York Moors south of Whitby, is one of the geological showplaces of Britain.

Our short walk starts from the central roundabout opposite the Victoria Hotel. Take the cliff-top path to the excellent viewpoint of Bank Top. Descend past the sea mine down the steep hill, passing the Laurel Inn, and then left just before reaching the bridge over the King's Beck along the higgledy-piggledy shops of cobbled Chapel Street. The street bends left into King Street, where you turn right, down into The Dock, opposite the Bay Hotel.

Walk back up King Street and turn right after the Dolphin Hotel, down steps which lead to the sea wall. Turn left to the end of the wall and climb more steps to the top of The Bank, where you turn right back to the car park.

Recommended restaurant: The Old Chapel, Chapel Street, Robin Hood's Bay. Further information from: Whitby Tourist Information Centre, Langbourne Road, Whitby (01947 602674).

Sutton Park, Sutton Coldfield

Sutton Park, just 10 miles from the centre of Birmingham, is an amazing survival story. It consists of more than 2,500 acres of largely unspoilt, ancient oak woodland, lowland heath, wetland and medieval mill and fish pools - a real taste of open country showing how the Midlands was before industrialisation.

Grazed by cattle only during the summer months, it has so far escaped the foot-and-mouth ban and is open to walkers, but not horse-riders, at present.

My favourite Sutton Park walk starts from the car park near Bracebridge Pool, which is reached off Hartop Road, which winds around the walled, north-eastern edge of the park. Bracebridge Pool is one of the oldest and most natural-looking lakes in the park. The Boat House and Bracebridge Cottage on the dam of the pool provides refreshment, but our path leads off to the right through the trees on the northern edge of the lake.

This is the famous Bridges Walk, known and loved by generations of children who delight in trying to count the numerous plank bridges which cross the drainage ditches. Eventually, you come to a pleasant, sandy "beach", another delightful spot of "wild country" in this amazing public park. Continue ahead along a path which is boggy at first but climbs through more ancient oaks and birches to reach Little Bracebridge Pool.

Go round the pool and turn left on a broad track before reaching the railway line that crosses the park, following it round through glades of oaks and stately beeches to emerge again at the Bracebridge Pool dam.

Recommended café: The Boat House, Bracebridge Pool, Sutton Park. Further information from: Sutton Park Visitor Centre ( 0121 355 6370).

Tintagel, Cornwall

The rocky headland on the north Cornish coast on which Tintagel Castle was built in the 12th century is now inescapably linked in the public mind with King Arthur. Indeed, the "Arthurian Industry" has taken a complete hold of the tiny north Cornish village.

Our lane walk starts from the village car park in Fore Street, where you turn right and then right again into Atlantic Road. At the end, turn left past Gavercombe Farm towards the entrance of King Arthur's Castle Hotel, built on Fire Beacon Hill in 1899. Ahead, but still barred to walkers, lies Barras Nose, a fine viewpoint which was one of the first properties to be acquired by the National Trust in 1896.

Retrace your steps to Fore Street and then turn right down Castle Road to reach Tintagel Haven straight ahead. You can descend (at low tide only) to the beach to inspect the legendary Merlin's Cave, where the baby Arthur was supposed to have been washed ashore.

Back on the road, turn right to inspect the remains of the monastery and 12th- century castle, which formerly existed on rocky heights of The Island. Return to the "mainland" to visit the main castle ruins on the right, which date from the 14th century and were built by Edward the Black Prince, and where there is a shop and exhibition centre. Walk back up the rocky valley on Castle Road, back into Fore Street and then right up Vicarage Hill, which leads into Church Hill by the vicarage and on to the mainly Norman church of St Materiana. This unusual dedication probably refers to St Madryn, a 6th-century Welsh princess who brought Christianity to the area.

Walk down Church Hill back into the village, turning right to walk along Fore Street to visit the Old Post Office, noting the two Dark Age granite crosses in front of the Wharncliffe Arms Hotel, before returning to your car.

Recommended pub: Wharncliffe Arms Hotel, Fore Street, Tintagel. Further information from: Tintagel Old Post Office (NT), Tintagel (01840 770024).
fields.bodyText: There'll always be an England While there's a country lane. The Dunkirk spirit of Hughie Charles's Second World War song seems to echo the current situation on walking in the countryside during the foot and mouth crisis. Britain is blessed with an abundance of country lanes, and, as long as walkers abide by the rule of the road - avoid the dangerous "rat-runs" increasingly used by nouveau-rural, 4x4-mounted townies, they should be safe. In addition to lane and village walking, there are also still some areas of parkland, coast and open country which have remained open to walkers. Here are some suggestions: Castleton, Derbyshire Castleton stands on the Great Divide of Peak District geology - on the junction between the limestone White Peak and the gritstone Dark Peak. It also boasts two of the Peak's ancient Seven Wonders, first extolled in the 17th century - Peak Cavern, the largest cave entrance in Britain, and Mam Tor, the "Shivering Mountain" on the outskirts of the village, which is at present still barred from access. But there is much more to Castleton than its "Wonders," as this short village walk will show. Starting from the main car park, turn left into Cross Street and then right opposite the Bull's Head pub into Castle Street. A few yards up here on the left is the gateway to St Edmund's Parish Church, one of the oldest and most interesting in the Peak. The zig-zag decorated Norman chancel arch echoes exactly that of the entrance to Peveril Castle, on the crag above, perhaps indicating the same architect. From the church, walk up to the Market Place, where a path in the corner (signposted) leads up a steep path to Peveril Castle, built by William Peveril shortly after the Conquest to oversee his hunting and lead mining interests in the Royal Forest of the Peak. Unfortunately, as access leads through grazing land, the castle remains closed. Turn right down the lane to Goosehill Bridge, turning left on to the path which leads to the yawning entrance of Peak Cavern. Recommended pub: The Castle, Castle Street, Castleton. It is one of a series of 12 which have been produced by the Lake District National Park Authority in a "Right Here, Right Now!" pack, which includes local attractions, events and activities still open in the National Park. From the main car park in the centre of Coniston, take Lake Road down to the Pier and Landing Stage where the Coniston Launch Company offers a 20-minute cruise across the lake to John Ruskin's former home at Brantwood, on the eastern shore. Later in the season, the National Trust's ornate Victorian steam-driven launch, the Gondola, will provide a similar service. You can buy an inclusive ticket for £6.70. Alighting at the pier at Brantwood, allow plenty of time to explore Ruskin's home from 1872 to his death in 1900. Take the lake-side lane which leads north from Brantwood towards Hawkshead, and which provides similar spectacular views over the lake towards the brooding shape of the Old Man. After about a mile, turn left just past How Head and descend by a minor lane to the head of the lake, passing a car park on your right. Follow the path that leads up the centre of the gorse-covered valley, finally bearing right to join the steep, direct ascent to the summit of Arthur's Seat. fields.trailText: Your guide to the cheapest flights around
fields.body:
Six top destinations

Sydney: £499

Olympic Airways from Heathrow or Manchester via Athens. Must be booked by April 18. Full payment required when booking. Valid for departures until June 30. No minimum stay, maximum one year. Quest Travel (0870 4445552).

Hong Kong: £394.

Alitalia from Gatwick via Milan or Rome. Valid for departures April 15 - July 15. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum three months. Thomas Cook Flights Direct (0870 7520066).

New York: £205

Air India from Heathrow. Tickets must be bought at least 21 days before departure. Valid for departures until May 31. No minimum stay, maximum 60 days. Trailfinders (020-7937 5400).

Los Angeles: £286

Continental Airlines from Gatwick via New York or Washington. Full payment required when booking. Valid for departures. April 16 - 30. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum six months. Airline Network (0800 727747).

Paris: £90.

British Midland from Heathrow. Valid for midweek departures April 1 - 30 (weekends £99). Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Thomas Cook Flights Direct (0870 7520066).

Amsterdam: £101

British Airways from Birmingham. Tickets must be bought at least three days before departure. Valid for departures until December 31. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Trailfinders (020-7937 1234).

The pick of the rest

Malaga: £75

Monarch Airlines from Gatwick. Departs May 6 for 11 or 12 nights. Avro (020-8695 4440).

Mexico City: £324

Air France from Heathrow, London City, Birmingham, Edinburgh, Glasgow, Manchester, Newcastle or Southampton via Paris. Valid for departures May 1 - June 18. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Journey Latin America (020-8747 3108).

Casablanca: £196

Alitalia from Heathrow via Rome. Valid for departures June 4 - 30. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum 20 days. Bridge The World (0870 4447474).

Muscat: £300

Royal Jordanian from Heathrow via Amman. Valid for departures until June 30. Minimum six days, maximum two months. Trail- finders (020-7938 3939).

And the rail alternative

Paris/Brussels: £70. Lille £60. Eurostar from Waterloo. Must be bought at least 14 days before departure. Minimum stay one Saturday night or two other nights. Eurostar (08705186186).

webTitle: 'Devon is still open and there's plenty to do and see'

fields.headline: 'Devon is still open and there's plenty to do and see'
fields.trailText: People are deciding to stay away in fear they might add to the situation. But, says Samantha Warwick, unless you make a concerted effort to travel up B roads, and farm tracks, it's unlikely you'll even see a MAFF warning. The countryside is as beautiful as it has always been.
fields.body:
Canary yellow daffodils surround the main Torquay roundabout, joining in abundance to spell out the name of the town. The blooms seem determined to put on a vibrant show, making a defiant and colourful statement that Devon's premier seaside resort, heart of the self-proclaimed English Riveria, is still open for business.

South West Tourism says the industry in Devon will have lost more than £300m by June due to the foot-and-mouth crisis. "People have seen the horrific sights of burning cattle on the news and now have a perception that they'll be engulfed in clouds of black smoke as soon as they hit the M4/M5. But this is just not the case," says Karen Martin, spokesperson for SWT. "Devon is still open and there's plenty to do and see." In the course of a weekend, driving and walking around the county, I did not see any animal pyres and indeed only came across one sign warning people to stay off the land due to the foot-and-mouth precautions.

But the televised images have taken their toll. Peter Morgan owns Orestone Manor, a beautiful 12-room hotel set in woodlands overlooking Maidencombe beach near Torquay. Refurbished 12 months ago, Morgan says his phone is not ringing. "We've had cancellations but more worrying is the lack of enquiries and bookings. Easter is looking very slow. With the best intentions, people are deciding to stay away in fear they might add to the situation. But unless you make a concerted effort to travel up B roads, and farm tracks, it's unlikely you'll even see a MAFF warning. The countryside is as beautiful as it has always been."

Although Dartmoor has been closed to ramblers, it's still possible to drive through the national park and enjoy its great pubs, such as the Rock Inn at Haytor, The Old Inn at Widecombe-in-the-Moor and The Cleave at Lustleigh. And, if it's walking you want, the South Devon coastline is among the most beautiful and dramatic in Britain.

Seaside walks abound, and vary from the kind that require a sturdy pair of walking boots to those that start and finish with a 99 cone from a Mr Whippy van (check www.devon4allseasons.co.uk for details). At Bigbury-on-Sea, try a spot of surfing or take the sea tractor over to the art deco hotel on Burgh Island. After surveying the timber-carved buildings in Dartmouth or wandering the riverside to the 15th-century castle, hop on the car ferry to Kingswear and drive to Brixham. A traditional fishing port with ice-cream-coloured houses there's a marina bobbing with wooden boats ready to take you shark or mackerel fishing ("keep all you catch!"), watch out for couples getting married afloat the full size replica of Francis Drake's The Golden Hind.

From the harbour, take the winding footpath to Berryhead, a conservation area with fortifications built during the Napoleonic wars on the southern limit of Torbay. The views of the red-cliffed coastline with Monterey pines and nesting sea birds are breathtaking. And the exercise will prepare you for a fresh Brixham crab sandwich. Ask anyone in the village for Graham the Crab's whereabouts.

Paignton, next. A real bucket-and-spade town, this, with a Quad track for thrill-seekers or multi-coloured beach huts for flask sippers. Torquay, its upmarket cousin with the famous palm trees (actually New Zealand cabbage trees), blue-and-white hotels and fairy-light harbour, has a real Mediterranean feel. Agatha Christie lived here (her former home is soon to open to the public), Spanish Armada prisoners were held captive at Torre Abbey and, of course, Basil and Sybil Fawlty used to offer slap-stick accommodation.

From Torquay, the drive to Exeter is stunning. Follow the coast road to Teignmouth and Dawlish. Stop at Cockwood for a Pint o' Prawns at The Anchor, then on past Powderham Castle, where deer graze on acres of picture postcard hills.

Beyond the exclusion zones, Devon has plenty to offer, from model villages and miniature railways to traditional stony or sandy beaches and working vineyards. As Peter Morgan says: "By keeping away, tourists will hit the farmers with a double whammy, as most either supply local produce to the hotels or have diversified into the tourist industry offering holiday homes and the like in a bid to supplement their original trade."

 Prices at Orestone Manor start from £50pp per night including a full English breakfast. Ask about special offers and packages when you call. For more details telephone 01803 328098 or check out the website at www.orestone.co.uk.

webTitle: Six in the city

fields.headline: Six in the city
fields.trailText: With trendy boutique hotels opening up faster than you can say chintz curtain, heaving bars and clubs to rival the capital's and a little bit of sightseeing thrown in for good measure, there's plenty to entertain you in some of the UK's hippest cities. Here is a quick guide to some British cities that you may not have thought of visiting recently.
fields.body:
With trendy boutique hotels opening up faster than you can say chintz curtain, heaving bars and clubs to rival the capital's and a little bit of sightseeing thrown in for good measure, there's plenty to entertain you in some of the UK's hippest cities. Here is a quick guide to some British cities that you may not have thought of visiting recently.

Where to stay: Hotel du Vin & Bistro, The Sugar House, Narrow Lewins Mead (0117 925 5577, www.hotelduvin.com).

Set in a Grade II-listed former sugar refinery in the city centre, the hotel's large, New York loft style, cream and black rooms are smart and modern, with leather armchairs, free standing baths, showers so huge you could get lost and vast, custom made beds complete with Egyptian cotton sheets. Don't come for the views, though; the hotel may be set on the waterfront, but the tall ships that once stood outside have been replaced with concrete and Tarmac. The hotel's bar is trendy but comfortable, with a snooker table and walk-in cigar humidor; a three course meal in the candle-filled bistro costs around £25. Double rooms from £109.

On the town: The newly opened Rock, housed in a converted cinema on Frogmore Street, is home to Bristol's beautiful people. One of the best sound systems in the country has attracted DJ luminaries such as Boy George, Seb Fontaine, Paul Oakenfold and Judge Jules.

Don't forget to: Oh, go on then, walk if you must - along the stunning Clifton Suspension bridge for views of the Avon Gorge, then back through bijou Clifton Village, packed with tearooms, boutiques, bookshops and restaurants. Recuperate at the wonderfully laid-back Boston Tea Party on Park Street.

Where to stay: Lace Market Hotel, 29-31 High Pavement, The Lace Market (reservations: 0800 1698817, www.planethotels.com).

Regency on the outside but younger on the inside, the smart but unpretentious Lace Market Hotel is Nottingham's first boutique hotel, set in the vibrant, newly-developed area of the same name. The 29 individually decorated rooms retain period features, including fireplaces and floor to ceiling windows (some with stunning views of St Mary's Church) and all the mod-cons you could wish for. The bathrooms are to die for, with sheer glass sinks, huge walk in showers and good sized tubs, complete with mountains of Molton Brown goodies and a silver platter of artfully arranged lemons for when you're feeling fruity. The restaurant, Merchant's, is so popular you're advised to book in advance, but the hotel doesn't stand on ceremony when it comes to breakfast with home comforts such as beans on toast and porridge with double cream. Doubles from £79.

On the town: Rev yourself up with cocktails in the hotel's lounge, then hit Media on Queen Street, winner of the Ericsson Muzik magazine Venue of the Year award and one of the UK's glammest superclubs.

Don't forget to: Sober up at the Galleries of Justice on Shire Hall High Pavement, an old style Chamber of Horrors with plenty of user friendly interactive tricks and spine chilling reminders of what happened to Nottingham residents of days gone by when they stepped out of line.

Where to stay: The Point, 34 Bread Street (0131-221 5555; www.point-hotel.co.uk).

Set in a former Co-op department store, this is the place to stay in Edinburgh. An almost intimidatingly trendy reception - all white walls and steel pillars - The Point was doing the fluorescent lighting thing way before Ian Schrager caught on. In stark contrast to the shimmering corridors, the white rooms are warm and restful, with walnut furniture and postcard views of the Castle. Beds big enough to throw a party in and a double Jacuzzi with leatherette headrests make it perfect for a naughty weekend; the ground floor restaurant and bar mean you don't have to go out unless you really, really want to. Doubles from £95.

On the town: Hang out in George Street, home to a number of clubs and bars. The Maghreb-themed Po na na (43b Frederick Street) is the place to go for late night vodka and Red Bulls, while Espionage (4 India Buildings, Victoria Street) offers massed drinking over four levels. Rose Street, the one with all the pubs in, is only a block away if you fancy drinking games.

Don't forget to: Pay a visit to the Dean Gallery, housed in Thomas Hamilton's 19th century Dean Orphan Hospital on Belford Road. This huge neoclassical building is home to a permanent collection of work by sculptor Sir Eduardo Paolozzi as well as changing exhibitions in the upstairs gallery.

Where to stay: Hotel Pelirocco, 10 Regency Square (01273 327 055; www.hotelpelirocco.co.uk).

Behind the Regency façade, the 18 individually themed rooms are very rock'n'roll. Couples can choose from one of the hotel's sexier rooms, including the 1950s style Betty's Boudoir, featuring lashings of leopard print and a spa bath for two, or Absolute Love with its velvet chaise longues and heart shaped headboard. Mad-fer-it clubbers should go for one of the hotel's more eccentric options -the Muhammad Ali room is decked out like a boxing ring; the Dotty Room, dedicated to Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama, features orange and black polka dotted walls; and Sugar Glider boasts pale blue walls painted with fluffy clouds and flying teapots.

The bar is open until 4am at weekends, but the fun doesn't stop there; each room comes equipped with a Sony PlayStation. Doubles from £70.

On the town: It' s got to be Concorde II on the seafront, home to Brighton's best club night, Boutique (previously the Big Beat Boutique) - if you're lucky you might even catch local DJ Fatboy Slim on the decks.

If you want to eat in, a simple deli style menu of sandwiches and pasta is served in the small lounge while the Irish breakfasts are huge and unmissable. Conveniently located for the airport and away from the hustle and bustle of the city centre, the hotel uses its leafy location to full effect. If you want to eat out, there's a shuttle service to the restaurant of your choice in Didsbury, while a 15 minute cab ride will take you into town. Doubles from £69.50.

A converted flour mill with old beams, lovely views of the canal and a very convenient location opposite Tetley's Brewery, 42 The Calls has played host to all manner of celebs including Vinnie Jones, James Brown, Robbie Williams and Baby Spice. Rooms are individually designed with fresh lilies, bowls of fruit and barley sugars, CD player and satellite TV. The handmade beds are super comfy - ideal for southern softies - and the bathrooms come equipped with wonderfully thick towels, bathrobes so huge you won't be able to fit them in your suitcase and posh smellies. If you want to eat in, there's a brasserie and the Michelin-starred Pool Court restaurant.

Don't forget to: Shop till you drop at Leeds' own branch of London superstore Harvey Nicks. Credit cards at the ready in the Victoria Quarter, home to a number of men's and women's boutiques, including Vivienne Westwood, with branches of designer emporiums Joseph and Flannels nearby.

webTitle: How to plan ahead

fields.headline: How to plan ahead
fields.standfirst: Here's a guide to websites that can help you find out what's open during the foot-and-mouth crisis
fields.trailText: A list of the websites that can help you find out what's open during the foot-and-mouth crisis, from closed attractions to restricted access
fields.body:
Good news for walkers and those looking forward to spring - country houses, parks and monuments are beginning to re-open for Easter, despite the relentless spread of foot and mouth disease. Here's a guide to planning your trips in light of the latest advice from the Government.

VisitBritain.com

The British Tourist Authority has drawn up a charter (which you could also recommend to friends visiting from abroad) setting out what you can and cannot do in the countryside. It points out that in some areas you can still play golf, stay in caravans and tents, sail, fish, row or canoe and occasionally use rights of way.

Cancelled events and attractions

List of events that have been postponed or cancelled and parks, walks, zoos and nature reserves that have been shut.

Countryside.gov.uk

A very well co-ordinated site with a map that enables you to click on any area of England and zoom in on the latest news releases and designated outbreak zones within it. A map of infected areas in Wales can be found at www.wales.gov.uk while Scotland's equivalent is available by visiting www.visitscotland.com, and Northern Ireland's at www.discovernorthernireland.com

National Trust

A large number of National Trust properties are expected to reopen in the period leading up to Good Friday, and a full list of them is online. (For Scotland, see www.nts.org.uk)

English Heritage

A similar list is updated daily.

British Waterways

British Waterways closed all its rural paths and watercourses on March 2, but is now starting to reopen them again. It has classified them as Level 0 (no precautions required); Level 1 (open to navigation with compulsory precautions); and Level 2 (open to navigation but which run through infected areas).

Association of National Park Authorities

At the time of writing, only Exmoor National Park is still open, and the ban extends to laybys on A-roads and golf courses. ANPA links to each of the park sites, which are often very detailed.

Forestry Commission

The commission is "progressively re-opening forests where it is safe to do so". The full lists are here.

British Mountaineering Council

Useful for all walkers, not just mountaineers. The BMC has taken the lead in keeping track of restricted areas.

Ramblers Association Urban Walks

An extensive collection of semi-rural and town walks for those who simply have to put their walking boots on. If you're heading north of the border, try www.walkingwild.com, which is the site co-ordinating walking in Scotland.

webTitle: Better never than late

fields.headline: Better never than late
fields.standfirst: There's nothing worse than a snow-free resort.  John Sweeney  on the perils of spring skiing
fields.trailText: There's nothing worse than a snow-free resort. John Sweeney on the perils of spring skiing
fields.body:
He was as sad, in Lichtenberg's phrase, as a dead bird's bird bath. Had his girlfriend stormed out, professing undying ardour for a Bulgarian love rival? Had his pet Chinese Shar-Pei passed on to doggy paradise? Or were the Plovdiv mafia after him?

The mournful demeanour of the rep on the coach from Bulgaria's Sofia airport hinted at hidden sorrow. It wasn't hacking sobs, snotty-nosed, externalised grief, but nor was it exactly Hi-de-hi. If I was a psychiatrist, I'd say he suffered from clinical depression.

So, what was the snow like?

The snow is not so good at the bottom, but there is some at the top, he intoned sadly into the coach microphone.

Good snow at the top, then, eh?

No, I would not say it was good snow, he said, and the long, dark night of the Bulgarian soul enveloped us like a black shroud.

The bad news was that the lower slopes of the ski resort of Borovets were denuded of snow. The good news was the gondola would whisk us high to the top of the mountain to the remaining snow.

At the foot of the gondola, the bad news was that it was windy up top, and so the gondola was closed. At the bottom of the resort, we were looking at zero snow. The sun climbed higher in the sky.

A little daunted, we trooped off to practise on the nursery slope, a football pitch-sized scum of browning slush. On the edge of it, a caterpillar-tracked slush-mover trudged up and down, moving the slush around the pitch.

Our guide hove into view, not quite the Italian god of my first week's skiing in the French Alps or the haughty but dry-witted and screamingly funny English lady of a certain age of my second week in Andorra, more like a Balkan Arthur Daley. His name was, if memory serves, Arsenic. Arsenic wasn't a bad chap or a bad ski instructor. But the fates were against him. By now everyone else had clumped on to the football pitch. Dozens of us robotically performed the snow plough. Most of us were considerably better than snow plough level, but Arsenic said he was concerned about our safety.

In fact, the main dangers had to do with the absence of snow. Like coming to a dead stop in the slush, or crashing into one of the beginners, or, worst, avoiding them and crashing into the caterpillar- tracked slush-mover.

It was depressing. One sloughed through the slush and came to a soggy dead stop. People started peeling off their ski gear, because it was getting so hot.

At lunchtime we wolfed down chicken and chips, washed down with beer. It was very, very cheap. Then came the good news: the gondola was now open. It took us high above Borovets, affording us wonderful views of the tips of the pine trees. There was no snow to be seen for miles. Higher and higher the gondola took us, until we could see the top of the mountain. It looked like a slaughtered Friesian cow, baring brown and white patches to the sky. The brown was rock, the white snow. All 10 centimetres of it. If that.

There were three or four basic runs, which would have been OK, had we been the only people on the mountain. But the entire resort was zooming along the same tracks. Pretty soon, snow turned to slush and slush to brown rock.

You dared not move off other people's tramlines in the slush in case you hit brown rock. The sun punched you in the face like a bully.

Arsenic gathered us together for a warming drink of chocolate and brandy - a Bulgarian speciality. Well, actually, I had had it in both France and Andorra. It tasted both more alcoholic and more chocolate-ty in France and Andorra, but we politely went "mmmm".

Arsenic hadn't got us together for a morale-booster. It was so that he could do his patter. "You come to my village. All the food you can eat. Only £10."

His offer sounded incredibly cheap. But then so did he. I went for a swim in the pool in the main hotel. The water was chilly, the attendants glum.

The rep with clinical depression went through the exciting things we could do in Borovets. He spent rather too long talking about accidents and medical emergencies. People started dropping off.

That evening the almost empty resort echoed to the despairing cries of the restaurateurs. "Twenty per cent off - come in, happy hour..." Cheap neon lights hung in the night sky, lone and palely loitering.

The sadness was unbearable. At a roadside stall I bought a banana and chocolate pancake for two lev - about 60 pence. While the girls were making the pancake, a Bulgarian car slumped to a full stop and noxious plastic fumes started boiling out from under the bonnet. Bon appetit.

The beer was cheap.

Had there been snow, Borovets could have been a laugh. Without it, it seemed more a suicide risk than a holiday resort. I left the next morning at 7am, to watch the war in Macedonia.

I caught the same flight back as the others on the ski ing trip. There was a small fight in the check-in desk queue when someone knocked over someone else's skis.

The others said the snow had got worse and on the final day the whole resort had been closed. Some of them had had a laugh, despite everything. One holiday-maker in particular had enjoyed himself so much that he had thrown his television set out of the window because he didn't want to go home. He had gone on an all-night bender and his girlfriend had asked everyone else: "Have you seen him?" So some people did have fun.

The plane was late taking off, because the agent had underestimated the amount of passengers by 100. To solve the problem of not giving some 100 passengers meals, no adults got meals. The flight was hit by terrible air turbulence. On the way into Gatwick one passenger had an epileptic fit.

Paramedics were called, but they hadn't arrived before I got off the plane.

Other than the above, I would heartily recommend a skiing holiday in Bulgaria.
