webTitle: Lords of the Manor, Upper Slaughter

fields.headline: Lords of the Manor, Upper Slaughter
fields.trailText: Address: Upper Slaughter, Gloucestershire GL54 2JD.
fields.body:
Address: Upper Slaughter, Gloucestershire GL54 2JD.

Tel: 01451 820243.

Web address: www.lordsofthemanor.com

First impressions The model country manor. Warmth and cosiness exude from the honey-coloured stone walls and a sense of well-being is assured from the moment you check in. Oh, and there's a satisfying crunch of gravel as you pull into the drive.

What are the rooms like? Each of the 27 rooms has been decked out with antiques. Ours, in the original part of the 17th-century former rectory, had a welcoming bottle of sherry on the dresser and a table in the oriel window at which to sip.

The bed test Four-poster looks inviting and sleeps like a dream.

The bathroom test Functional but with the luxury of Molton Brown goodies.

The restaurant One Michelin star, 4AA rosettes, RAC Gold Ribbon, 2001 Good Food Guide Restaurant of the Year, England (joint)... the accolades are as extensive as chef John Campbell's menu - almost. The Tasting Menu combines eight courses from the à la carte - delights such as slow-cooked sirloin with onion ice- cream (it works, believe us) - with a different glass of wine to compliment each. Starts with a glass of Dom Perignon 1993 and ends with a £79-a-head bill. But it's worth every penny.

The lounge Convivial and comfortable - sink into one of the leather armchairs around the fire and enjoy a snifter.

What is there to see within walking distance? Manicured grounds, picture-book village of Upper Slaughter.

webTitle: Miami advice

fields.headline: Miami advice
fields.standfirst: It took the 80s cop series to put the cool back into South Beach. Now it's America's hottest night spot.  Pascal Wyse checks out the scene
fields.trailText: It took the 80s cop series to put the cool back into South Beach. Now it's America's hottest night spot. Pascal Wyse checks out the scene
fields.body:
On the ceiling in one of the rooms of the Rubel family collection of contemporary art in Miami there is a police marksman's target sheet textured with a consistent pattern that never leaves the upper body. It even carries a signature, like the works of art. "Oh, we just decided not to take that down," says the curator, explaining that the building used to be the police department's warehouse for seized drugs, and that this room was where they put all the cocaine.

The signature on that target must surely have been Crockett and Tubbs - the cops in the hit 80s TV series Miami Vice, who kept the pimps, drugs and the mob at bay, while casually committing their own crimes of fashion. They don't quite have the artworld kudos of Gilbert and George but there should be a monument to them on the beach - pastel T-shirts, shades, espadrilles, fancy suits with sleeves rolled up and a glimpse of gun holster, because, ironically, their depiction of the sleazy glamour of Miami proved - at least to the satisfaction of the tourist industry - that crime pays.

"Oh yeah, Miami Vice really put South Beach back on the map - it started the whole regeneration," says a local café owner, all tan, white teeth and eyeballs in the ultraviolet glow of the Mangoes club. The vice here is the fact that the staff - men and women - take it in turns to dance on the bar to an all-night cycle of Latin pop that pays homage, at least every half an hour, to Ricky Martin. "Fifteen years ago it used to just be pensioners and criminals here. You'd take a cab just to go two blocks it was so unsafe."

This town once had the highest murder rate in the US, and a majestic coke habit. It is hard to picture that now on South Beach, with its restored glory of Art Deco buildings - a string of cake-coloured blocks piped with neon and soothingly curved edges that basks in the more natural shades of the sand, palm trees and sunset. This is the heart of a trip to Miami: its sassy and often sleazy altar to the sun.

Don Johnson doesn't need to police this adult Disneyland any more, but the beach life has retained its colourful characters: "You wanna stroke my snake?" asks a man as his pet slowly curls in the furnace of the early afternoon; thongs thin enough to floss your teeth with rollerblade by; Ferraris kerb crawl, while strains of dance, hip-hop and Latin music fight for attention, and stretch vehicles snarl the traffic in "limo-lock". And, as the afternoon's 15-minute tropical downpour begins, the khaki-shorted staff of The Tides Hotel arm themselves with umbrellas for the guests scuttling back in.

Confident in its ability to distinguish itself in such rich surroundings, The Tides (one of six "Island Outpost" hotels on South Beach owned by Chris Blackwell of Island Records) describes itself casually as "across the street from the Atlantic Ocean". Designed in 1936 by L Murray Dixon, its original 115-room layout has been knocked through to provide 45 more spacious suites, all of which have a view of the beach (and telescopes to magnify it). Compared with the more obviously designer cool of (ex Studio 54 partner) Ian Schrager's Delano, or Blackwell's own more funky Marlin (interior designed by Barbara Hulanicki, and home to the 72-track South Beach Studios), The Tides's strict decor of steel, khaki, cream, marble, nautical portholes and frosted glass is, in South Beach terms, understatedly luxurious.

There is nothing that hasn't been given The Tides stamp. Somebody, somewhere, even has the job of etching the "T" logo into the sand of every ashtray in the building. You can only marvel at this holistic service and wonder, as you request a cappuccino and different music in the swimming pool, what frantic activity is going on behind the scenes. The heart of South Beach is used to dealing with the glamorous and the peculiar - and part of the Miami experience is pushing the boat out and feeling famous for a day.

Lines count for a lot in Miami: the lines between vice and virtue, the VIPs and the ordinary folk, between Latin America and the US, taste and vulgarity. The celebrity second-homers like to draw the line at exclusivity and privacy, obsessions readily catered for by the islands that satellite the tip of Miami Beach (Fisher Island and Star Island are home to the likes of Gloria Estefan, Oprah and Boris Becker).

Outside the nightclubs of South Beach, the lines continue to be drawn, but by red velvet ropes and bouncers; at Level or Crobar, people groom themselves and flutter fragrantly around the entrances, waiting to be picked out and ushered in -although in reality the queue is just ticking down like any other. Inside, VIP areas are placed like the top layer of a wedding cake, so the privileged few can observe the bouncing mass below. Fickle, fun and absolutely to be taken at face value, these are the super clubs - the glamour factories that, since the infamous Liquid opened in 1996, have put Miami on the dance music scene. Every March, they play host to the Winter Music Festival, making America's own little Ibiza for a month.

In typical American fashion, you generally get a bit extra, wherever you go. There's the laundrette that also has a bar (a favourite lesbian hangout); there's Bed, the restaurant that serves you a gourmet dinner in bed before throwing back the covers to turn into a nightclub; or Tantra, a restaurant and club with grass on the floor, water trickling down the walls and a menu of entirely aphrodisiac food. Power Studios, with its nine different rooms and stages covering everything from rooftop cinema, house music, jazz, salsa, dance and food - goes for a full immersion in the arts, and is a fine place to watch Miami's Latin and American flavours (and people) fuse.

Developer Craig Robins, who had been part of South Beach's return to form is doing similar things with the Design District, which is being labelled a South Beach for shoppers, and top designers, artists and restaurateurs - as well as nightlife generators such as Power Studios - are moving back into what was a thriving area in the 1970s.

There are locals, however, who feel that Miami has lost it - that the bubble has burst and left a hollow playground. Perhaps at the peak of its latest rejuvenation (and few places have been knocked out and got back on their feet as many times as this one), it was more of a glamourous well-kept secret with an edge, forced to drop its velvet ropes by the march of tourism. But these are subtle distinctions that needn't bother the traveller. Few places offer such a perfect hot climate of hedonism, such an intriguing split personality: an American engine powered by Latin batteries.

Brunch... at the 11th St Diner, 1065 Washington Ave, between 10th & 11th St (534 6373). An original 40s diner from Pennsylvania - cut up, shipped,and welded back together in Miami.

Take cocktails... at the Delano, 1685 Collins Avenue. Plenty of fame-spotting opportunities.

Have dinner... in Bed, literally. At 929 Washington Avenue. Asian Spiced Crusted Vellotail Snapper served on a family-sized mattress? It works, bizarrely.

Dance... at Crobar, 1445 Washington Ave. Currently banging to the Winter Music Festival with a speaker system the military would be envious of.

Come down... at Tantra, 1445 Pennsylvania Avenue. Soothing trance, bellydancers, grass on the floor and walls of waterfalls.

Sleep... at The Tides Hotel, 1220 Ocean Drive (see details opposite). Like a luxury cruiser that never sets sail.

Way to go

Flights to Miami cost from £296pp inc taxes on American Airlines (0845 6010619) valid from April 16 - 30. A room at The Tides Hotel starts from £305 a night valid until May 31 (Island Outpost Hotel Group reservations: 020-7440 4360). A seven-night package including accommodation at The Tides Hotel, return flights and car hire, based on two people sharing a room costs £1,439pp. For reservations, contact Peregor Travel on 0845 3450003. Miami tourist information: www.tropicoolmiami.com

webTitle: Greek Island Hopping 2001, Thomas Cook Publishing, £12.99

fields.headline: Greek Island Hopping 2001, Thomas Cook Publishing, £12.99
fields.trailText: This is an essential for island hoppers. Updated yearly, the guide enables travellers to keep up with the fast-changing islands and the ferry routes that serve them
fields.body:
This is an essential for island hoppers. Updated yearly and supported by an excellent website, the guide enables travellers to keep up with the fast-changing islands and the ferry routes that serve them.

Emphasis is placed on travel. The islands are grouped according to ferry routes they are on, making holiday planning easier. Port tables help hoppers to create realistic itineraries. Ferry timetables are rarely finalised more than a month in advance so the website carries updated travel information. There is an at-a-glance rating guide comparing the islands in categories such as beaches and nightlife.

The website is being expanded with E-guides to Corfu and the Ionian islands under construction, a links page is also planned. Online island updates keep travellers posted about changes in overland transport and places mentioned in the guide. This should end the frustration of locating your guidebook hotel only to find it has vanished or upped its prices.

The advice on ferry travel is unromantic - the majority remain safe modes of transport. The principle risk for most travellers comes from poor disembarkation technique and inadequate safety guards rather than sinking. The guide and the website carry safety information on vessels allowing travellers to avoid the worst rust buckets. Road transport remains the most treacherous part of a hopping holiday with more than 100 tourist moped fatalities last year.

Island sections provide information on local accommodation and facilities with maps showing their location. The beaches are described so you can find the perfect one. Although nudism is officially illegal in Greece, there are nudist beaches on most islands. Bus routes help hoppers to get to the sites and beaches. They also explain the popularity of the treacherous moped, on many islands you need private transport to get around.

The book includes sections on museums and archaeological sites that will satisfy most visitors' curiosity. For hikers, it recommends good walking guides available in Greece. The language guide is very short. It lacks a section on illness so sick hoppers will need to find an English-speaking doctor or a phrase book to get treatment.

This is an unashamedly practical book. It is well laid out and easy to use. There are few photographs and the illustrations look dated but this is a small price to pay for such a valuable travel tool.

webTitle: Walk this way

fields.headline: Walk this way
fields.standfirst: Cumbria, one of England's most picturesque counties, is also one of the hardest hit by foot and mouth. But it is still possible to enjoy a holiday there. David Ward reports
fields.trailText: Cumbria, one of England's most picturesque counties, is also one of the hardest hit by foot and mouth. But it is still possible to enjoy a holiday there. David Ward reports
fields.body:
On this day 199 years ago, Dorothy Wordsworth walked to Portinscale, west of Keswick, and "lay upon the turf and saw into the Vale of Newlands". She tells in her journals how she looked up to Borrowdale and down to Keswick and described what she saw as a "soft venetian view". Last weekend we saw what she saw but were still puzzling over how she could compare a lonely Lake District valley with Venice when, having walked south from the hamlet of Braithwaite, we met the black plastic bucket.

We had sniffed disinfectant in the crisp morning air and then came across a soggy, cleansing mat on the road; next to it sat the bucket. Two shivering volunteer national park wardens asked us to dip our boots. As we did, we glanced across to the adjacent field where a contented ewe was nuzzling her new-born triplets. We tried not to think how much longer she and her lambs would have in this world and strode off on a tarmac walk, which is just about the only walk you can do in the Lake District at present. (But don't try walking over the Hardknott and Wrynose passes: they are closed.)

If you have to walk on roads, the lane that ambles down to Stoneycroft and Rigg Beck and back through Little Town and Swinside makes a satisfying six-mile circuit if you can hide your eyes from the keep out signs on every stile and from the tracks that lead invitingly up to Causey Pike and the wild hinterland of the fells.

On the way out there was Catbells to the east and just a glimpse of Derwent Water; ahead lay High Crags and beyond that, Great Gable. A cautious sun in a big sky made the prospect more Turner than Venice. We turned east by a purple house that looked like a reject from Psycho and eventually headed north, gazing towards Skiddaw and Blencathra while wondering what to do about the errant Herdwick sheep that trotted resolutely along the road in front of us.

So the Lake District is open and anyone involved in the tourism business should be able to offer the kind of warm welcome we received at the Lairbeck Hotel in Keswick, which we had plucked more or less at random from a website: a large, comfortable double room for £31.50, as many mint imperials as you can swallow and the chance of a game of Scrabble with the owners in a bar warmed by a roaring fire.

We had made our way to Keswick from Windermere, dropping off first at the Steamboat Museum, a superb collection of varnished teak launches from the age of elegance, a century ago, when owners of grand lakeside homes vied with each other to show off the quality of their craft to ladies with parasols. We were torn between Branksome (the apotheosis of Victorian style) and Otto (built for speed), but neither was plying the lake (trips should start at Easter), so we took to the water on a cruise boat from Waterhead near Ambleside.

Miss Cumbria II, did not, like the boat the young Wordsworth rowed, go "heaving through the water like a swan", but it returned us to Ambleside in time for a visit to Dove Cottage, up the road in Grasmere, the poet's home with Dorothy (and sundry other friends and relations, including Coleridge and De Quincey, both high as kites on laudanum) from 1799 to 1808.

Foot and mouth has closed the garden that William and Dorothy made (and into which Walter Scott once did a bunk through an open window), but the cottage still exercises its strange, intense charm, especially when a fire blazes in the kitchen hearth and a vase of daffodils rests on a table by the window. There were just half a dozen people on our tour of the nine rooms, but that left both scope for romantic daydreams about the nature of genius and time to admire some of the cottage's magnificent floorboards. The ceiling in Dorothy's bedroom leaked, by the way.

The nearby museum, with bare walls of local stone, was pretty empty, too, but that meant there were no queues for the headphones to hear readings of Upon Westminster Bridge and Tintern Abbey. It was enough to turn the sensitive visitor into what Wordsworth would have called a living soul. And there was a cheap, groupy kind of thrill in seeing the skates on which the poet could have glided across Esthwaite Lake in a famous passage in The Prelude.

We met Wordsworth again at Rheged, near Penrith, one of Cumbria's newest tourist attractions where the county's "history, mystery and magic" are celebrated in Europe's largest earth-covered building. There are shops (everything Cumbrian), crafts, cafés and play areas for children. But at Rheged's heart is a cinema with a huge screen on which is shown a film (narrated by Sir Derek Jacobi, no less) that dabbles in Celtic and Arthurian whimsy while telling the tale of an American lad who heads east to find his Cumbrian roots.

Wordsworth and Dorothy make a slightly embarrassed arm-in-arm appearance because the lad turns out to be a descendant of the errant son of Michael, the hero of Wordsworth's long poem about a peasant shepherd and his incomplete pen for sheep (which may have had foot and mouth but it didn't seem to matter much in those days).

Our diversion was a pint of Jennings bitter, excellent sausage and mash and a pile of fresh veg at the George in Keswick followed by Twelfth Night at the Theatre By The Lake, the town's loveable and successful theatre on the shores of Derwent Water. The production was more Ibiza than Ilyria, with much of the action taking place in Olivia's bar. There were no references to sheep (thank God they were not doing A Winter's Tale) and not a lot of depth-plumbing. But a full house enjoyed every minute, glad for a moment to forget a crisis that had prompted an angry farmer to erect on the outskirts of the town a sign reading, in blood-red paint, "Drop dead Blair."

The volunteer warden who had watched us dip our boots in the bucket near Braithwaite had commented gloomily: "It [foot and mouth] is in the Duddon Valley now." Wordsworth loved the Duddon Valley and celebrated it in 34 sonnets:

Still glides the stream, and shall for ever glide;

The Form remains, the Function never dies;

While we, the brave, the mighty, and the wise,

We Men, who in our morn of youth defied

The elements, must vanish.

By the time you read this, a Duddon flock of Herdwicks, the sheep Beatrix Potter loved, will have been slaughtered amid fears for the future ecology of the Lake District. And in one of Rheged's shops you can buy Backpacks and Blisters "the Lakeland walking game for the armchair rambler", which could prove a useful diversion until current restrictions are lifted.

* Lairbeck Hotel, Vicarage Hill, Keswick (017687 73373), B&B £31.50 (£38.50 high season). Special deals for three-, four- and seven-night packages.

* Windermere Steamboat Museum, Windermere, 10am to 5pm daily, tel: 015394 45565.

* Windermere Lake Cruises, departures from Lakeside, Bowness and Ambleside, tel: 015394 43360.

* Dove Cottage, 9.30am to 5.30pm daily, tel: 015394 35544.

* Theatre By The Lake, Lakeside, Keswick, tel: 017687 74411.

* Rheged, Redhills, Penrith, 10am to 6pm daily, tel: 01768 868000.

Check points

* The Lake District National Park has an information pack listing local attractions, lane-based walks and activities that can still be enjoyed in the area. It can be obtained by sending an SAE to the Lake District Visitor Centre, Brockhole, Windermere, Cumbria LA23 1LJ.

* Republic of Ireland: www.irelandtravel.co.uk

So the Lake District is open and anyone involved in the tourism business should be able to offer the kind of warm welcome we received at the Lairbeck Hotel in Keswick, which we had plucked more or less at random from a website: a large, comfortable double room for £31.50, as many mint imperials as you can swallow and the chance of a game of Scrabble with the owners in a bar warmed by a roaring fire. We had made our way to Keswick from Windermere, dropping off first at the Steamboat Museum, a superb collection of varnished teak launches from the age of elegance, a century ago, when owners of grand lakeside homes vied with each other to show off the quality of their craft to ladies with parasols. We were torn between Branksome (the apotheosis of Victorian style) and Otto (built for speed), but neither was plying the lake (trips should start at Easter), so we took to the water on a cruise boat from Waterhead near Ambleside. Miss Cumbria II, did not, like the boat the young Wordsworth rowed, go "heaving through the water like a swan", but it returned us to Ambleside in time for a visit to Dove Cottage, up the road in Grasmere, the poet's home with Dorothy (and sundry other friends and relations, including Coleridge and De Quincey, both high as kites on laudanum) from 1799 to 1808. Foot and mouth has closed the garden that William and Dorothy made (and into which Walter Scott once did a bunk through an open window), but the cottage still exercises its strange, intense charm, especially when a fire blazes in the kitchen hearth and a vase of daffodils rests on a table by the window. There were just half a dozen people on our tour of the nine rooms, but that left both scope for romantic daydreams about the nature of genius and time to admire some of the cottage's magnificent floorboards. The ceiling in Dorothy's bedroom leaked, by the way. The nearby museum, with bare walls of local stone, was pretty empty, too, but that meant there were no queues for the headphones to hear readings of Upon Westminster Bridge and Tintern Abbey. It was enough to turn the sensitive visitor into what Wordsworth would have called a living soul. And there was a cheap, groupy kind of thrill in seeing the skates on which the poet could have glided across Esthwaite Lake in a famous passage in The Prelude. We met Wordsworth again at Rheged, near Penrith, one of Cumbria's newest tourist attractions where the county's "history, mystery and magic" are celebrated in Europe's largest earth-covered building. There are shops (everything Cumbrian), crafts, cafés and play areas for children. But at Rheged's heart is a cinema with a huge screen on which is shown a film (narrated by Sir Derek Jacobi, no less) that dabbles in Celtic and Arthurian whimsy while telling the tale of an American lad who heads east to find his Cumbrian roots. Wordsworth and Dorothy make a slightly embarrassed arm-in-arm appearance because the lad turns out to be a descendant of the errant son of Michael, the hero of Wordsworth's long poem about a peasant shepherd and his incomplete pen for sheep (which may have had foot and mouth but it didn't seem to matter much in those days). Our diversion was a pint of Jennings bitter, excellent sausage and mash and a pile of fresh veg at the George in Keswick followed by Twelfth Night at the Theatre By The Lake, the town's loveable and successful theatre on the shores of Derwent Water. The production was more Ibiza than Ilyria, with much of the action taking place in Olivia's bar. There were no references to sheep (thank God they were not doing A Winter's Tale) and not a lot of depth-plumbing. But a full house enjoyed every minute, glad for a moment to forget a crisis that had prompted an angry farmer to erect on the outskirts of the town a sign reading, in blood-red paint, "Drop dead Blair." The volunteer warden who had watched us dip our boots in the bucket near Braithwaite had commented gloomily: "It [foot and mouth] is in the Duddon Valley now." Wordsworth loved the Duddon Valley and celebrated it in 34 sonnets: Still glides the stream, and shall for ever glide; The Form remains, the Function never dies; While we, the brave, the mighty, and the wise, We Men, who in our morn of youth defied The elements, must vanish. By the time you read this, a Duddon flock of Herdwicks, the sheep Beatrix Potter loved, will have been slaughtered amid fears for the future ecology of the Lake District. And in one of Rheged's shops you can buy Backpacks and Blisters "the Lakeland walking game for the armchair rambler", which could prove a useful diversion until current restrictions are lifted. * Lairbeck Hotel, Vicarage Hill, Keswick (017687 73373), B&B £31.50 (£38.50 high season). Special deals for three-, four- and seven-night packages. * Windermere Steamboat Museum, Windermere, 10am to 5pm daily, tel: 015394 45565. * Windermere Lake Cruises, departures from Lakeside, Bowness and Ambleside, tel: 015394 43360. * Dove Cottage, 9.30am to 5.30pm daily, tel: 015394 35544. * Theatre By The Lake, Lakeside, Keswick, tel: 017687 74411. * Rheged, Redhills, Penrith, 10am to 6pm daily, tel: 01768 868000. webTitle: Child benefits

fields.headline: Child benefits
fields.standfirst: Jane Cunningham finds a city that knows how to keep children entertained, fed and watered
fields.trailText: Jane Cunningham finds a city that knows how to keep children entertained, fed and watered
fields.body:
Antwerp isn't an obvious choice for a family weekend away. But for those who take the time to visit, its delights quickly become obvious. Indeed, it is quietly and confidently pro-children.

Small playgrounds are dotted at regular intervals, just in case the urge to spin around in a tea-cup becomes overwhelming. Shops are buggy friendly, with many having ramps for easy access. Virtually everywhere has a table and chairs with crayoning books laid out for unenthusiastic shoppers, and a basket of sweets to reward the patient.

Antwerp kids have the pick of the crop when it comes to fashion. Label-conscious parents are in trendy heaven, with small, minimalist boutiques dedicated entirely to stylish small people. Mind you, none of it comes cheap.

The word "enticing" sums Antwerp up in a nutshell. One of the most striking things about the profusion of shops selling flowers, interior design, chocolates, candy, shoes, clothes, cheeses and just about anything you could wish for, is the attention to detail. Cakes turn out to be exquisitely made from flowers, chocolate is fashioned into tea-pots, houses, carriages and more. Restaurants lay out small wrought-iron tables topped with simple, elegant terracotta pots bursting with bright flowers. Window dressing is considered an art form, a feast for the eyes.

But it isn't just in the stores that this innate sense of accessorising, adorning and garnishing belongs. Coffee houses automatically provide a chocolate, a piece of waffle or a tempting square of cake with every order. In restaurants, children are given a tiny dish of smarties, a lollipop - anything to appeal or amuse - as a prelude to the meal. The first restaurant we ate at provided my six-year-old son with a salad "garden", complete with a toadstool, ingeniously made from a boiled egg and half a seeded tomato. It was dotted with mayonnaise spots and the finishing flourish was cress grass and a couple of radish flowers. Ice-creams are pre sented with Smartie faces or rabbit ears made of wafer. If there is a way to make presentation pristine, the people of Antwerp find it.

Walking and cycling are the most popular forms of transport, particularly in the old town. It's easy to see why the coffee houses are always bursting at the seams with locals hungry for cakes and waffles because physical exercise is part and parcel of living in Antwerp, and calories taken in are quickly expended on a brisk walk and act as insulation from the brisk chill that comes off the river.

Assuming that walking through cobbled streets awash with an exotic mix of 16th-, 17th- and 18th-century Art Nouveau architecture won't keep the kids amused for ever, there is an assortment of entertainment which certainly will.

Not to be missed

Rubens' House, Wapper 9-11, BF100pp (£1.60)

A memory game inside the entrance of this breathtaking 17th-century house gives pictures and objects for children to spot as they progress through the rooms. Surprisingly, this provided enough motivation for my kids to be enthusiastic throughout. Don't be fooled by the name, Rubens' House; he was here but a moment. The residential palazzo, however, portrays the Rubens era, including a selection of paintings by the man himself.

Cathedral of Our Lady, Handschoenmarkt, BF70pp, (children under-12 free)

The four important paintings by Rubens are virtually lost in the myriad of colours provided by the massive stained-glass windows, flickering candles, gilded side chapels, ornate wooden carvings and memorial stones.

Taking 169 years to complete, the cathedral is huge, spectacular and impressive in equal measure.

The Pilgrim's House, Pelgramstraat 15, BF 100pp (weekends only)

A 16th-century establishment that belonged to a wealthy merchant. This tiny house was one of the first in Antwerp to have running water, and has been faithfully reproduced. A fascinating insight into life as it was, with a few surprises along the way.

The Bird Market (Vogelenmarkt), Theatreplein

Traditionally a venue for selling livestock, on Sunday mornings the square is transformed into a hotchpotch of vendors selling riotously-coloured flowers, earthy bulbs, cheeses, chocolate, clothes, furniture and bric-a-brac. There are still birds for sale - hens, geese, budgerigars, fancy pigeons and more specialist breeds. We also saw rabbits, mice and hamsters.

Chocolate Tour , Burie, Korte Gasthuisstraat 3, tel +32 3 232 36 88, www.chobel.be, BF500 pp (which includes a 250g box of chocolates)

If you haven't already succumbed to the vast array of chocolate goodies on offer, then the chocolate tour will break the most iron will. Hans Burie, specialises in making anything out of chocolate. His unusual assignments to date include a life-sized chocolate wardrobe, and a car. Burie is happy to take parties of 10 or more around his tiny factory. Don't miss the sight of three huge vats of hot, liquid chocolate churning in thick, velvety swirls. Book in advance. (Not suitable for under-5s.)

Worth a visit

The National Maritime Museum, Steenplein 1, BF100 per adult, BF50 per child

A waterfront fort and the oldest building in Antwerp, with a statue of Gulliver outside makes the Maritime Museum a fun place to visit. Vast and intricate hand-made models of ships and their contents are fascinating.

Riverwalk

The light on the water of the river Scheldt has inspired and thrilled painters throughout the ages. It's pretty enough, and a delightful walk, but none of us felt moved to put brush to paper.

The Diamond District, Vestingstraat, Lange Herentalsestraat 31-33, (free admission)

Much is made of Antwerp's diamond industry, with the city housing four exchanges. The district is worth a look, if only to slaver over the ingenious pieces of jewellery and experience the film-set feeling. Security cameras, guards, police and armoured vehicles line the streets. Visit the Diamond Museum and see diamonds being cut and polished.

Need to know

* Antwerpenars pathologically obey road signs. Never cross at a zebra unless the green man is showing.

* Don't expect to be seated in restaurants. In all but the most upmarket establishments, you are expected to find your own seat.

* Be aware that a visit to any newsagent - and some bric-a-brac shops - will expose your kids to hardcore pornography. What would be "top shelf" material in Britain, is easily accessible, and front covers are no-holds barred. I had to rugby-tackle my nine-year-old daughter just before her eyes alighted on a gob-smackingly explicit magazine.

* You can eat at any time. Unlike most family holidays abroad, you won't end up being the only people in the restaurant if you need food before 8pm. Antwerp restaurants are doing brisk business from 6pm.

* Antwerp is laid out in a complex and rambling way. Hiring a guide for a morning is a good way to get your bearings and sort out the lie of the land.

* There is a generally relaxed attitude to smoking. Few restaurants have much in the way of no-smoking areas.

* The gorgeous looking ice-cream at IJS Leon, at Melk Markt 29, is made from horse's milk. Mmmm.

Where to stay

The Tourist Information Office has many recommendations, from youth hostels (open to all) to five-star luxury hotels. We stayed ina small, centrally-located, family-run hotel with all the charm of a 1970s loveshack, but which had a duplex room ideal for families. Accommodation included a double bedroom and bathroom upstairs, with a small twin room and toilet downstairs. With continental breakfast, the price was £25pp per night. (Euro Hotel, St Jacobsmarkt 91-93).

Useful numbers

* Tourist Information Office, Grote Markt 15, tel: +232 01 03, www.dma.be

*Antwerpen Averechts, Bureau for Alternative City Walks and Tours Kronenburgstraat 34/1, tel +248 15 77

*Affiliation of Antwerp City Guides, tel: +232 01 03

Getting there

Eurostar (08705 186186) will take you to Antwerp via Brussels starting at £75pp return. There are up to 10 trains a day to Brussels and Antwerp is 30 minutes from the Belgian capital.

For scoff...

Coffee and Cakes at:

1 Weiner Kaffe Leonardo, Hoogstraat 28.

2 Desire de Lille, Schrijnwerkersstr 14.

3 Silhouet Tea Room, Hopland 7.

Lunch at:

1 De Foyer, Komedieplaats 18.

2 Het Dagelijks Brood, Steenouvers 48 (one long table, seat yourself).

3 Taverne de Markt, Graanmarkt 6.

Dinner at:

1 Horta, Hopland 2 (features kids' menu). www.grandcafehorta.be

2 San Remo, de Keyserlei 33-35 (pizza).

3. Het Vermoeide Model, Lijnwaadmarkt 2.

webTitle: Ski tips

fields.headline: Ski tips
fields.trailText: * Snatching a ski holiday in late April or early May is always a bit of a gamble and this spring is no exception. Even where the snow is sufficiently deep, warm weather can make for slushy conditions. With heavy spring storms far from unknown, however, it can be a gamble worth taking. Leaving aside summer skiing on glaciers, many resorts close immediately the Easter rush is over. Among those where the lifts keep going longer are Val d'Isère , Tignes and Val Thorens , which stay open until May 8, while Flaine still closes on May 1, "subject to conditions" and Courchevel shuts on the evening of April 29. In California, Mammoth has a tradition of staying open very late. On the east coast, which has enjoyed heavy recent snow, Maine's Sunday River will close on the evening of May 1 - with free skiing on the last two days of the season. But don't leave home for any of these resorts without first making sure that "open" mean more than a handful of runs.

* Erna Low (020-7584 4921) has very late self-catering holidays left for customers prepared to drive to the Alps. A studio for four in Val Thorens , for a trip starting on April 28, costs a total of £450 including ferry crossings. A similar holiday in Tignes costs £339. Studios for two cost £225 or £291 respectively - again including Channel crossings.

* Le Ski (0870 7544444) has lopped £100 off the price of some holidays next month in Courchevel and Val d'Isère . One week in a chalet with en suite facilities now costs £399. Flights are from Gatwick on April 14/21 and from Manchester on April 21.

* Skiworld (020-7602 4826 for European destinations, 020- 7602 7444 for North America) says it has plenty of chalet space left during April. For example, if you can get away quickly, it can offer 10 nights in Whistler , with flights from Gatwick on April 4, for £619. A week in the same property, with a departure three days later, costs £669. The firm also has holidays available in France, Switzerland, Austria and the US, with flights on April 7, 8, 11 and 14. Prices range from £265 for one week in Les Arcs to £855 for 10 nights in Aspen . These prices are based on two sharing rooms.

* Ski Beat (01243 780405) also has post Easter chalet holidays left in Val d'Isère and its linked neighbour, Tignes . The price for one week, starting on April 21, is £399 if you fly from Gatwick or £279 if you travel independently. All chalets in Val d'Isère and most of those in Tignes have en suite facilities.

webTitle: Big air days

fields.headline: Big air days
fields.standfirst: Martin Bell  concludes this season's ski clinic with some lessons on how to jump
fields.trailText: Martin Bell concludes this season's ski clinic with some lessons on how to jump
fields.body:
Many who enjoy skiing say that its attraction is the sensation of flying that can be achieved by making long, swooping turns. But skiing can bring you even closer to the birds, for those who dare to jump.

Some professional skiers are actually jumping specialists. Nordic ski-jumpers need to have plenty of spring in their legs to generate distance, but they must also be of tiny physique, so as to be able to float down on the wind like a leaf. Aerialists can spin and somersault in the air- and if they belong to the "New School", they need to be able to take off and land backwards, or "switch". But many of these kings of the air are actually unable to perform an expert-level turn on the ground.

Other athletes must combine terrestrial skiing skills with mastery in the air. Downhillers intermix 90mph turns with huge 50-yard flights, where the wind resistance alone threatens to flip them on to their backs. Freeskiers are able to intersperse jump turns on 50-degree steeps, with enormous drops off cliffs, occasionally with a somersault thrown in for style.

But for average holiday skiers, the scope for jumping is more limited. They are unlikely ever to gain access to a nordic ski jump or an FIS downhill course, so their only opportunities to grab some air will be in the terrain park, or off-piste.

Park jumps

Most jumps, or "hits" in terrain parks are "table-tops", where a short flat section, followed in turn by a steeper-landing zone follows an upwards-facing "kicker". Once you jump, you'll soon learn that flat landings, with their high impact forces, are less pleasant than steep landings. So on tabletops, you need to fly far enough to clear the flat. If you're having difficulty doing this, you either need to carry more speed into the jump, or perform a stronger "pop" at the moment of take-off.

"Popping" the jump means extending your legs forcefully for greater height. (The opposite of popping is "absorbing", where you bend your legs just at the moment of take-off; this is used by downhillers, who want to reduce their flight distance, it's also known as "squashing" or "pressing".)

When you pop a tabletop, it's also important that you move your weight forwards, because you are going from an uphill gradient on the kicker, to a downhill gradient on the landing zone. If you don't move forward to align your body at right angles to the landing slope, you'll be leaning too far back, in relation to the slope, when you touch down.

If you want to try some tricks, you must build up gradually. Spend a morning in the terrain park, learning the various hits and getting a feel for the necessary speed to clear the tabletops. Watch other skiers and riders: where they start their in-run, and where they land. Pick a hit you feel comfortable with. Concentrate on making a clean take-off to give yourself plenty of height, and only think about starting the trick once you're in the air. There's plenty to choose from, Old School such as "spreadeagles", "daffys"or "backscratchers", or New School such as "mute" or "japan". The key to maintaining mid-air balance is to balance every movement of the legs with an opposite movement of the upper body.

Half-pipe

No longer is it purely the preserve of snowboarders. In fact, there are just as many skiers having fun in the halfpipe nowadays. Again, start gradually, just going halfway up the "wall", and hopping your skis around. Try to go higher and higher. Once you're ready to jump out of the pipe, be aware that the timing of the pop is everything. Pop too early, and you'll land back inside the pipe, on the flat. Pop too late, and you may fly out of the pipe entirely. But once you time it right, you'll fly vertically upwards, spin through 180 degrees, and touch back down smoothly, just inside the lip. Once you're getting enough height and "hang time", you can try some sim ple tricks like a mute or indy grab. Or, you can attempt the "alley oop", where you spin through 180 degrees in the "wrong" direction, ie opposite to your direction travel down the pipe.

Off-piste jumping

There are two types of jumps performed by serious off-piste freeskiers: cliff jumps and cornice jumps. The profile of both is similar: a vertical downward drop, as opposed to the upward kick of a terrain park jump. Checking out the landing area in advance is absolutely crucial. It must be steep enough and soft enough. If there has been a recent snowfall, check with locals whether there may be any hidden rocks or stumps, lurking just beneath the surface. If possible, watch other skiers or snowboarders to see how deep they sink in when they land. (But remember that snowboarders will sink in less than you will, if you are on skis. And old-fashioned "straight skis" will sink in more than fat skis.) Try to learn from watching others how much speed you'll need to clear the lower part of the cliff. Make sure a friend spots the landing for you, to check no one else is standing below.

When standing above a cornice, don't get too close to the edge until you're actually ready to launch, because the snow could break away under your weight. And when you ski off the cliff or cornice, pick your feet up just before the lip to avoid snagging your skis on a piece of rock or having the cornice break away unexpectedly. You'll need to move your weight forward slightly to align yourself with the steep landing, but not too far forward or you may go "over the handlebars". Start modestly, with little 3ft drop-offs, and gradually build up to the bigger drops, when the snow conditions are soft enough.

webTitle: Snow show

fields.headline: Snow show
fields.trailText: Austria
fields.body:
Austria

Following some fresh snow at altitude in Obergurgl (* * *) and St Anton (* * *), conditions are very good on the upper slopes and there is some excellent off piste powder in among the trees. However, the lower slopes are slushy. In Kitzbuhel (* *), the pistes are wet and heavy going. Head to the high altitude, glacial resorts such as Kaprun (* * *), Hintertux (* * *) or Solden (* * *).

France

In Alpe d'Huez (* * *) and Argentiere (* * *)there are hard, icy conditions in the mornings. However, the pistes quickly soften in the sun and by the end of the day the lower slopes are heavy going. The best conditions can still be found in Serre Chevalier (* * * *) and Montgenevre (* * * *).

Switzerland

Fresh snow has refreshed the upper slopes in St Moritz (* * *) and Davos (* * *). In Verbier (* * * *) Mont Fort has finally reopened giving access to some fantastic powder. Some resorts are now really struggling with lower snow cover such as Crans Montana (* * ), Klosters (* * *) and Murren (* * *).

Italy

The best conditions in Europe can still be found in Italy - in Cervinia (* * * *) and Cortina (* * *).

Andorra

In Soldeu (* * ) the pistes are hard in the morning but soften by mid-morning.

US

In Aspen (* * *) and Breckenridge (* * *) the snow cover is still very good throughout the area but the best skiing can be found first thing in the morning. In Killington (* * * *) the snow just keeps on falling and over the past week another 45 inches of snow has fallen.

Canada

Fresh snow for the Banff Ski Area (* * *) has dramatically improved conditions. Whistler (* * *) has also received some fresh snow, which has refreshed the major slopes but the lower slopes are slushy in places. In Fernie (* *) conditions are soft and wet particularly at resort level.

No snowflakes = a serious lack of snow - no lifts open. * = poor snow conditions, very few lifts open. * * = conditions reasonable, ome slopes in poor condition. * * * = plenty of good skiing. * * * * = good conditions. * * * * * = fantastic on and off piste.

webTitle: Travel tips

fields.headline: Travel tips
fields.trailText: Travel tips
fields.body:
Travel tips

* If travelling in Russia as a tourist, one will automatically be charged a higher entrance rate for places such as St Basil's. One tip is to look to the people standing outside the site, often locals are "renting" out their identity card/books. which allow access at a greatly reduced rate. By this means, we, at the age of 23, gained access to Red Square, as Muscovite pensioners. It is an accepted practice, which means that the tourist is not being overcharged, the tourist industry is still making money and the pensioner gains.

Yasmin-Stefanov-King

* To reduce the swelling of bites and stop that horrible itchiness, try a bottle of Chinese medicine called White Flower Lion. It only costs around £3 and a touch of this tiny miracle liquid instantly reduces redness and the swelling goes down after a day.

Derek Humphries

* Wherever you go, take spare socks. Wet, cold or blistering feet can ruin any holiday - and they don't take up much space.

Georgina High

* When travelling, it's a good idea to take a pair of laces for trainers/shoes, as you do not want to waste valuable time looking for a cobblers.

webTitle: South Sea bubble

fields.headline: South Sea bubble
fields.standfirst: When we think of paradise, places such as Tahiti and Bora Bora spring to mind.  David Teather travels thousands of miles to see if they live up to expectations
fields.trailText: When we think of paradise, places such as Tahiti and Bora Bora spring to mind. David Teather travels thousands of miles to see if they live up to expectations
fields.body:
Drifting slowly around Bora Bora at dusk in a 36ft catamaran, something caught my eye. On the edge of the island there was a simple weatherboard church, painted in sky blue and white with a small steeple. The building was completely isolated apart from a few people sitting nearby, their feet dangling langourously over a rickety, wooden jetty.

The church was dwarfed by the mountain which climbed steeply behind it, seeming to ridicule the man-made attempt to pay homage to God. The church had also seen better days but had gained dignity with age.

By now the water was a dark, deep blue and had lost the translucence and ribbons of different shades that rippled in the sea by day. But if you couldn't see them, you could still hear the fish splashing and you could see small white eruptions of spume as they flicked their tails and pierced the surface.

The island itself had also turned dark green. Like the others in the Society Islands of French Polynesia, Bora Bora is densely covered with palm trees which climb up the peaks that shape their dramatic skylines - a kind of leafy Manhattan. The peaks themselves were lost amid dark clouds that seemed to huddle over the islands for fear of getting lost in the vast expanse of ocean and blue sky that surrounds them in every direction.

The sun was going down behind the island and throwing sparks of light through the gaps between cloud and mountain peak. The hum of the boat was the only sound to keep me company and the only other visible sign of life was the odd whisp of smoke escaping from between the treetops where I imagined people were lighting fires for the night.

The silence was then broken as the crew of the boat began singing with a collection of makeshift instruments including the spoons, an empty can of the local brew filled with stones and an ageing ukulele. The church got smaller and finally disappeared as we turned the corner to follow the shore of the island. I ordered a gin and tonic and sunk into the evening. Perfect.

For most people, the Tahiti they travel half the world to see is the stuff of textbook paradise. And that Tahiti exists. Long lines of tiny cartoon-style islands (known locally as motus ) fit for a castaway - the kind of scene that makes you blink in disbelief. A cluster of palm trees surrounded by white sand and in turn surrounded by water that looks like blue cut glass. Arriving from London, it was like emerging from black and white into splendid technicolour. Honeymooners laze about in the classic low-rise luxury hotels spreading into the sea on stilts like an exoskeleton from the islands.

But it was a different Tahiti that I wanted to see. One that was at once exotic in the old-fashioned kind of way and chic from the long influence of the French: light but also excitingly dark and gothic. I'd grown up with a couple of places in mind that fitted the bill coming from no more highbrow a source than Bob Hope, Bing Crosby and Dorothy Lamour. The experience of drifting past Bora Bora at dusk felt as though I was in an old movie circling unexplored lands.

I'd arrived, as all visitors to the Society Islands do, on Tahiti, the main island of the region which supports most of the otherwise sparse population. Staying at the Sheraton, not far from the airport, the exotic required a little work on my part. Not least when lying next to the pool. To the left was the view of neighbouring volcanic island Moorea, to the right, the industrial port of Tahiti's capital, Papeete.

But even on Tahiti it was relatively easy to escape by moving off the main road circling the island and heading inland. Tahitians have a taste for the beach life and cling on to the edges of the islands leaving the interiors virtually unspoilt. My guide for a trek through the jungle was a Frenchman bearing a striking resemblance to Gerard Depardieu, who swung his machete with rather too much abandon, encouraged me to wade through rivers fully clothed and eat avocados recently dropped to the ground.

It was only once I had left Tahiti that I became seduced by the islands. The cruise was a five day sojourn around the main Society Islands including Bora Bora, Tahaa and Huahine. We were following an annual race, the Hawaiki Nui Va'a - a gruelling three day boat race between the islands in which 90 outrigger canoe teams take part.

For the islanders it is the biggest social occasion of the year. A large flotilla follows the race, from small, brightly-coloured speed boats peeling with paint and overflowing with families to large luxury yachts, including the president's. As the race progresses, the drinks come out and men and women alike start to strip off and position themselves to catch the sun while taking the occasional glimpse at who's winning. The race also underlined the sheer drama of the place - boats cross in the paths of the competing canoes in what seems like aquatic games of chicken while officials dart about on jet skis, and helicopters hover overhead with camera crews. And all the time in the background are those looming, mountainous islands.

The race is designed to underline the links between the islands, but for me only emphasised their isolation from the rest of the world. French Polynesia is more than 3,300 miles from Sydney to the west, 3,500 miles to Los Angeles in the north and 4,000 miles to Santiago in the east - a fact that lends the islands an intensity at odds with the laid-back nature of the people.

The seduction wasn't only visual. The reliance on local produce means you literally taste the place - and it is a good taste. The staple diet is fish and vegetables, some familiar, others, like the bread fruit or black root vegetable taro, less so. Thankfully, the French influence is evident in the food preparation but not the portions. When someone talks about "Tahitian portions" they mean large. Tahitians enjoy life.

One morning of the cruise, I woke at dawn to go spear fishing for mahi mahi, the local blue-finned tuna, and sped through choppy waters on a speed boat, clinging on for life. The only way to stay on board was to stand and grip a bar behind the man in charge of the wheel, an experience much like skiing over moguls, your feet leaving the deck as the boat momentarily becomes airborne at the crest of every wave.

The fisherman spotted his prey by watching for birds skimming the surface. As we finally found one, it was a case of cowering as the boat virtually turned in circles on its side. The driver knew only two words of English, which he used when the eight-pronged spear finally found its mark. "Game over." The long haul back to the island, where the catamaran was anchored reminded me of the scene in the Hobbit when the nearer they got to the dragon's mountain, the further away it seemed.

The seduction was tactile, too. We stopped at an enclosure off one of the islands where you could swim with and feed the fish. It was there that I learnt stingrays' wings have the texture of mushrooms.

In some ways, Tahiti is like Cuba, a society which a visiting European can believe, with glassy eyes, harks back to more innocent days. The buses are 1950s trucks fitted out with wooden benches and often decorated by the flowers which have dropped from behind ears. The sight of kids playing on the mooring ropes of a large French navy ship docked in one of the islands' small ports elicited similar thoughts - as did the twin engine planes seating 16 people that fly between the islands and land on dirt-track airstrips.

To talk of an innocence though is, perhaps, too patronising, For this is a sophisticated society with a nice line in ironic humour - one that has resisted the complete bulldozing by American culture.

But in truth, probably the best thing about the noirish nature of the islands is that it was more a case of their effect on my imagination than anything really sinister.

In hushed tones, Taina, a guide from Tahiti tourism told me about the curse put on her uncle. An arresting woman in her 30s with long, thick, black hair, Taina was brought up on Tahiti but her family was from the more remote Rimatera, part of the Australs, which a local archaeologist said is more like stepping into the last century than the 1950s. Taina's uncle had returned to the island to reclaim some land which the family had owned but fell ill when he came back. For three weeks doctors failed to reach a diagnosis and finally the local priest was called in for an exorcism. It worked.

Taina offered a Gallic shrug of her shoulders. "I would like to go back there one day, but I'm scared," she said with apparent good reason. In Rimatera, so the story goes, recently buried bodies are regularly dug up to make sure they haven't turned into evil giant birds. Now that would be a real adventure into the unknown.

Way to go

The most economical time to visit Tahiti is between April and June, when the weather is also good. Air New Zealand (020-8741 2299, www.airnewzealand .com) flies three times a week to Tahiti; return economy flights from London Heathrow to Papeete via Los Angeles start from £754.10 (inc taxes and free optional LA stopovers), April16 -June 30. Haumana Cruises Catamaran, tel: 689 78 74 18 - Tour operators include: Classic Connection (0870 7519310), Kuoni Travel (01306 747000), Transpacific (01293 567722) and Holiday Options (01444 239999). For general information on Tahiti and her islands, contact Tahiti Tourisme on 020-7771 7023.

In hushed tones, Taina, a guide from Tahiti tourism told me about the curse put on her uncle. An arresting woman in her 30s with long, thick, black hair, Taina was brought up on Tahiti but her family was from the more remote Rimatera, part of the Australs, which a local archaeologist said is more like stepping into the last century than the 1950s. Taina's uncle had returned to the island to reclaim some land which the family had owned but fell ill when he came back. For three weeks doctors failed to reach a diagnosis and finally the local priest was called in for an exorcism. It worked. Taina offered a Gallic shrug of her shoulders. "I would like to go back there one day, but I'm scared," she said with apparent good reason. In Rimatera, so the story goes, recently buried bodies are regularly dug up to make sure they haven't turned into evil giant birds. Now that would be a real adventure into the unknown. webTitle: Minister admits school prizes awarded in error

fields.headline: Minister admits school prizes awarded in error
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The school standards minister, Estelle Morris, yesterday advised 300 schools that they had been awarded cash prizes by mistake.
fields.body:
The school standards minister, Estelle Morris, yesterday advised 300 schools that they had been awarded cash prizes by mistake.

An official inside the Department of Education and Employment was brooding over a "miscalculation" that cost £2m and left ministers embarrassed. Two weeks ago Ms Morris announced the first school achievement awards, through which staff at 6,800 schools would receive cash bonuses, given to staff at schools whose results were either much improved compared with 1997, or better results than schools in similar circumstances.

Primary schools won awards for good results in English, science and, maths. But yesterday she told 300 headteachers: "We have checked the data and a number of schools that were told had won an award had not, in fact, increased their average point score in key stage 2 tests by as much as we had believed. I am sorry to tell you that your school is one of these."

These schools were stripped from the list of improvement award winners on the DfEE website and told they would no longer be sent a certificate and logo. But they have been told they can keep the money, worth an average of £6,500 each, this year. And 300 more schools have been told they will get awards after all. "It is bizarre," said John Ritchie, head teacher of Harton junior in South Shields, whose school was handed £11,200 in error. "I don't think we are going to lose any sleep over it but it's a very strange situation to be in."

Results at Harton junior have showed big improvements, including a 20% increase in those obtaining level four in maths last year. He expects the money will be divided between all his 19 teachers, three classroom assistants and two secretarial staff.

Most of the schools wrongly awarded had improved their scores, but not by enough to qualify for an award.

But Mr Ritchie said he felt sorry for those schools who had missed out on the money and were no less deserving. "Its a terribly unfair way to run an education system."

Ms Morris said: "As soon as the error was brought to my attention this week, I wanted to act quickly to put things right.

"I want to make sure that those schools that qualified for an award but were not on the recent list should receive one as quickly as possible."

The mistake was made by miscalculating the school's average point score in 1997's key stage two tests.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said: "Maybe the department should have its own literacy hour."

webTitle: Somewhere in Britain

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Love in a hot climate
fields.body:
Love in a hot climate

Cleopatra VII, the last Ptolomaic monarch of Egypt, was famed for her sexual allure and intelligence; her life and liasons with Marc Anthony and Julius Caesar are traced with sculptures, coins, inscriptions and gems.

April 12 - August 26. Mon-Wed, Sat, Sun 10am-5:30pm, Thurs-Fri 10am-8:30pm. £7/ £3.50. Cleopatra of Egypt: From History to Myth, The British Museum, Great Russell St, London (020-7323 8000).

In the army now

All guns will blaze at Warwick Castle when centuries of military men are brought to life, from knights demonstrating hand-to- hand combat to Warwick Bowmen showing off their deadly skills.

April 13-16. 10am-6pm. £10.25/ £6.25/ £29. Warwick Castle, Warwick, Warwickshire (0870 4422000).

The science bit

Fire a giant water cannon, walk through an electric storm, operate a JCB digger and take a spin in a gyroscopic chair at the UK's first science adventure centre.

Opens April 12. 10am-5pm. £5.99/ £4.50/ £17.99. Magna, Sheffield Rd, Templeborough, Rotherham, South Yorkshire (01709 720002).

Write on

Pens poised for the world's first exhibition combining modern calligraphy from China, Japan, the Arab world and the West, including demonstrations, workshops and lectures.

Until June 10. Tues- Sat 10.30am-5pm, Sun 2pm-5pm. £2.50/ £0.50. Spring Lines, Ditchling Museum, Church Lane, Ditchling, East Sussex (01273 845777).

Easter events

A busy programme of events and activities at Gunwharf Quays culminates in a Mardi Gras afternoon with high energy samba dancers, trapeze acts and fireworks displays.

Until April 14. 10am- late. Free. Gunwharf Quays, Portsmouth Harbour, Portsmouth (023-9283 6700).

On yer bike

Uncover the symbols and hieroglyphics on the 1,000 cast-iron mileposts along the National Cycle Network to reveal the riddle of the Millennium Time Trail, with special prizes for those who crack the secret code.

For more information, visit www.sustrans.org.uk

Eggstravaganza

A test of observation and wit, the Great Easter Egg Hunt encourages visitors to find objects in the house and grounds which might otherwise pass them by.

April 16. 11am-6pm. £8.50/£5.25. Kentwell Hall, Long Melford, Suffolk (01787 310207).

webTitle: When Ludwig met Karl...

fields.headline: When Ludwig met Karl...
fields.standfirst: Did Wittgenstein threaten Popper with a red-hot poker in Cambridge 55 years ago?  John Eidinow  and  David Edmonds  on the truth behind a row described as a watershed in 20th-century philosophy
fields.trailText: Did Wittgenstein threaten Popper with a red-hot poker in Cambridge 55 years ago? John Eidinow and David Edmonds on the truth behind a row described as a watershed in 20th-century philosophy
fields.body:
On the evening of Friday October 25 1946, the Cambridge Moral Science Club - a discussion group for the university's philosophers and philosophy students - held a meeting. The members assembled in King's College at 8.30pm, in a set of rooms in the Gibbs Building - number three on staircase H.

Although its tenant was a don, Richard Braithwaite, H3 was just as neglected as the other rooms in the building, squalid, dusty and dirty. Heating was dependent on open fires and the inhabitants protected their clothes with their gowns when humping sacks of coal.

That evening, the guest speaker was Dr Karl Popper, up from London to deliver an innocuous-sounding paper, Are There Philosophical Problems?. Among his audience was the chairman of the club, Professor Ludwig Wittgenstein, considered by many to be the most brilliant philosopher of his time. Also present was Bertrand Russell, who for decades had been a household name as a philosopher and radical campaigner.

Popper had recently been appointed to the position of reader in logic and scientific method at the London School of Economics. The Open Society and Its Enemies, his remorseless demolition of totalitarianism, had just been published in England. It had immediately won him a select group of admirers, among them Russell.

This was the only time these three great philosophers - Russell, Wittgenstein and Popper - were together. Yet, to this day, no one can agree precisely what took place. What is clear is that there were vehement exchanges between Popper and Wittgenstein over the fundamental nature of philosophy. These instantly became the stuff of legend. An early version of events had Popper and Wittgenstein battling for supremacy with red-hot pokers.

In Popper's account, found in his intellectual autobiography, Unended Quest, published in 1974, more than two decades after Wittgenstein's death, he put forward a series of what he insisted were real philosophical problems. Wittgenstein summarily dismissed them all. Popper recalled that Wittgenstein "had been nervously playing with the poker", which he used "like a conductor's baton to emphasise his assertions", and when a question came up about the status of ethics, Wittgenstein challenged him to give an example of a moral rule. "I replied: 'Not to threaten visiting lecturers with pokers.' Whereupon Wittgenstein, in a rage, threw the poker down and stormed out."

Those 10 or so minutes in October 1946 still provoke bitter disagreement. Above all, one dispute remains heatedly alive: did Karl Popper lie in his published account of the meeting?

If he did, it was no casual embellishing of the facts but directly concerned two ambitions central to his life: the defeat at a theoretical level of fashionable 20th-century linguistic philosophy and triumph at a personal level over Wittgenstein, the sorcerer who had dogged his career.

To an outsider, a violent confrontation between Wittgenstein and Popper might have seemed implausible. They were both Jews from Vienna and, superficially, they had in common a civilisation - and its dissolution. Although Wittgenstein was the older by 13 years, they had shared the cultural excitement of the last years of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. They had in common, too, the impact on their lives of the lost first world war, the attempt to raise a modern republic on the ruins of the monarchy, the descent into the corporate state, and the maelstrom of Hitler and Nazism. With their Jewish origins, interest in music, contacts with cultural radicals, training as teachers, and their connections with the fountainhead of logical positivism, the Vienna Circle, Wittgenstein and Popper had many potential links. That they had never met was remarkable.

Of the great figures in 20th-century philosophy, only a very few have given their names to those who follow in their path. That one can be identified as a Popperian or a Wittgensteinian is a testament to the originality of these philosophers' ideas and the power of their personalities. Those extraordinary qualities were on display in H3. The thrust of the poker becomes a symbol of the two men's unremitting zeal in their search for the right answers to the big questions.

Three years after Popper's death, a memoir published in the proceedings of one of Britain's most learned bodies, the British Academy, recounted essentially Popper's version of events. It brought down a storm of protest on the head of the author, Popper's successor at the LSE, Professor John Watkins, and sparked off an acerbic exchange of letters in the Times Literary Supplement. A fervent Wittgenstein supporter who had taken part in the meeting, Professor Peter Geach, denounced Popper's account of the meeting as "false from beginning to end". A robust correspondence followed as other witnesses or later supporters of the protagonists piled into the fray.

There was a delightful irony in the conflicting testimonies. They had arisen between people all professionally concerned with theories of epistemology (the grounds of knowledge), understanding and truth. Yet they concerned a sequence of events where those who disagreed were eyewitnesses on crucial questions of fact.

But why was there such anger over what took place more than half a century before, in a small room, at a regular meeting of an obscure university club, during an argument over an arcane topic?

Of the 30 present that night, nine, now in their 70s or 80s, responded by letter, phone and, above all, email from across the globe to appeals for memories of that evening. Their ranks include a former English high court judge, Sir John Vinelott. There are five professors. Professor Peter Munz had come to St John's from New Zealand and returned home to become a notable academic. His book, Our Knowledge of the Search for Knowledge, opened with the poker incident: it was, he wrote, a "symbolic and in hindsight prophetic" watershed in 20th-century philosophy.

Professor Stephen Toulmin is an eminent philosopher, co-author of a demanding revisionist text on Wittgenstein, placing his philosophy in the context of Viennese culture and fin de siècle intellectual ferment. As a young King's research fellow, he turned down a post as assistant to Karl Popper.

Geach, an authority on logic, lectured at Birmingham University, and then at Leeds. Professor Michael Wolff specialised in Victorian England, and his academic career took him to the US. Peter Gray-Lucas became an academic and then switched to business, first in steel, then photographic film, then papermaking. Stephen Plaister became a classics master.

"Consider this poker," Geach hears Wittgenstein demand of Popper, picking up the poker and using it in a philosophical example. But, as the discussion rages on between them, Wittgenstein is not reducing the guest to silence (the impact he is accustomed to), nor the guest silencing him (ditto). Finally, and only after having challenged assertion after assertion made by Popper, Wittgenstein gives up. At some stage he must have risen to his feet, because Geach sees him walk back to his chair and sit down. He is still holding the poker. With a look of great exhaustion, he leans back in his chair and stretches out his arm towards the fireplace. The poker drops on to the tiles of the hearth with a little rattle. At this point Geach's attention is caught by the host, Braithwaite. Alarmed by Wittgenstein's gesticulating with the poker, he is making his way in a crouching position through the audience. He picks up the poker and somehow makes away with it. Shortly afterwards, Wittgenstein rises to his feet and, in a huff, quietly leaves the meeting, shutting the door behind him.

Wolff sees that Wittgenstein has the poker idly in his hand and, as he stares at the fire, is fidgeting with it. Someone says something that visibly annoys Wittgenstein. By this time Russell has become involved. Wittgenstein and Russell are both standing. Wittgenstein says: "You misunderstand me, Russell. You always misunderstand me."

Russell says: "You're mixing things up, Wittgenstein. You always mix things up."

Munz watches Wittgenstein suddenly take the poker - red hot - out of the fire and gesticulate with it angrily in front of Popper's face. Then Russell takes the pipe out of his mouth and says firmly: "Wittgenstein, put down that poker at once!"

Wittgenstein complies, then, after a short wait, gets up and walks out, slamming the door.

From Gray-Lucas's standpoint, Wittgenstein seems to be growing very excited about what he obviously believes is Popper's improper behaviour and is waving the poker about. Wittgenstein is acting in "his usual grotesquely arrogant, self-opinionated, rude and boorish manner. It made a good story afterwards to say that he had 'threatened' Popper with a poker."

Plaister, too, sees the poker raised. It really seems to him the only way to deal with Popper, and he has no feeling of surprise or shock. To Toulmin, sitting only six feet from Wittgenstein, nothing at all out of the ordinary is occurring. He is focusing on Popper's attack on the idea that philosophy is meaningless and his production of various examples. A question about causality arises and at that point Wittgenstein picks up the poker to use as a tool in order to make a point about causation. Later in the meeting - after Wittgenstein has left - he hears Popper state his poker principle: that one should not threaten visiting lecturers with pokers.

Vinelott alone sees the crucial point - whether Popper makes what was probably an attempt at a joke to Wittgenstein's face - in Popper's way. Vinelott hears Popper utter his poker principle and observes that Wittgenstein is clearly annoyed at what he thinks is an unduly frivolous remark. Wittgenstein leaves the room abruptly, but there is no question of the door being slammed.

The debate continues and the story has achieved the status, if not of an urban myth, then at least of an ivory-tower fable. The story goes beyond the characters and beliefs of the antagonists. It is also the story of the schism in 20th-century philosophy over the significance of language: a division between those who diagnosed traditional philosophical problems as purely linguistic entanglements and those who believed that these problems transcended language. In the end, of course, it is the story of a linguistic puzzle in itself: to whom did Popper utter what words in that room full of witnesses, and why?

And what of the sine qua non of this story? The fate of the poker remains a mystery. Many have searched for it in vain. According to one report, Braithwaite disposed of it - to put an end to the prying of academics and journalists.

 This is an edited extract from Wittgenstein's Poker: the Story of a Ten- Minute Argument Between Two Great Philosophers, published on April 9 by Faber, price £9.99. To order a copy for £7.99 plus p&p, freephone Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166 102.

webTitle: A reluctant heart-throb

fields.headline: Twice Shy
fields.standfirst:
Colin Firth was a reluctant heart-throb as the haughty but lovestruck Darcy in Pride And Prejudice six years ago. There were, he felt, more rigorous, less conspicuous roles to take on. So why risk diving into the same pool again, playing a postmodernised Darcy in Bridget Jones’s Diary, asks Susie Steiner
