He argues that the United Nations has to be saved from insolvency and given a greater leadership role which escapes from the asymmetry caused by the veto power of the five richest and/or largest countries. "There needs to be a watchdog institution which is concerned with inequality and fair trade, asks why the USA and Europe are so restrictive to products from the third world, and raises questions about the pricing policy of the drug companies," he says. For the past 10 years, Sen has been married to the economic historian, Emma Rothschild, an expert on Adam Smith and Fellow of King's. The two children he brought up on his own have done well. Indrani is a journalist in New York and Kabir teaches music at a school in Boston, and has a rock band called Uncle Trouble. Sen usually spends the winter holidays in India, where he likes to go on long bike rides, and maintains a house in Cambridge, Massachusetts, where he and Emma spend the spring and long vacations. Asked how he relaxes, he replies: "I read a lot and like arguing with people." As well as his global interests, he has taken up one local goal. He wants to raise the proportion of state school pupils getting into Trinity. There has been progress, and for the first time last year, the college made more than half (53%) of its offers to state-school pupils. Sen, however, acknowledges there is still a gap, since nationally 65% of students with three A-levels are from state schools. "This is not a personal initiative," he insists. "The council was already doing it before my time, and the undergraduates on the access committee who visit sixth forms are very keen to explain we are not unfriendly to state schools. My reputation would be mud if I seemed to be trying to take the credit." A lifelong believer in equality, in this, as in all his other contributions, he feels the main thing is to reach the correct analysis. He is not a crusader. Others must implement the solutions. Life at a glance: Amartya Kumar Sen Born: Santiniketan, Bengal, November 3 1933 Education: Presidency College, Calcutta; Trinity College, Cambridge Married: Nabaneeta Dev, 1960-71, (two daughters, Antara and Nandana); Eva Colorni, 1978 (died 1985), a daughter, Indrani, and son, Kabir; Emma Rothschild,1991. Some books: Choice of Techniques, 1960; Collective Choice and Social Welfare, 1970; On Economic Inequality, 1973; Poverty and Famines: an Essay on Entitlement and Deprivation, 1981; Hunger and Public Action, jointly edited with Jean Dreze, 1989; India: Economic Development and Social Opportunity, with Jean Dreze, 1995; Development as Freedom, 1999. Awards: Indira Gandhi Gold Medal Award of the Asiatic Society, 1994; Nobel prize for economics, 1998; Eisenhower Medal, USA, 2000; Honorary Companion of Honour, UK, 2000.

webTitle: Madeleine Bunting on the sheep cull

fields.headline: Who are the brutes now?
fields.standfirst:
This slaughter of animals is utterly barbaric. Sheep and cows have rights too

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: This slaughter of animals is utterly barbaric. Sheep and cows have rights too.
fields.body:
For weeks, whenever I've watched the news with the children around, I've had my finger poised over the remote control button. The screen goes blank repeatedly. Now, the Easter trip to the Lake District looks implausible. Why? Ask the children.

Will foot and mouth kill us? No. Is it killing the animals? No. How do you explain this mass killing to a six-year-old? The more you try, the more stark the collective madness becomes. Those mass graves, the funeral pyres of healthy animals. The death toll creeping close to the one million mark, those condemned to die numbered in hundreds of thousands more: the neat little charts of lines soaring ever upwards.

It's as if we have all gone dizzy with zeros: thousands of animals are dying, millions of pounds have been lost, billions more pounds at risk. It has numbed our critical faculties so that, dazed, the only debate is why the killing can't be quicker, when the election should be or the usual blame-game - it's the government's fault, it's a Chinese restaurant or it's the farmers' own fault. Environmentalists, to their shame, seem to have seen this solely as an opportunity for "I told you so", a chance to capitalise on their crusade against modern farming.

But if environmentalism is about anything, it is about a profound challenge to human beings' terrible arrogance and destructiveness towards all other forms of life with which we share the planet. That's not just dolphins, tigers and foxes, but the thousands of cows and sheep we seem quite prepared to slaughter.

Ah, you say, but all these lovely cows and sheep were going to be slaughtered anyway, so what's it matter if they end their lives in a limed pit a few months earlier? Call me fanciful, but I see a world of difference between life sustaining other forms of life and a wanton waste of life. Most cultures in human history have seen that distinction, hence the ethic of many hunting societies in which you kill for your need, not for your greed.

That rubric has ensured a balance between human life and other species at many times in many places in human history. It doesn't romanticise, or sentimentalise the fact that all life depends and often preys on other life; the universe is a cycle of destruction as well as creation. In turn, my body will support the worms and the daisies. That kind of thinking means I gave up vegetarianism long ago and I've never been that interested in animal rights.

But what we are witnessing now is the nadir of western industrialised societies' total disregard for animals. The mass graves at Great Orton represent the triumph of greed over any other relationship we have to other forms of life. The almost complete absence of any serious debate about whether it is right to kill this kind of quantity of animals is, quite literally, unbelievable.

Where are the animal rights protesters who have been making the lives of the scientists hell at Huntingdon Life Sciences? Where are the hunt saboteurs? Why is it wrong to experiment on a few dozen kittens or monkeys but quite all right to kill hundreds of thousands of sheep? Who's mad and who sane when a government committed to bringing in legislation on fox hunting is presiding over the biggest slaughter of animals in human history?

The RSPCA is concerned that some sheep are not being properly killed and might be buried alive. Compassion for World Farming is worried that normal legislation banning animals being killed within sight of each other has had to be suspended. Isn't this fiddling while Rome burns? They don't question the big picture of this killing orgy. Will we be as docile, accepting the experts' arguments when the trained marksmen roam the countryside shooting the wild deer, wild ponies, birds and foxes and poison is laid down for hedgehogs?

At what point do we discover some remnant of morality and recognise that our corner of the planet and its residents are not here simply for our sake? How can we lecture America on global warming when we are applying a similar principle? Most importantly, at what point do we say enough is enough, the end simply doesn't justify the means?

Perhaps the Herdwick sheep was the point for me. A rare breed, they are at risk of being completely wiped out. Beatrix Potter's healthy herd is one of several designated for slaughter simply because of proximity to infected farms. Having spent more time than I once thought possible reading Potter, and building Lego farms, how am I to explain to children where the lambs have gone?

And no, the fascination of small children with farms and domestic animals is not sentimental (certainly not in the broad moral universe of Potter where, for every coy Mrs Tiggy-Winkle, there is a sadistic Samuel Whiskers), it is the instinctive curiosity about life, about being alive and what is alive. Why else are Sea Monkeys such a hit?

A touching detail about the Herdwick: they graze on the fells but they have no need of fences or shepherds because they pass on knowledge of their boundaries from ewe to lamb over generations. We know and respect this kind of intelligence in elephants but not sheep: how come the latter have been relegated to the lowest rung in our hierarchy of species?

How dare we criticise poaching in Africa for ivory or in India for tiger skins, when at least many of the poachers kill out of genuine need? Or take another analogy which also demonstrates our insufferable moral double standards. Those Herdwick sheep are part of British heritage, as much as stately homes and country churches; so how can we criticise the Taliban for destroying the Bamiyan Buddhas?

Mad analogies? Maybe, but it's becoming harder and harder to work out what's sane and what's mad. A whole set of considerations have been erased from the debate. At this time of year one of the greatest delights is lambs playing in the fields, but we understand the tragedy of this catastrophe only in terms of its effect on the farmers - their income and their lives - rather than the animals themselves. But how come these animals don't have rights? We share up to 90% of our genetic material with these creatures who feel pain and anxiety.

The most cursory philosophical knowledge exposes the flimsiness of the intellectual constructs by which we have awarded ourselves rights, and sheep and cows none, as JM Coetzee explores in his novel, The Lives of Animals. These considerations have been totally subordinated to an economic rationale of productivity, efficiency and export markets from which almost no one demurs (farmers, government, animal welfare groups). It's a terrible indictment of a culture that our accommodation with the market has so numbed us that we can see no other way of viewing the world and all its occupants. Who now are the brutes when we have become so brutal?

webTitle: The right secondment can help you reach for the stars

fields.headline: The right secondment can help you reach for the stars
fields.standfirst: Do you need a a springboard to reach higher office?
fields.trailText: Do you need a a springboard to reach higher office?
fields.body:
Few graduates would pass up an opportunity to improve their skills working in another company, knowing they could always return to their old job. Secondments allow you to make this happen. They're growing in number and are an ideal vehicle for ambitious graduates.

"We persuade people to go on secondments early on in their careers, while they are still open to new ideas and before they get set in their ways," says John Hicks, an adviser with Interchange, a government-run scheme which gives people from different areas of the economy a chance to work in government and civil servants a taste of life in the private sector.

John reveals that Interchange, which was launched in the seventies, has enjoyed a 28% increase in activity during the last couple of years.

A secondment can last anything from three months to three years. Or it may involve a day a week for about six months. You are paid for going on a secondment and your salary may come with extra benefits such as living, food and travel expenses. However, if you are working in an expensive part of the country, these perceived benefits will actually be necessities.

Big blue-chip companies like PricewaterhouseCoopers and Ernst and Young offer secondments within and outside their companies.

Christine Macaulay, a 24-year old trainee chartered accountant has been on two secondments since she joined Ernst and Young nearly three years ago. She usually works at the company's office in Inverness but has just completed a two-month secondment in London.

"Secondments often come up when a department has a very busy period, which is how I ended up working in London," says Christine, a Glasgow University graduate.

"London's busy time coincided with a quiet period in Inverness so I was asked if I wanted to go to London. It's not something staff have to do if they don't want to."

In Inverness Christine audits the accounts of a variety of companies, but in London she specialised in auditing the accounts of media companies.

"It was good for me career-wise because I gained knowledge of a different industry and built new contacts. If I decide to move around internally, I've got ready-made contacts who are familiar with my work."

Christine also learned how to adapt to living and working in London: the different mix of people, the fast pace of life and the arduous journey on the tube during rush hour.

"It's been a stark contrast to life and work in Inverness where the pace is slower, I can walk to work in 20 minutes and drive to the countryside within ten minutes from the centre of town," she says.

Christine's first secondment in the summer of last year was near her home in Inverness. "I worked for five months in a company on a consultancy basis, giving business and accounting advice.

"I learned a lot about how to get my point across, while taking other people's objectives and perspectives into consideration. It gave me greater confidence to speak out when dealing with clients."

Secondments come highly recommended from Christine. "It gives you a chance to try out a certain industry and get paid," she says.

Christine wants to continue auditing but doesn't know which industry to specialise in yet. So inevitably this will mean a few more secondments. "One abroad for a couple of years would be pretty cool."

A secondment could improve your chances of promotion when you return to your old job, though don't expect it to happen overnight.

Of course, sometimes a secondment may not be of your choosing. However, it is vital that you adopt a positive attitude. If you don't, it is extremely unlikely that you will gain from the experience. Focus on the positive and see it as a finite amount of time in which to learn all you can.

webTitle: How to... detox yourself and be a better workmate

fields.headline: How to... detox yourself and be a better workmate
fields.standfirst: Cleanse your system and you'll gain extra energy and creativity
fields.trailText: Cleanse your system and you'll gain extra energy and creativity
fields.body:
Detoxing is supposed to do great things for the body, but what about the mind? Could a good internal seeing-to turn you into a bright, enthusiastic workmate, bursting with new ideas and extra energy? Or might it transform you into a tired, cranky stress-head, desperate for a decent cup of toxic tea and an office lunch that isn't composed entirely of random green vegetables.

But before we get to all that, we had better answer a more pressing question: why bother detoxing in the first place?

According to Farmicia, the Covent Garden specialist in "natural urban healing", we are all pretty blocked up with modern poisons. Our daily consumption of drugs, alcohol, pollution and various food additives is inhibiting our bodies' ability to renew themselves automatically. So, suggests Farmicia, "it is important to give your system a respite and allow it to catch up".

At the end of a detox programme they say you'll feel more "refreshed, creative, motivated, productive and energetic".

It sounds too good to be true. But it works, insists June Shaw of the Cedar Falls Health Farm in Somerset. "A detox for the mind is a bit like a service for the car. It simply makes everything work better."

I decided to put this theory to the test. For cost and convenience, I went for a Farmacia DIY kit (£20). This comes complete with a detox elixir, detox tea, nutritional supplement, sample menu plan, and a list of recipes. The latter are not as bad as you may think: the food is simple, but not unbearable. Fruit for breakfast, salad for lunch, soup or perhaps some fish for dinner. Plus lots and lots and lots and lots of water. It is not so much what you have to consume as what you are not allowed to consume.

Detox specialists say it's best to supplement your dietary regime with several treatments. Some of these can be done in the privacy of your home; both E'Spa and Elemis do a range of aromatherapy bath and skin products that promise to improve the detoxing process (priced from £13.50).

Or you can upgrade to a salon. Thalgo and The Universal Contour Wrap plaster marine mud (yum) on to the body to help cleanse it inside and out (priced from £38).

If this all seems a bit OTT London-based health clinic Balance, provides two other alternatives. One is a specialist massage (£65) designed to improve the body's pumping mechanism, known as the lymphatic system. The other is a food intolerance test (£125) which results in a complete nutritional profile with specific advise on ways to get the most of your detox.

But this is all for nought if you can't stay the course. Ian Marber, founder of TheFoodDoctor.com, has the following suggestions on how best to avoid temptation:

 Remove from your house anything you're not supposed to eat.

 Buy in plenty of the things you are supposed to eat.

 Eat often and in small portions to ward off any food panics.

 Remember you will be releasing lots of toxins and that it won't always be easy.

 Keep your eyes on the goal - you will look, feel, and work better.

I have tried to put this into practice over the last week or two. Sometimes I succeeded. Other times not. There have been afternoons when, starved of caffeine and that other office essential, sugar, I have been really, really tired. Not to mention irritable. Oh, and very short tempered. ("What's new", my nearest colleague may say.) But I do feel better, mentally, for the experience.

As for whether it was worth the effort_ hmmm, that's a difficult question; one I'll need to consider over a tall double latte and a sod-off sized danish.

Ian Marber, founder of TheFoodDoctor.com, has the following suggestions on how best to avoid temptation:  Remove from your house anything you're not supposed to eat.  Buy in plenty of the things you are supposed to eat.  Eat often and in small portions to ward off any food panics.  Remember you will be releasing lots of toxins and that it won't always be easy.  Keep your eyes on the goal - you will look, feel, and work better. I have tried to put this into practice over the last week or two. Sometimes I succeeded. Other times not. There have been afternoons when, starved of caffeine and that other office essential, sugar, I have been really, really tired. Not to mention irritable. Oh, and very short tempered. ("What's new", my nearest colleague may say.) But I do feel better, mentally, for the experience. As for whether it was worth the effort_ hmmm, that's a difficult question; one I'll need to consider over a tall double latte and a sod-off sized danish.

webTitle: An ABC guide to complex company hierarchies

fields.headline: An ABC guide to complex company hierarchies
fields.trailText: Moving on up
fields.body:
A. Ordering procedures

Scratch the surface of any apparently egalitarian organisation and you'll find a hierarchy. Just because the boss doesn't have a special place to park or sits in the same room as you doesn't mean your positions are equal. Hierarchies are inevitable. The way you understand and respond to the one you're part of contributes to how content you are at work, how well you fit in and how likely you are to get on.

B. Perfect fit

Make a mental list of those you have authority over and those you expect to defer to - there's your hierarchy. If you believe it's fair and are happy to go along with it you're likely to flourish. Having respect for the way things are is hard to fake, but showing you think those at the top are a waste of time is a sure route to career stagnation or regression. If you feel so strongly you can't hide it, why stay?

C. Settle down

Different organisations base their hierarchies on different criteria so it should be possible to find one that's right for you. Well-defined and differentiated structures will suit those who crave order and clear lines of accountability. These are most often available in older organisations. Newer companies and small employers are more likely to have fuzzy formations, good for those who enjoy taking responsibility. Finding a position that's comfortable is essential if you're to remain in it for any length of time - don't settle for less.

webTitle: Help: My colleague is a charlatan!

fields.headline: Help: My colleague is a charlatan!
fields.standfirst: The person I share my workload with is an accomplished skiver, but so charming and plausible that everyone thinks he's wonderful. In reality I'm carrying him, but no one would believe me.  TG, solicitor, Bath
fields.trailText: The person I share my workload with is an accomplished skiver, but so charming and plausible that everyone thinks he's wonderful. In reality I'm carrying him, but no one would believe me. TG, solicitor, Bath
fields.body:
One of the perils of team work is that the distribution of duties can become uneven. In many cases it's hard to unravel who contributed what, so success or failure reflect on everyone. There are going to be times you need to compensate for someone else's shortcomings.

That's fine if it's mutually beneficial and you get your share of support when necessary. When there's a real imbalance you have to recognise that you have contributed to it, which means you also have the ability to even things up again. The much-admired are difficult to confront. However if you're carrying someone, you always have the option of dropping them - but try to make it look like an accident.

Popular opinion is hard to change but easy to exploit. It would be counter-productive to pick a fight with the wonder boy; your chances of winning are slim. On the other hand, if you ask to be reassigned to a different partner because his charms are so distracting, you will receive understanding rather than disapproval.

If you find that embarrassing, ask for your reasons to be kept confidential. Shifting your problem to someone else is uncomradely, but there's no telling what an new perspective could do.

The more people who have the chance to work closely with your workshy colleague, the more likely it is that his cover will be blown.

webTitle: Graduates want an outlet for their global ambitions

fields.headline: Graduates want an outlet for their global ambitions
fields.standfirst: Foreign Office romps home in first place
fields.trailText: Foreign Office romps home in first place
fields.body:
The BBC has succumbed to pressure from the government, handing over the coveted title of UK graduates' ideal employer to the Foreign & Commonwealth Office. Volvo, IBM, WS Atkins and BP are also among the winners in this year's Top 100 Ideal Employer Rankings compiled by research and management consulting company Universum. But big traditional graduate employers such as BT, JP Morgan, and Ford take some of the biggest tumbles.

More than 5,500 final-year students at 43 universities across the UK were asked to name the five organisations or companies they would most like to join. And for the first time since the annual survey began in 1997, there are three government offices listed in the top 20 employers. The Foreign & Commonwealth Office moves up from fourth to first, the Cabinet Office (11th position last year) climbs to 8th and GCHQ rises to 17th position (from 26th and 27th respectively in the two previous surveys).

The runner up, for the third consecutive year, is Richard Branson's Virgin Group, which is still perceived as a leading employer brand despite disappointment over the People's Lottery and question marks over the reliability of Virgin Trains.

Taking third position is management consulting group Accenture (previously Andersen Consulting), fifth last year, which may be enjoying a golden halo effect thanks to the controversial 'golden hello' introduced last year to beef up its appeal to graduates.

Graduates continue to show preference towards technology-based companies as evidenced by the rapid ascent of companies like IBM, Vodafone, Marconi and WS Atkins - up an astonishing 64 places on its position last year. In contrast the darling of the nineties, Microsoft has dropped out of the top 10 - the fall-out, perhaps from bad publicity surrounding its recent court case.

Appearing in the results for 2001 for the first time are two Swedish companies: Volvo (7th) and IKEA (27th). Other new entries include Cisco Systems (31st), Audi (37th), Sun Microsystems (49th), PA Consulting (57th), NTL (77th), Johnson & Johnson (78th), ABB (90th), Pharmacia (99th) and Bayer (100th).

Despite the hype surrounding start-ups and internet companies last year, this year's rankings suggest that large employers are back on top - a reflection perhaps of current worries about recession and job insecurity.

"Our research this year suggests graduates are seeking more balance between their personal lives and careers. This is, possibly why we have seen the financial institutions drop in the ranking list because graduates view them as rigid corporate environments, with long working hours," says Maria Cansick, spokesperson for Universum which specialises in graduate recruitment. "Graduates also want employers who can offer increasingly challenging tasks and the chance to work internationally. It could be one reason why the Foreign & Commonwealth Office has been nominated as the ideal employer and consulting is still one of the most popular career paths."

webTitle: Mark Lawson on the election date

fields.headline: A May poll would be madness
fields.standfirst:
An early election might do for Blair what the poll tax did for Thatcher

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: An early election might do for Blair what the poll tax did for Thatcher.
fields.body:
Whatever qualities Tony Blair has displayed in office, he has never actually seemed mad, a charge routinely levelled against Margaret Thatcher. But a May or even June election now seems to me insanity. What the poll tax was to Thatcher, the poll date would become to Blair. He might continue in office, but his judgment would be suspected ever after; this single decision would become a focus for the doubts about him.

What's most astonishing is that the people reportedly keenest on a May 3 election are the invisible Millbank operatives who run the campaign. This seems largely to be a case of inertia motivation, like someone carrying on with the reception and the honeymoon even though their partner ran screaming from the church before the vows. It would be a fitting epitaph for the age of spin if these types prove to have thrown away power purely because they had booked their holidays in Tuscany for the middle of May.

Oh, I know what they say. The opinion polls remain stable. The media and the public are tiring of sick-cow disease as a story. The farming lands vote Tory or Lib Dem anyway. William Hague wouldn't be electable even if Blair were caught in bed with a troop of boy scouts on May 2. All this may be true. But what these professional campaigners are ignoring is that their biggest problem is the campaign itself and its effect on the prime minister's subsequent image.

Consider first the question of posters and election broadcasts. We can guess what was planned: pictures of Tony grinning amid delighted cancer patients, schoolchildren and investment bankers. Now, if these images run, the public will have in their heads an alternative spool of rural inedible barbecues and army marksmen.

Last Sunday, Rory Bremner ran a sketch in which a Blair speech about how he had changed Britain beyond recognition was intercut with footage of the victims of bovine firing squads. One of the effects of satire is to expose the weak areas in a person and Blair must realise that any triumphalist speech he made would be rendered comic by public knowledge of the reality.

Millbank should also reflect that the Tories, in their posters and commercials, will produce a version of the Bremner sketch. Until six weeks ago, you felt sorry for Conservative copywriters. After four years of presidential-style competence, Blair offered no obvious target for attack. What could Hague's slogan be?

Now the possibilities pile up like massacred cattle. "What Are They So Afraid Of After May?" against pictures of Wall Street screens cascading. Pictures of the farmyards which are now graveyards with the copyline: "Let The Country Decide". Even, perhaps, a split-screen with Margaret Thatcher on one side and a proud Friesian eating grass on the other and a deep voice intoning: "You might have been glad to get rid of this cow but did you really want to get rid of all these?"

Another worry for Labour is Blair's demeanour. Although accused of obsession with presentation, this PM has never been able to spin his emotions. Under pressure, he looks instantly old and ill. The last six weeks have already aged him by two years. Any Kennedyesque campaign planned by his handlers will now look as if it's got George Bush senior in it.

The candidate is also uncomfortable with tough interviews. Earlier this year, it was hard to see how the television and radio interrogations during the campaign could be spun out to half an hour. Now foot and mouth - as a peg for questions on arrogance, competence and fear of the economic future - could fill half an hour alone.

The most intriguing shapes in the white smoke coming out of Labour HQ are suggestions that Blair might distance himself from the campaigning, leaving the chancellor to be Labour's face on the hustings. This scheme has the initial problem of being entirely illogical. If the country is in such crisis that the PM can't campaign, then why is he holding an unnecessary poll anyway?

However, such a strategy would have the benefit of connecting the so far carefully distanced Mr Brown with the government's troubles. It would be him submitting to Paxman's pulled faces, Humphrys's impatient snort and the placards of protesters. This could be a useful precautionary culling of a potential rival if the prime minister were to find himself returned to power but weakened.

The final point that Blair should consider this weekend at Chequers is historical. This column has often referred to the tendency of Britain and America since the 70s to have leaders paired by ideology or circumstance: Callaghan/Ford (unelected); Thatcher/Reagan (charismatic monetarist); and Blair/Clinton (youthful presentationalist). So who's the most fitting twin for George Bush?

Optimistic Conservatives have concluded from these parallels that Britain will now follow America in electing a rightwing half-wit who no one can quite believe got the job. This remains unlikely, but the British system probably is about to produce a political pair for Bush by choosing a leader so undermined by the grubby conditions of his election that he surrenders all political legitimacy.

For the disenfranchisement of Florida, read the theft of electoral rights from the countryside. Though actual defeat may be improbable, a May or June election puts Blair at severe risk of loss of meaning.

webTitle: Polling date jitters set in

fields.headline: Polling date jitters set in
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Senior cabinet ministers and officials at Labour headquarters at Millbank are piling pressure on Tony Blair not to delay a May 3 general election.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, James Meek  and  Angelique Chrisafis
fields.body:
Senior cabinet ministers and officials at Labour headquarters at Millbank are piling pressure on Tony Blair not to delay a May 3 general election, amid signs that the prime minister's visits to struggling farming communities have persuaded him of the necessity of postponement during the foot and mouth epidemic.

Senior ministers claim that Mr Blair now sees himself as the "father of the nation" and is in the mood to make a decision in what he regards as the national interest. Mr Blair yesterday visited farms in Dumfries and the regional control centre in Newcastle.

The tourist industry also made a desperate call for him to press ahead, warning that delaying the local elections would cripple rural economies by sending the wrong message to tourists at a vital time.

Following a meeting in Manchester, regional tourist directors warned that the industry was on the verge of losing £1bn a month in takings. Dorothy Naylor, chairman of the regional directors of English tourist boards, said: "We need confident and assertive decisions from the government and delay of the local elections, or general election will send just the wrong message".

But with the decision 48 hours away, Mr Blair is being inundated by conflicting advice, with some of his closest advisers at Downing Street and his local constituency in Sedgefield urging a delay. A postponement is also being urged by the influential Lord Falconer and by the pollster Philip Gould, who has warned that 25 seats could be lost if an election is held on May 3.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and the party's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, all support May 3 to various degrees, but recognise that the judgment is finally balanced.

In a sign of the divisions even among Labour modernisers, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, is urging a postponement and the industry secretary, Stephen Byers, supports May 3.

In encouraging news for Mr Blair, a senior scientist advising the government on the likely course of the epidemic said yesterday that if the number of new cases today and tomorrow stayed below 60, it would suggest the disease was being beaten.

Professor Roy Anderson of Imperial College London, a member of one of three teams of epidemiologists feeding forecasts to the government, said the next few days were critical.

"There are some encouraging signs in the epidemic," he said. "This week is crucial. If the cases this weekend stay around the 30 or 40 mark, or even a little bit higher - the 50s is all right - that's good news. If they don't, there's a lot more effort to be made."

Mr Brown meanwhile met his closest advisers, including leading US Democrats, in a Soho restaurant on Thursday night to discuss tactics. Some warned that foot and mouth could dominate the election campaign for two weeks.

Mr Blair's fateful decision is likely to be taken at a Chequers summit tomorrow, by which time the latest figures on the spread of the outbreak will be available. Amid tentative signs that the disease may be abating, he delayed until Monday a decision on whether to press ahead with vaccination of dairy cattle in Cumbria.

The Ministry of Agriculture, was not officially releasing fresh figures, but said that 780 cases had been confirmed with 200,000 sheep in the neighbouring zones.

Among the farmers Mr Blair met was Donald Biggar, from Castle Douglas, who had watched more than 300 of his pedigree livestock shot with stun guns the night before.

Mr Biggar said: "I think [the prime minister] saw the emotion in it and the need to support the industry."

Emerging from the meeting, Mr Blair said he had heard some "really heart-rendering accounts. It is a tragic and terrible situation for people here and I can only imagine the distress that is felt".

webTitle: Mandelson comes out fighting as convert to regionalism

fields.headline: Mandelson comes out fighting as convert to regionalism
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson yesterday relaunched his political career as a champion of the country's less favoured provinces by publicly challenging Tony Blair's much-quoted dismissal of a north-south divide while calling for regional devolution to move power and wealth from London and the south-east.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson yesterday relaunched his political career as a champion of the country's less favoured provinces by publicly challenging Tony Blair's much-quoted dismissal of a north-south divide while calling for regional devolution to move power and wealth from London and the south-east.

Parting company with the prime minister's cautious approach to constitutional reform in England, the former Northern Ireland secretary portrayed himself as a convert to the cause of regionalism and served notice that he intends to challenge ministers where necessary by arguing for greater decentralisation.

Over two months after resigning from the cabinet for the second time, Mr Mandelson chose his Hartlepool constituency to deliver a carefully-crafted speech which could put him on a collision course with some former ministerial colleagues who regard English devolution as a dangerous step into uncharted political territory.

Raising the stakes in the battle to persuade Tony Blair to hold a series of devolution referendums after the election, he effectively called for self-government in the north-east and other areas where there is demand and urged people to seize an historic opportunity.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, has successfully pressed Mr Blair to produce a green paper outlining the case for eight elected regional assemblies after the election.

But the prime minister, who has said that talk of a north-south divide is an over-simplification, still appears uncertain over whether a case has been made for regional referendums to test support for English devolution in poorer regions like the north-east.

Mr Mandelson, still smarting from his abrupt departure from the Northern Ireland post after being cleared by the Hammond inquiry in the cash-for-passports affair, was careful not to mention the prime minister by name yesterday. Mr Blair has argued that differences within regions are as wide as any north-south divide.

But Mr Mandelson's inference was clear, when he said: "Some argue that there is no longer a regional problem in the UK, only a problem with areas of greater economic and social difficulties within regions. Certainly there are sharp differences in performance between communities within the north-east.

"But the statistics show that a large performance gap between regions remains. London and the south-east is the richest region in the EU ... but in every other part of the UK standards of living are below the European average."

His Hartlepool constituency remained "one of the highest areas of persistent unemployment in the UK".

But a strong, centrally driven policy which attempted to bridge regional imbalances was no longer enough.

Now, he said, the north-east had to reverse years of neglect, and being excluded from sharing in Britain's prosperity, by "taking control of its own destiny".

While putting his thesis into an historical context, Mr Mandelson - who, until recently, claimed that some critics of government policy were "talking down" the north-east - clearly had current policy in his sights when he attacked overheating in the south-east, skill shortages, and pressure on the green belt, while other areas "suffered industrial decimation, depopulation and decline."

Recent figures show the north-south divide widened slightly in the present government's first three years.

To correct such imbalances, Mr Mandelson called for an active regional policy running hand in glove with political devolution. He argued that this was as much in the interests of the south-east as the north.

"Perhaps transport congestion and price inflation in the south-east would in time force some businesses to break free of the markets where they have prospered," he said.

"They might locate elsewhere. But there is no guarantee. And those market forces are just as likely to drive investment away from poorer regions."

webTitle: Comment: US wants isolation from the rest of the world

fields.headline: The cold shoulder
fields.standfirst:
The US wants isolation from the rest of the world - including our weather

Special report: global warming
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The US wants isolation from the rest of the world - including our weather.
fields.body:
It's not that George Bush is ill-informed about the emission of greenhouse gases, but he can't understand why everyone doesn't just go into their greenhouses and close the windows.

"Yup, it's a kinda warm humid gas - smells of tomato plants and bags of fertiliser. But frankly I just don't see it as a threat to the future of the world."

By reneging on the US commitment to the Kyoto treaty on climate change, President Bush has signalled that the US is returning to isolationism, only this time he's decided that the US won't be having anything to do with the rest of the world's weather. Like King Canute, he thinks he is immune from the advancing seas. (Actually Canute was trying to demonstrate the opposite, but back in the 11th century political spin was not so sophisticated as it is today.)

The timing of Bush's announcement seemed to be designed to bring maximum humiliation to the visiting Gerhard Schröder. The German chancellor tried to put a brave face on it; saying that he and Bush had had a pleasant lunch and had found common ground on all issues except one. So they agreed to have sparkling water rather than still, to share the medley of mixed vegetables and croquette potatoes, and the only sticking point was whether the US should honour its agreement to help prevent half the world's population being under water in a few years' time. Well, two out of three's not bad. If they sat in the no smoking section of the restaurant, you can be sure that Dubya puffed on cigars throughout.

Bush was warned that the US oil companies will now have to face the wrath of Green party Euro MPs. Boy, now they're for it. The irony is, of course, that the Greens had it in their power to save the Kyoto treaty. They knew that the environmental breakthrough made by Clinton would not be supported by Bush. But they stood against the Democratic party anyway, and as a direct result of that decision the world's environment will now be affected for the worse. Until we win the fight for proportional representation, the Greens, like everyone else on the left, only serve to help the right when they stand in elections against the Democrats or the Labour party.

Now we will have to wait until the Atlantic Ocean is lapping at the knees of the Statue of Liberty before the US government admits there may possibly be a problem. The oil companies have their man in the White House and are in complete control. Like a driver waiting to fill up his car, Bush can't do anything until the man from the petrol company presses the little button in the kiosk.

George Bush's America has by far the greatest number of car owners in the world. You'd think one of them could manage to run him over. The news that global environmental policy is being dictated by the oil multinationals is a fairly terrifying realisation. For socialists and Greens alike it is the rudest awakening since the radio alarm came on just as Frederick Forsyth was doing the Saturday essay on Radio 4.

This is only the beginning. Now we can look forward to having peace talks being chaired by the arms manufacturers, the tobacco companies being put in charge of cancer research and the World Health Organisation being chaired by Ronald McDonald. What is so depressing about Bush's decision is that the rest of the world was asking so little. The Kyoto treaty was far too timid in the first place, but this was because every concession was made to keep the world's greatest polluters on board. Like negotiating with an aggressive drunk in a pub, we could not have been more conciliatory, but the result was always going to be the same;

"You spilt my pint."

"I'm sorry, I don't think I did."

"You calling me a liar?"

"No, of course not, let me buy you another one."

"Why are you trying to pick me up, you poof?"

"No, really; look I'll leave. Why don't I leave the pub altogether?"

"Yeah, all right. Then I can follow you out and smash your face in."

So it is left to the other industrialised nations to save the world from environmental catastrophe. Japan selflessly sent its economy into a nose-dive last week. Russia stopped functioning as a country altogether a few years back. Meanwhile, here in Britain, every effort has been made to prevent global warming. Railtrack have turned off all the radiators in their waiting rooms. The owners of mobile burger vans have been taking care to undercook hamburgers. Car owners have been driving around with rear screen heaters that have several of the wires not working. Barbecues have been left in the garden all winter so they are now filthy, rusty and completely unusable. Despite Bush's selfish actions, in Britain we're doing our bit. Okay, so it's a shame all our efforts have been completely cancelled out by the mass burning of farm animals but you can't have everything.

webTitle: Mark Lawson on the election date

fields.headline: A May poll would be madness
fields.standfirst:
An early election might do for Blair what the poll tax did for Thatcher

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: An early election might do for Blair what the poll tax did for Thatcher.
fields.body:
Whatever qualities Tony Blair has displayed in office, he has never actually seemed mad, a charge routinely levelled against Margaret Thatcher. But a May or even June election now seems to me insanity. What the poll tax was to Thatcher, the poll date would become to Blair. He might continue in office, but his judgment would be suspected ever after; this single decision would become a focus for the doubts about him.

What's most astonishing is that the people reportedly keenest on a May 3 election are the invisible Millbank operatives who run the campaign. This seems largely to be a case of inertia motivation, like someone carrying on with the reception and the honeymoon even though their partner ran screaming from the church before the vows. It would be a fitting epitaph for the age of spin if these types prove to have thrown away power purely because they had booked their holidays in Tuscany for the middle of May.

Oh, I know what they say. The opinion polls remain stable. The media and the public are tiring of sick-cow disease as a story. The farming lands vote Tory or Lib Dem anyway. William Hague wouldn't be electable even if Blair were caught in bed with a troop of boy scouts on May 2. All this may be true. But what these professional campaigners are ignoring is that their biggest problem is the campaign itself and its effect on the prime minister's subsequent image.

Consider first the question of posters and election broadcasts. We can guess what was planned: pictures of Tony grinning amid delighted cancer patients, schoolchildren and investment bankers. Now, if these images run, the public will have in their heads an alternative spool of rural inedible barbecues and army marksmen.

Last Sunday, Rory Bremner ran a sketch in which a Blair speech about how he had changed Britain beyond recognition was intercut with footage of the victims of bovine firing squads. One of the effects of satire is to expose the weak areas in a person and Blair must realise that any triumphalist speech he made would be rendered comic by public knowledge of the reality.

Millbank should also reflect that the Tories, in their posters and commercials, will produce a version of the Bremner sketch. Until six weeks ago, you felt sorry for Conservative copywriters. After four years of presidential-style competence, Blair offered no obvious target for attack. What could Hague's slogan be?

Now the possibilities pile up like massacred cattle. "What Are They So Afraid Of After May?" against pictures of Wall Street screens cascading. Pictures of the farmyards which are now graveyards with the copyline: "Let The Country Decide". Even, perhaps, a split-screen with Margaret Thatcher on one side and a proud Friesian eating grass on the other and a deep voice intoning: "You might have been glad to get rid of this cow but did you really want to get rid of all these?"

Another worry for Labour is Blair's demeanour. Although accused of obsession with presentation, this PM has never been able to spin his emotions. Under pressure, he looks instantly old and ill. The last six weeks have already aged him by two years. Any Kennedyesque campaign planned by his handlers will now look as if it's got George Bush senior in it.

The candidate is also uncomfortable with tough interviews. Earlier this year, it was hard to see how the television and radio interrogations during the campaign could be spun out to half an hour. Now foot and mouth - as a peg for questions on arrogance, competence and fear of the economic future - could fill half an hour alone.

The most intriguing shapes in the white smoke coming out of Labour HQ are suggestions that Blair might distance himself from the campaigning, leaving the chancellor to be Labour's face on the hustings. This scheme has the initial problem of being entirely illogical. If the country is in such crisis that the PM can't campaign, then why is he holding an unnecessary poll anyway?

However, such a strategy would have the benefit of connecting the so far carefully distanced Mr Brown with the government's troubles. It would be him submitting to Paxman's pulled faces, Humphrys's impatient snort and the placards of protesters. This could be a useful precautionary culling of a potential rival if the prime minister were to find himself returned to power but weakened.

The final point that Blair should consider this weekend at Chequers is historical. This column has often referred to the tendency of Britain and America since the 70s to have leaders paired by ideology or circumstance: Callaghan/Ford (unelected); Thatcher/Reagan (charismatic monetarist); and Blair/Clinton (youthful presentationalist). So who's the most fitting twin for George Bush?

Optimistic Conservatives have concluded from these parallels that Britain will now follow America in electing a rightwing half-wit who no one can quite believe got the job. This remains unlikely, but the British system probably is about to produce a political pair for Bush by choosing a leader so undermined by the grubby conditions of his election that he surrenders all political legitimacy.

For the disenfranchisement of Florida, read the theft of electoral rights from the countryside. Though actual defeat may be improbable, a May or June election puts Blair at severe risk of loss of meaning.

webTitle: Europe and the media: Stockholm Euro-summit

fields.headline: Deafening silence on the summit
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Europe and the media: We are nothing if not two-faced. Just as our latest hero emerges and is a Swede, so we treat the serious efforts of his mother country to hold a summit with almost complete disdain.
fields.body:
We are nothing if not two-faced. Just as our latest hero emerges and is a Swede, so we treat the serious efforts of his mother country to hold a summit with almost complete disdain.

There is Sven Goran piling up the World Cup qualifying points for England in the charming and self-effacingly effective way Swedes have, while the British media almost completely ignore the Stockholm Euro-summit. They are very ungrateful.

Sweden, holding the current Euro-presidency, went to a lot of trouble to organise the weekend for EU heads of government. They laid on, apart from a few national dishes, an interesting agenda, including opening up the gas and electricity markets, moves toward a single market in financial services, and attempts to create a Europe-wide patent system.

But somehow none caught the imagination of the British media. For once Eurosceptics and Europhiles were united - in silence.

The Financial Times tried to engender a little excitement ahead of the summit when it said: "Getting European leaders to endorse the Lamfalussy report on creating a single financial services market would be the single most important breakthrough that could emerge from the Stockholm summit." So one turned eagerly to the FT on Monday (Lamfalussy was unlikely to be found in the Mail or Mirror) to find out whether the breakthrough had occurred.

The headline on the FT leader was not promising: "Modest result". However, it was gratifying to read that our prime minister had done his best. "Tony Blair deserves credit for pushing the Lamfalussy committee's strategy for creating a single market in financial services in the next four years," said the FT. "But final agreement depends on the European Commission ending a protracted dispute with the European Parliament over the right to influence draft legislation."

The FT tried hard to find "brighter spots", and came up with the "deal to liberalise postal services by the end of the year."

Tony Blair arrived late in Stockholm and left early, claiming he had a crisis to handle. In between he talked election timing to the commission president. At the same time the best-known Swede in England was at Anfield supervising the defeat of the Finns.

It was all so very different from Nice in November, where the French, as ever, managed to organise a summit full of controversy, and thus press coverage. It is the old Euro-problem: when it deals with the nuts and bolts of trade and economics and the single market it is boring and ignored. When it addresses the vision and sets its sights above trade and towards politics and integration, then the sceptics scream and the philes go quiet.

Radio Five Live tried to engage in the Euro-debate this week. It ran a show called Magnificent Seven which was a cross between the Oxford Union and Big Brother. Seven "ordinary people" with strong political views were assembled in a house in Norwich, where they debated with each other or went out door-knocking and seeking the views of local residents. Each day the listeners kicked out one of them, for being too boring, unpleasant or wrong.

The Magnificent Seven, both with one another and when they were out meeting the public, yet again confirmed the problem of the Euro-debate: "We do not feel sufficiently informed about the issues involved," said one of them.

There were two ominous stories for the Europhiles this week. The Times reported: "A business set up by the head of the Blair-endorsed campaign for membership of the single currency has collapsed with debts of more than £50,000." A company called ThreeSquare, set up by Simon Buckby, had gone into liquidation.

The other story concerned a survey carried out for Time magazine into the attitudes of young (21 to 35) Europeans. "We are British, not European say young," read the Mirror headline."Young Britons out of sync with continental counterparts on EU," said the Guardian.

The survey of Generation Europe found that only 21% of the British sample considered themselves to be more European than British. It is not just middle-aged, middle England, Mail and Telegraph readers who tend to the Eurosceptic. Maybe Sven should be put on the case.

 Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University.

webTitle: Taliban will not sacrifice Bin Laden

fields.headline: Taliban will not sacrifice Bin Laden
fields.trailText: The Taliban's supreme spiritual leader, Mullah Mohammed Omar, has privately ruled out handing over Osama bin Laden for trial and has said he is ready to "sacrifice" what is left of his shattered country before giving up his "guest" to the US, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The Taliban's supreme spiritual leader, Mullah Mohammed Omar, has privately ruled out handing over Osama bin Laden for trial and has said he is ready to "sacrifice" what is left of his shattered country before giving up his "guest" to the US, it emerged last night.

Sources in Kabul made it clear that there was no prospect of the Saudi dissident, accused by the US of carrying out the embassy bombings which killed 224 people in east Africa in 1998, being forced to leave his base in Afghanistan.

The FBI has put Mr Bin Laden near the top of its most wanted list and has offered a $5m (£3.5m) reward for his capture.

It has accused his fundamentalist group, al-Qaeda, of promoting international terrorism and carrying out attacks on US army personnel.

Mr Bin Laden has operated from secret camps in southern and central Afghanistan since 1996.

"Half of my country has been destroyed by two decades of war. If the remaining half is also destroyed in trying to protect Mr Bin Laden, I'm willing for this sacrifice," Mullah Omar said last week.

"He is not going to be handed over if there is any prospect he will be convicted," a Taliban source confirmed.

Last month the Taliban's foreign minister, Wakil Ahmed Mutawakil, indicated that the Taliban might be prepared to hand Mr Bin Laden over to another Muslim country where the evidence against him could be weighed by a panel of Islamic scholars. This proposal, rejected by the US, has now been shelved.

Officially the Taliban say they are still willing to discuss the issue; the new hardline position emerged after a dramatic power struggle in the movement. The "ultra-fundamentalists" who have close links with Mr Bin Laden have consolidated their grip, sources say.

Key moderates who advocated a degree of engagement with the west, including the culture minister, Abdul Rahman Hotaki, have been sacked.

One reliable Taliban source in Kabul said Shaikh Taseer Abdullah - also known as Abu Hafs - who is Mr Bin Laden's deputy and key military aide, was the "mastermind" of al-Qaeda.

"You have to remember that Osama is not educated. All of the key decisions concerning al-Qaeda are taken by the Egyptian [Shaikh Abdullah]," the source said.

Sources said the Taliban were planning to impose further restrictions on foreign-aid workers living in Kabul and other Afghan cities.

"Things are going to get a lot worse before they get better," a one said last night.

"Those within the Taliban who believe Afghanistan should be a laboratory for their puritanical Islamic ideas are firmly in control."

webTitle: Milosevic 'under arrest'

fields.headline: Milosevic 'under arrest'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Serbia
Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic, the indicted war criminal responsible for 10 years of war and bloodshed in the Balkans, was reportedly arrested by Serbian authorities last night, six months after his regime was toppled by a popular uprising on the streets of Belgrade.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic, the indicted war criminal responsible for 10 years of war and bloodshed in the Balkans, was reportedly arrested by Serbian authorities last night, six months after his regime was toppled by a popular uprising on the streets of Belgrade.

Although his associates denied that he had been apprehended, a source close to the Serbian government, as well as western diplomats in Belgrade and Serbian state TV said the former Yugoslav president was taken from his luxury government villa in the Belgrade suburb of Dedinje to the palace of justice in the city centre.

Three jeeps with darkened windows sped into the garage of the palace of justice, past a crowd of cheering onlookers convinced that one of them was carrying Mr Milosevic.

The convoy of jeeps later left again and the ousted president was seen outside the gates of his residence, waving to supporters, soon after midnight.

Later he told B92 radio: "I'm just drinking coffee with my comrades and I'm very well. In front of my house, many have gathered who have our people and national dignity at heart. I expect this story to end in a just manner and for the benefit of our people."

Investigating magistrates were believed to have served two warrants on Mr Milosevic, one for his arrest and another for the search of his premises. It was unclear on what specific charges he had been detained, although he is being investigated for alleged offences from property fraud to war crimes.

Tony Blair said last night the reported arrest was "very welcome". "Milosevic has been a cause of several wars and countless deaths in the last 10 years. He should face justice," the prime minister said.

Last night's denouement to a 13-year era of virtually absolute rule came on the eve of a US deadline for Serbia to cooperate fully with the Yugoslav war crimes tribunal in the Hague or face crippling economic penalties, including a US veto on lending by international financial institutions.

The drama kicked off in the early evening in Belgrade when five vehicles carrying special police in fatigues and black ski masks moved on the government villa where Mr Milosevic had been living with his wife and grandson since last October. An ambulance was also at the scene. Some police vehicles entered the compound, while others remained outside. A senior associate of Mr Milosevic, Zivorad Igic, who said he was in the villa, told a Serbian journalist: "The situation is very stressful. The president is upset."

A tussle between Mr Milosevic's security units and the arriving special police forces was reported as he apparently refused to give himself up. Hundreds of Milosevic loyalists, many armed with steel bars, gathered outside the villa, jeering at journalists.

The reported arrest came as a climax to a power struggle raging within the ranks of the government, pitting the new Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, a legalist who firmly opposes handing over Mr Milosevic to the Hague, against the Serbian government of prime minister Zoran Dzindzic, who is keener to see Mr Milosevic behind bars.

webTitle: Archives lost in arson at ballet company HQ

fields.headline: Archives lost in arson at ballet company HQ
fields.trailText: Arsonists have wrecked the headquarters of one of Britain's leading ballet companies in a blaze which destroyed historic archives and left thousand of pounds' worth of costumes soaked and smoke-damaged.
fields.body:
Arsonists have wrecked the headquarters of one of Britain's leading ballet companies in a blaze which destroyed historic archives and left thousand of pounds' worth of costumes soaked and smoke-damaged.

Petty thieves are suspected of setting alight the former school in Leeds which is housing the Northern Ballet Theatre temporarily until a £6m base in the city's arts quarter is finished in two years. Hundreds of letters - some from past performers, critics and the ballet's late director, Christopher Gable - have been lost, along with contracts and other details for forthcoming productions and tours.

webTitle: Nation of Islam granted appeal on leader's ban

fields.headline: Nation of Islam granted appeal on leader's ban
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: The high court has granted the Nation of Islam permission to challenge a 15-year exclusion order preventing its leader Louis Farrakhan from entering the UK.
fields.body:
The high court has granted the Nation of Islam permission to challenge a 15-year exclusion order preventing its leader Louis Farrakhan from entering the UK.

Mr Farrakhan has described whites as "devils", called Judaism a "gutter" religion and demanded the creation of a separate African-American state in the US. But his supporters - numbering between 500 and 2,000 in this country - argue that the ban contravenes the Human Rights Act.

Sadiq Khan, who will represent the Nation at the judicial review hearing next month, said: "This case raises double standards in allowing in members of the Ku Klux Klan, racist supporters and admirers of Nazi Germany, yet failing to allow in the leader of a vast section of the black community."

Mr Farrakhan has led the US-based group since 1978. He organised Washington's million man march in 1995 and the million family march in October last year.

Hilary Mohammed, the UK representative for the Nation, said: "The Nation of Islam does not promote or endorse anti-semitic views or racial bigotry. Minister Farrakhan is the leader of the Nation of Islam and it is unfair and unjust that we are not allowed to have such a prominent leader come and visit us."

A Home Office spokeswoman would not comment.

It is not clear if Mr Farrakhan, 67, is likely to visit the UK even if the exclusion is overturned. He has faced health problems including prostate cancer in recent years.

webTitle: Ministry 'failed to install' epidemics computer

fields.headline: Ministry 'failed to install' epidemics computer
fields.standfirst:
System could predict outbreaks

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Agriculture has been accused of failing to install a powerful computer system purchased two years ago with the intention of preventing a foot and mouth epidemic.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Agriculture has been accused of failing to install a powerful computer system purchased two years ago with the intention of preventing a foot and mouth epidemic.

Maff officials purchased a computer tracking system known as EpiMan in the late 1990s. The system was designed to predict future cases of foot and mouth in the event of an outbreak of the disease.

But government spending cuts meant funding was switched to BSE and the computer system was instead designated to track BSE.

The system had been developed by Roger Morris, an authority on foot and mouth based at Massey University, New Zealand.

Speaking to Farmers Weekly, Professor Morris claimed that the scheme would have been able to speedily predict the scale of the epidemic. "Undoubtedly fewer cases of the disease would have occurred. We could have damped the disease down much more quickly."

When the foot and mouth crisis broke in February, Maff experts finally decided that the system should be installed.

But they could not work out how to do it. Maff was forced to fly in a team of specialists from New Zealand.

Prof Morris said: "The team from New Zealand took just four days to install the system."

However, Maff denied the accusation, saying that Prof Morris contacted Maff and offered to install his computer system.

Maff officials said that his system was working alongside their own at the ministry's headquarters.

Prof Morris's computer system holds detailed maps of the UK and information on factors influencing the spread of the disease, such as weather and terrain.

He said the system could have raised the alarm earlier in the crisis that Maff alone could not deal with the outbreak.

The news comes on top of the revelation that Maff failed to undergo any exercises on the possibility of a foot and mouth epidemic.

There are increasing signs that the crisis will sound the death knell of Maff in its current form after the election. Stephen Tindale, former special adviser to Michael Meacher, environment minister, has already called for the shutdown of Maff.

Many in Whitehall believe the rural task force chaired by Mr Meacher represents the new ministry of rural affairs in embryo.

The new body would cover not just agriculture, but also the rural community.

webTitle: World sake web

fields.headline: World sake web
fields.standfirst: Momokawa Ruby Sake, 15 per cent volume
fields.trailText: Momokawa Ruby Sake.
fields.body:
Price and stockist £5.99, Waitrose.

What's interesting about this sake? It's made by a Japanese company in Oregon, in the Pacific Northwest, home of Pinot Noirs, micro-brewed beers, boutique brandies and latte. There is an increasing interest in sake on the West Coast, especially in areas of long-established Japanese influence. This sake is classified as a Junmai ginjo. 'Junmai' means that it is made only from rice, with no added alcohol. 'Ginjo' means that each grain has been polished to the extent that at least 40 per cent of the outer part has been removed. This is said to produce more delicate, fragrant characteristics.

What does the sake smell and taste like? Slightly spicy sweet aroma. Gradual development of flavours, with most of the action in the finish. Melon. Lemon. Dried fruit. Sherry.

What does it go with? Salads. Seafood. Oily fish. Cool jazz. Fusion music.

Serving temperature? Lightly chilled.

Will it keep? The fresher it is, the better it will taste. Unopened, it will not mind being kept for a couple of weeks in a cool, dark, place. Once it has been opened, it definitely needs to be in the fridge, and for no more than a further fortnight.

webTitle: Letters:  Another choice

fields.headline: Another choice
fields.trailText: While agreeing with much of Nick Cohen, I do not agree that his claim that the choice will be between three parties whose tax, spending and economic plans are all but identical is correct (Comment, last week).
fields.body:
While agreeing with much of Nick Cohen, I do not agree that his claim that the choice will be between three parties whose tax, spending and economic plans are all but identical is correct (Comment, last week).

While they may not go far enough for Nick, the Liberal Democrats offer a genuine alternative to the Dutch auction offered by the Labour and Conservative parties of keeping taxation low, reducing expenditure on services in real terms and extending privatisation.
Andrew Hudson
London E10

webTitle: Leader: Blair should back have-nots

fields.headline: On the wrong side
fields.standfirst: Mr Blair should be backing the have-nots
fields.trailText: The Blair government tries, constantly, to avoid choosing. Its "third way" was a way of pretending you could have social justice and still eat the cake of globalisation and boundless free enterprise.
fields.body:
The Blair government tries, constantly, to avoid choosing. Its "third way" was a way of pretending you could have social justice and still eat the cake of globalisation and boundless free enterprise.

The government says to business: your profitability is safe with Labour - and it has been. But the Blairites then find themselves compromised when the results of profit-maximisation turn out to be socially pernicious (and the steel industry is eviscerated). One of their worst traits is pretending everything in the garden is lovely when it patently is not.

The British pharmaceutical industry is not just a major employer but a symbol of UK participation in leading-edge science; that is why the drugs barons (to adapt a phrase) will always have entry at No 10, whoever is in residence. But government's interest also lies in buying medicines for the NHS at lowest cost; in the national institute for clinical excellence it now has a tool for assessing their cost-effectiveness.

There is, in other words, a conflict of interests; unavoidable perhaps, but unignorable. Why, then, in his foreword to a major report on the future of this industry just published by the Department of Health, does the prime minister utter not a word about how government must ride different horses?

Mr Blair does have something to say about the supply of branded vs generic medicines to poor countries. He says the status quo rules OK - that South Africa and Brazil have no choice but to accept the regime of intellectual property rights which works to protect the interest of the pharmaceutical biggies. But they do have a choice - if only the UK and other European countries would stir themselves against American definitions.

Our best endeavours ought to go into the pursuit of some alternative trading and research regime. Incentives might be given to laboratories and manufacturers in the west to do research (on the treatment of those diseases, including malaria, which lack the salience of HIV and which we tend to ignore simply because they are non-western in whom they affect).

Merck and SmithKline and the others do not have to have untrammelled access to poor countries' markets for their branded products in order to prosper. Mr Blair should at least have recognised that here is a conflict of interests in which it is shameful for the UK to place itself unequivocally on the side of the haves. But, too much in character, he has not.

webTitle: Comment: US wants isolation from the rest of the world

fields.headline: The cold shoulder
fields.standfirst:
The US wants isolation from the rest of the world - including our weather

Special report: global warming
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The US wants isolation from the rest of the world - including our weather.
fields.body:
It's not that George Bush is ill-informed about the emission of greenhouse gases, but he can't understand why everyone doesn't just go into their greenhouses and close the windows.

"Yup, it's a kinda warm humid gas - smells of tomato plants and bags of fertiliser. But frankly I just don't see it as a threat to the future of the world."

By reneging on the US commitment to the Kyoto treaty on climate change, President Bush has signalled that the US is returning to isolationism, only this time he's decided that the US won't be having anything to do with the rest of the world's weather. Like King Canute, he thinks he is immune from the advancing seas. (Actually Canute was trying to demonstrate the opposite, but back in the 11th century political spin was not so sophisticated as it is today.)

The timing of Bush's announcement seemed to be designed to bring maximum humiliation to the visiting Gerhard Schröder. The German chancellor tried to put a brave face on it; saying that he and Bush had had a pleasant lunch and had found common ground on all issues except one. So they agreed to have sparkling water rather than still, to share the medley of mixed vegetables and croquette potatoes, and the only sticking point was whether the US should honour its agreement to help prevent half the world's population being under water in a few years' time. Well, two out of three's not bad. If they sat in the no smoking section of the restaurant, you can be sure that Dubya puffed on cigars throughout.

Bush was warned that the US oil companies will now have to face the wrath of Green party Euro MPs. Boy, now they're for it. The irony is, of course, that the Greens had it in their power to save the Kyoto treaty. They knew that the environmental breakthrough made by Clinton would not be supported by Bush. But they stood against the Democratic party anyway, and as a direct result of that decision the world's environment will now be affected for the worse. Until we win the fight for proportional representation, the Greens, like everyone else on the left, only serve to help the right when they stand in elections against the Democrats or the Labour party.

Now we will have to wait until the Atlantic Ocean is lapping at the knees of the Statue of Liberty before the US government admits there may possibly be a problem. The oil companies have their man in the White House and are in complete control. Like a driver waiting to fill up his car, Bush can't do anything until the man from the petrol company presses the little button in the kiosk.

George Bush's America has by far the greatest number of car owners in the world. You'd think one of them could manage to run him over. The news that global environmental policy is being dictated by the oil multinationals is a fairly terrifying realisation. For socialists and Greens alike it is the rudest awakening since the radio alarm came on just as Frederick Forsyth was doing the Saturday essay on Radio 4.

This is only the beginning. Now we can look forward to having peace talks being chaired by the arms manufacturers, the tobacco companies being put in charge of cancer research and the World Health Organisation being chaired by Ronald McDonald. What is so depressing about Bush's decision is that the rest of the world was asking so little. The Kyoto treaty was far too timid in the first place, but this was because every concession was made to keep the world's greatest polluters on board. Like negotiating with an aggressive drunk in a pub, we could not have been more conciliatory, but the result was always going to be the same;

"You spilt my pint."

"I'm sorry, I don't think I did."

"You calling me a liar?"

"No, of course not, let me buy you another one."

"Why are you trying to pick me up, you poof?"

"No, really; look I'll leave. Why don't I leave the pub altogether?"

"Yeah, all right. Then I can follow you out and smash your face in."

So it is left to the other industrialised nations to save the world from environmental catastrophe. Japan selflessly sent its economy into a nose-dive last week. Russia stopped functioning as a country altogether a few years back. Meanwhile, here in Britain, every effort has been made to prevent global warming. Railtrack have turned off all the radiators in their waiting rooms. The owners of mobile burger vans have been taking care to undercook hamburgers. Car owners have been driving around with rear screen heaters that have several of the wires not working. Barbecues have been left in the garden all winter so they are now filthy, rusty and completely unusable. Despite Bush's selfish actions, in Britain we're doing our bit. Okay, so it's a shame all our efforts have been completely cancelled out by the mass burning of farm animals but you can't have everything.
