webTitle: Diary: Simon Hoggart

fields.headline: Navy larks
fields.trailText: The other day I went to a formal Royal Navy dinner. I won't go into details because it was a private occasion - we were there through friends - though I can reveal that it was enormous fun.
fields.body:
 The other day I went to a formal Royal Navy dinner. I won't go into details because it was a private occasion - we were there through friends - though I can reveal that it was enormous fun.

One of the people I met was a young woman lieutenant who told me something I never knew before. Her cummerbund had on the front the emblem of her ship and the reverse side consisted of red and white stripes, which she described as "our fighting cummerbund". This is for use when the ship is at war.

It could give vital clues to an enemy. A journalist posing as a correspondent for the Iraqi edition of the Tatler might report sightings of reversed cummerbunds at the MoD. A year or so back, our submarines were famously ordered, in case radio communications were cut, to sur face and tune into the Today programme.

If they didn't hear it for a certain number of days, they were to assume that there was a war on, and Britain possibly destroyed in a nuclear strike.

It's the other side of the world, and dinner time in the mess approaches. Sparks dashes in. "Sorry, sir, it's bin three days now, and I ain't heard Jim Naughtie once."

"Very well," says the skipper. He clears his throat for the gravest announcement he will ever make. "Gentlemen, I must ask you to reverse your cummerbunds."

I suppose at some point some bean counter will decide that we could save money by issuing only non-reversible cummerbunds. And I suppose they will be right. But it will be a sad moment, all the same.

 Michael Cocks, the former Labour chief whip, has just died. He was a rough, tough character, but I always admired him because he loathed Tony Benn. So do many of the people who worked with Benn - Neil Kinnock and Roy Hat tersley for a start. Benn was happy to belong to the Wilson and Callaghan governments of 1974-79, went along with all the miserable compromises, then sniffed the wind and repudiated everything that government had ever done. Of course he claimed that his apostasy represented a lifelong commitment to "values".

By supporting the loony left ("the democracy of the committed" as they called themselves, meaning those who stayed to the end of every meeting and bullied anyone who disagreed with them) he did as much as anyone to keep Margaret Thatcher in power for so long. Now there is a bronze bust of him on show in the Commons, and he is almost universally regarded as a kind, honest, sincere elder statesman.

Actually Mr Benn has always reminded me of Jacques Tati's M Hulot, another tall man with a pipe who created chaos everywhere he went. Except that M Hulot was oblivious to it all, and Mr Benn still sneaks little self-satisfied glances behind himself.

Sometimes two or three unwanted free magazines drop through our door every day. There are supermarket magazines (not catalogues; they contain sort-of articles, such as "Celebrities reveal their favourite beer mats"). My bank sends a magazine. The building society which owns our house has one, as do the people who look after our Tessa. My old university sends a mag. I got a money-off card from a chain of wine bars, and they post a quarterly magazine. So do our gas and electric utilities.

Join a worthy organisation such as the National Trust or the Royal Botanic Gardens, and yet more magazines pour on to your mat. They are all much the same, being full of glossy colour pictures of happy families swinging their children and having picnics. This week we received the first issue of New Wave, published by the local water company. It recommends washing machines of the type which use their water, how to grow a vegetable garden - well irrigated by their splendid product - and suggests cocktails, cooled by ice made from - well, you get the idea.

I don't really see the point. But I do know that all these utterly unwanted magazines employ lots of people, and their incomes join the gross domestic product, thus making us appear, as a nation, even more rich and productive than we really are.

 After my scary encounter with Esther Rantzen a week ago, I keep sighting TV celebrities. I was having a cup of tea in the Commons when in walked Carol Vorderman with a Tory MP, David Lidington. Everyone goggled At lunch in the Ivy, I was at the next table to Chris Tarrant. It was, I thought, a perfect opportunity for a waiter with theatrical ambitions - as I believe many of them have - to make his mark.

Tarrant: "I'm not sure what to choose."

Waiter: "Do you want to ask the audience? Or phone a friend?"

Tarrant: "Ha, ha! I'll have the duck."

Waiter: "Final answer?"

Tarrant: "Yes, the duck _"

Waiter: "But we don't want to give you that!"

Collapse of all concerned. Except that the waiters served him in a perfectly normal way.

 The real problem in this country is no longer the unions, nor the nationalised industries. It's the private monopolies. I wanted to book tickets for a summer concert at Kew. The organisers have handed the sale of all tickets to Ticketmaster, and we were sternly warned that they weren't available from any other source.

I commenced phoning at two-minute intervals for several hours, invariably getting the engaged tone. No queueing system, no automatic call-back allowed. If you want tickets you have to spend hours waiting for them.

For all I know the "hot line" was staffed by one harassed work-experience teenager. But that doesn't bother them. They know the concert will sell out in the end; they also know they'll get an extortionate £1.50 fee for each booking. Why should they give a stuff about our wasted time?

webTitle: Blair sides with drug giants

fields.headline: Blair sides with drug giants
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: The UK has aligned itself firmly on the side of the pharmaceutical industry in the battle over cheap drugs for developing countries, declaring that patents on medicines must be upheld even in poor countries where millions are dying of diseases such as tuberculosis and Aids.
fields.body:
The UK has aligned itself firmly on the side of the pharmaceutical industry in the battle over cheap drugs for developing countries, declaring that patents on medicines must be upheld even in poor countries where millions are dying of diseases such as tuberculosis and Aids.

The government's position is set out in a new report explicitly endorsed by Tony Blair and written by ministers, including the health minister Lord Hunt and science minister Lord Sainsbury, together with the heads of the major drug companies in the UK, including GlaxoSmithKline and Merck. It states categorically: "Intellectual property rights [patents] are the lifeblood of the innovative pharmaceutical industry."

The government and industry say they are "acutely aware of the growing HIV/Aids epidemic in Africa and their responsibilities in responding to it". The report goes on: "There is much that can be done to reduce the impact of Aids and to improve access to medicines. However, intellectual property protection is not per se a barrier to access to medicines and attempts to weaken it would be counter-productive."

The government's uncompromising stance is out of line with the growing mood of concern in other European countries about the unaffordable cost of medicines in poor countries where Aids, tuberculosis and malaria are killing millions. The inequities have been highlighted by a court case brought by 39 drug companies to stop legislation that would allow the South African government to import medicines that are cheaper elsewhere. Two weeks ago, the European parliament called on the drug companies to drop their legal action.

"It does look as if the government is capitulating to big business," said Sophia Tickell, senior policy adviser at Oxfam which is campaigning for access to cheap medicines. "It is very difficult to see any other interpretation. It seems a backward step and out of line with a growing number of other governments."

The report has been published just as Merck, one of the companies involved in the South African case, has threatened legal action against Brazil. Brazil is hailed as a blueprint for the developing world for managing to treat a significant proportion of its HIV-positive population by passing controversial laws to allow it to manufacture cheap copies of eight of the patented drugs used to keep the virus at bay. Since 1997, when it began to make its own versions, hospital admissions for Aids-related illnesses have dropped by 80% and deaths by a half. Brazil has brought the cost of treating patients down from $7,858 a year in 1997 to $4,137. In the US, treatment costs between $10,000 and $15,000.

Merck is now trying to ban Brazil's state-owned pharmaceutical company from importing Efavirenz, an Indian generic version of its drug Stocrin, with a view to making its own copy. A tenth of Brazil's Aids budget is spent on the drug, which is only available at high western prices. Brazil has said it will not make the drug if Merck drops its price significantly.

While United Nations agencies and charities have welcomed the lowering of medicine prices in the developing world which has come about as a result of the recent fierce generic competition and grassroots campaigns in countries such as South Africa, the UK government is now publicly backing the position of the pharmaceutical giants.

The Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry said the government shared its position on patents. "It [the government] recognises the importance of intellectual property rights in the development of new medicines," a spokesman said.

The report is the product of a joint industry/government taskforce set up a year ago after drug companies warned they might take their business elsewhere if the UK clamped down on the price at which they sell medicines to the NHS. It makes clear that the government recognises the threat and wants to do all it can to persuade the industry, which is hugely profitable for Britain, to stay here.

"The UK must continue to offer a supportive and competitive business environment compared to other viable locations," the document says.

The prime minister, in a foreword, says: "I am committed to ensuring that the UK retains the features that have made it an attractive location for investment - features such as the availability of a high quality scientific workforce, protection of intellectual property, a supportive regulatory framework and an environment conducive to the research needed to discover the cures of the 21st century."

 The report can be accessed at www.doh.gov.uk

webTitle: On the trail of Milosevic

fields.headline: Belgrade signals house arrest of fallen strongman
fields.standfirst:
Serbian government makes last-ditch attempts to avoid US financial sanctions

Serbia
Yugoslavia war crimes
fields.trailText: Serbian government makes last-ditch attempts to avoid US financial sanctions.
fields.body:
On the eve of the US deadline for Slobodan Milosevic to be taken into detention, police movements near the former Yugoslav president's home in Belgrade raised speculation in the capital that he was in effect being put under house arrest.

A police van, several other vehicles and an ambulance parked near the villa were taken as an indication that the security units guarding him were being augmented or replaced.

The Serbian parliament went into an unscheduled session and was expected to sit until midnight, increasing the expectations of an announcement about Mr Milosevic, who is under investigation at home for a range of alleged crimes, and has been indicted for war crimes by the Hague tribunal.

The new Serbian government has been facing its sharpest dilemma since taking office in January, in the form of the US ultimatum to arrest Mr Milosevic by today, the deadline set by congress for US aid to be cut off unless Serbia cooperates fully with the tribunal.

More important, its failure to meet the deadline could prompt the US to vote on the governing bodies of the international financial institutions against further aid to Serbia and Yugoslavia, which desperately need foreign funds for reconstruction.

It was unclear last night whether the expected parliamentary announcement and the movement around the Milosevic residence signalled that concrete steps would be traken or were mainly symbolic, undertaken in the hope that Washington would be placated for now.

Western diplomats in the city have suggested in recent days that it could be May before Mr Milosevic is taken into custody.

While senior officials in Belgrade are keen to see Mr Milosevic apprehended, they say they are being pushed too far too fast by the US, and they are pleading for more time to build a watertight legal case against him.

Belgrade's stance has infuriated the Hague war crimes tribunal, which has charged Mr Milosevic and four of his associates with involvement in crimes against humanity in Kosovo and is preparing new charges against him in connection with the wars in Croatia and Bosnia in 1991-95.

But the Americans are not insisting that Mr Milosevic must be extradited immediately to the Hague, rather that he be taken into custody at home and tried in Belgrade.

"There's no one here who does not want Milosevic in prison," said Goran Pitic, the foreign trade minister. "We're totally committed to Milosevic and his associates being sanctioned for what they did. The main thing is to have Milosevic in jail somewhere, and that's the signal the Americans are looking for."

The congressional bill enacted last autumn demands full Serbian cooperation with the Hague tribunal. It does not explicitly say Mr Milosevic has to be arrested, but US officials have told Belgrade that this is what full cooperation means.

As the Serbian media issue a daily diet of revelations about the alleged thuggery and corruption of the former regime, public opinion is also swinging against leaving Mr Milosevic at liberty. Opinion polls show a majority of Serbs now want ing him arrested and a growing minority supporting his extradition to the Hague.

The signals from Washington in recent days suggest that Belgrade is doing enough to avoid the congressional and administration censure.

In the past week the Serbian authorities have arrested eight associates of Mr Milosevic and for the first time ever arrested a Bosnian Serb charged by the tribunal and extradited him to the Hague.

But the arrest and extradition of Vladimir Stakic, a former mayor of the Bosnian town of Prijedor, was apparently done without telling the Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, a democratic Serbian nationalist and fierce critic of the Hague.

The divisions in Belgrade over Mr Milosevic and war crimes were highlighted this week when Mr Kostunica blasted the conduct of the officials and said Mr Stakic's extradition was illegal under Yugoslav law.

Belgrade is promising a new bill on cooperation with the Hague but that could take months to become law. Western officials say Belgrade is dragging things out on purpose.

Referring to Bosnian Serbs, the Yugoslav government has announced that anyone charged with war crimes and not a Yugoslav citizen is now unwelcome in Serbia.

Asked if that meant that the former Bosnian Serb commander Ratko Mladic would be detained if he returned to Belgrade, an official said he took out citizenship in 1993.

webTitle: Britons help anti-Mugabe propaganda

fields.headline: Britons help anti-Mugabe propaganda
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: British and American "well-wishers" have covertly supplied digital cameras, satellite phones and computers to support an attempt by opponents of Robert Mugabe to counter the government propaganda saturating much of Zimbabwe.
fields.body:
British and American "well-wishers" have covertly supplied digital cameras, satellite phones and computers to support an attempt by opponents of Robert Mugabe to counter the government propaganda saturating much of Zimbabwe.

Young black opposition activists and white farmers have been recruited for the operation, due to begin this weekend using a combination of modern technology and mountain bikes.

The aim is to deliver news critical of the regime into rural areas where the ruling Zanu-PF party has in effect banned opposition newspapers and the only source of information is the state-controlled radio.

Topper Whitehead, the white retired mining engineer running the scheme, said the equipment was donated or lent by people "well-wishers".

"There's a lot of well-wishers around. I've had a tremendous response from Britain and the US," he said, but refused to name his sponsors.

A key channel for aid to the opposition is the Zimbabwe Democracy Trust in London, which has been offering Mr Whitehead advice on his scheme. Its patrons include the former Conservative foreign secretaries Douglas Hurd, Malcolm Rifkind and Geoffrey Howe and prominent businessmen with large investments in Zimbabwe.

The British high commission in Harare denies that the UK is officially involved in the operation, but Mr Whitehead has been in regular contact with one of its members, a man regarded by the diplomatic community as an intelligence officer.

The opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) is keeping its distance for the present, in part because Mr Mugabe could exploit such foreign involvement to embarrass his opponents.

Mr Whitehead says the scheme is aimed at breaking the government's grip on propaganda outside the big cities

He intends to publish a daily bulletin, in English and the vernacular, email it to offices, print it out and then redistribute it.

"In some areas it will have to be very clandestine, because of the intimidation," Mr Whitehead said.

While part of the scheme is to deliver news and get the opposition's message in, the distributors will also be trying to bring information out. Mr Whitehead said digital cameras would be used to gather any evidence of intimidation.

In some areas young opposition volunteers are being given mountain bikes and turned into de facto newspaper delivery boys.

Such a strategy is risky, given Zanu-PF's repeated willingness to use violence against its opponents.

In other areas, the scheme will rely on white farmers who can operate satellite equipment discreetly.

"This time last year the commercial farmers went out and backed the MDC fully, and they got a good hiding for it," Mr Whitehead said.

"That is what has forced Mugabe to deploy the war veterans strategically on the farms. This time it has to be a lot quieter."

Asked about the source of the equipment, Mr Whitehead said he had supplied it himself. When it was suggested that the cost might be prohibitive, he said it came as donations and loans from British and American well wishers.

A spokesman for the British high commission, Richard Lindsay, said: "We have been involved in supporting various things - the national constitutional assembly, civic education programmes. But we have not given money to any political parties or opposition activities in Zimbabwe."

Mr Mugabe's government will soon introduce a law banning foreign funding of political activities.

 Harare is prosecuting a factory manager for reportedly making a lewd comment about President Robert Mugabe.

George Potgieter, 23, was charged on Thursday under a 25-year-old Rhodesian law which makes it illegal to insult or bring the president into disrepute.

The law was originally introduced to curb the spread of black nationalism and resistance to white rule.

Asked about the source of the equipment, Mr Whitehead said he had supplied it himself. When it was suggested that the cost might be prohibitive, he said it came as donations and loans from British and American well wishers. A spokesman for the British high commission, Richard Lindsay, said: "We have been involved in supporting various things - the national constitutional assembly, civic education programmes. But we have not given money to any political parties or opposition activities in Zimbabwe." Mr Mugabe's government will soon introduce a law banning foreign funding of political activities.  Harare is prosecuting a factory manager for reportedly making a lewd comment about President Robert Mugabe. George Potgieter, 23, was charged on Thursday under a 25-year-old Rhodesian law which makes it illegal to insult or bring the president into disrepute. The law was originally introduced to curb the spread of black nationalism and resistance to white rule.

webTitle: Ffion Hague profile: The likely one

fields.headline: The likely one
fields.standfirst: She has the intense loyalty, the look, and the unwillingness to voice her own opinions that Tories tend to like in the wife of their leader. But - given the vicissitudes of politics and her own career in the fast track - is not Ffion Hague rather more likely to end up star of her own show than as a consort at No 10?
fields.trailText: She has the intense loyalty, the look, and the unwillingness to voice her own opinions that Tories tend to like in the wife of their leader. But - given the vicissitudes of politics and her own career in the fast track - is not Ffion Hague rather more likely to end up star of her own show than as a consort at No 10?
fields.body:
When William Hague launched the Tories' bid for Downing Street earlier this month with his controversial "journey to a foreign land" speech, there was one young woman in the audience who was particularly attentive. She stood out a mile. A blonde woman, dressed in a black trouser suit, with long straight hair and a toothy smile. She sat bolt upright in the second row of the audience, hands resting demurely on her lap, chin uplifted, eyes front.

This woman looked stylish, modern, professional - yet here she was, at one of the least promising dates in the political calendar, the Conservative Party's Spring Forum in Harrogate. She applauded on cue, she laughed in all the right places, and when the time came, she leapt to her feet for the obligatory standing ovation.

As the applause rippled around the auditorium, the shaven figure on the podium lifted a hand to shield his eyes from the stage lights and searched among the faces below; there he spotted her, summoned her, and led her to the front of the platform. A collective sigh of contentment went up from the floor. It was Ffion, the Tory leader's partner of three years and the perfect political wife - attractive, discreet, supportive and, most vitally of all, mute.

We don't know what Ffion Hague thinks about anything. Not many of us even know what she sounds like, which is a shame because her voice is a delight - deep, dark, smooth, sexy. ("A fantastic phone-sex voice," one political correspondent raved.) Her public life as a political wife is an unilluminating round of Tory fund-raisers and formal engagements, playing second fiddle to her husband, deferring to him, standing behind him, taking care not to upstage. She never does interviews, though she will oblige with the occasional photocall in which she is pictured in an expensive dress next to her husband.

It is where her professional and private lives meet that Ffion Hague becomes interesting, and both are enigmatic. By all accounts, extremely competent, ambitious, directed, at age 33 she is building a very successful career as a high-powered, and highly-paid, head-hunter - by its very nature secretive work, conducted in the shadows, where discretion is paramount. And though her private life is the subject of endless political gossip and speculation, it remains a tantalising mystery why this intelligent, attractive young woman ended up marrying the deeply unpopular, uncharismatic William Hague, whose chosen career in politics hangs in the balance. In 10 or 20 years' time, it may be Ffion looking back on her dazzling career and William who will be perceived to have made a brilliant match.

It is a frustrating business trying to make direct contact with Ffion Hague. She's the sort of woman, I was told, that you'd like as a friend. Someone who had played with her in the National Youth Orchestra of Wales told me the young Ffion Jenkins had always been a bit square, a bit naff, a bit too earnest to be really good fun, but she was someone who "had soul". Which is one of the nicest things you can say about anyone.

So the Guardian put in repeated requests with Conservative central office for an interview - the answer was always no. We asked to be put in touch with friends, family and colleagues - they came up with a couple of names of party and professional colleagues. Family were strictly off limits. We asked to be given a list of her public engagements (she does about 100 a year), but even that wasn't forthcoming. In the end, they told me I could see her at Harrogate, where she would be accompanying William for the weekend, but there would be no chats. I was allowed in purely in the capacity of observer, spy, stalker.

As it was, she was there for less than 24 hours, the majority of which she spent hidden away in her bedroom amid the swirly-patterned carpets of the Moat House Hotel. She swept into town late Saturday afternoon in a white Range Rover and sailed through reception with a lovely smile for the media and nothing else. Later in the evening, she emerged from her suite for a couple of tightly controlled appearances at fringe meetings, and on Sunday she and William dashed for the Range Rover shortly after 10am, returning mysteriously 20 minutes later. No one would tell us where they were going or when they would be back, though it emerged later they'd been for a stroll in a nearby park.

It seemed an extraordinary level of secrecy and paranoia, when a pleasant picture of Ffion and William strolling arm in arm in snowy Yorkshire might have won them a few column inches, if not some votes.

Finally, there was the leader's speech, the climax of the weekend. As the faces of modern conservativism were presented grandly to the audience (the biggest cheer reserved, as always, for Ann Widdecombe) the genuinely modern Mrs Hague slipped in unannounced through a side-door, her entry as carefully stage-managed as her husband's - his for maximum impact, hers for minimum. During the ovation, she stood stiffly alongside him holding his hand, her smile sticking drily to her teeth. Then they walked out, hand in hand like children, exchanging pleasantries with party members, and back to the Range Rover, in which they were whisked away like royalty.

What did it all reveal? That she is fiercely protective of her own privacy; that she is uncomfortable in front of cameras; that she can work a room like she's been doing it all her life - charming everyone she meets, making middle-aged men go weak at the knees; and that, despite her social ease, three years down the line she is still struggling with her role as political wife. And what an unenviable role it is - all that smiling and deferring to your husband. At one meeting in Harrogate, as Hague addressed Conservative Future (a rowdy group formerly known as the Young Conservatives), Ffion stood on the stage like a reluctant beauty queen, two paces behind William's right shoulder. She did not look happy.

It is said that it is Tory central office keeping Ffion reined in. They don't want her doing interviews in case she drops a clanger, or taking centre stage in case she outshines her husband. But everything I heard suggested that it is Ffion who sets the rules for her involvement in the party - no interviews, no speeches, but she will buy an expensive frock and go on William's arm to some dinner.

Is that a triumph for feminism? I don't know. Ffion might have maintained her independence in many ways - she has her own professional life and earns perhaps double what her husband makes - but the role she has assumed of glamorous, silent, supportive, adoring wife is still regarded by many as demeaning. She's unwilling to have a voice or develop an independent public role, but still allows herself to be used as a rather intelligent clothes horse to humanise Hague and make him more attractive to voters. The Tories must therefore have been delighted with a recent survey among students which suggested that 70% of heterosexual males would prefer to have a relationship with Ffion than Cherie Blair. (On the other hand, of the gay men questioned, 80% preferred Blair to Hague - but maybe that's a good thing.)

"She's seen as some sort of Conservative-party glamour figure, whose clothes and hair are worthy of comment as if she was Liz Hurley," says one old friend. "I would imagine that for a girl who had very high credibility in terms of intelligence and work and culture, to be portrayed as some sort of blonde bimbo, whose views have not been sought on anything, is the exact inverse of what she had spent most of her life trying to achieve."

Charlotte Metcalf, who spent months filming the Hagues for her Channel 4 documentary Just William - And Ffion, says Mrs Hague clearly does not feel at ease with this aspect of her role. "You can see as the car arrives at any event, her face starts to change. One of the reasons she doesn't like it, is she resents having to be the smiling wife, as opposed to being a person in her own right. No one is interested in her as Ffion. They are only interested in her as William's wife. I would hate it. Any modern woman would hate it."

And with the general election coming up, the pressure on her to support the party effort has increased. After taking advice from friends and colleagues, she is now very much Mrs Ffion Hague, rather than Ms Jenkins, as she used to be known professionally. It has also been announced that she will accompany her husband around the country during the election campaign - last year it was reported that she intended to stay at her desk at Leonard Hull International, the head-hunting company she works for. "They've worked this out between them," says a friend within the Tory party. "She wants to support him and be with him whenever he needs her, but she's not interested in having a separate political existence. She's much more in the role of Norma Major and Denis Thatcher. Not like Cherie Blair or Hillary Clinton, who have their own political agendas, Ffion sees her role much more as one of support."

David McDonough, director of Bell Pottinger Consultants, who came to know Ffion when she worked for the arts sponsorship organisation Arts & Business between 1997 and February 2000, and has remained a close friend, was one of the two people I was put in touch with by Ffion's advisers. So this clearly is what she wants people to hear.

"Her view of her role in life - whether it's as a head-hunter or as a politician's wife - is, if it helps and pleases William, then it's right. If it does not help and please him, then it's wrong." Which is an interesting statement. Most of us would want to be supportive of our partners, but the idea that something is wrong if it doesn't please or help them seems extreme. McDonough adds: "I've never seen such unvarnished, undiluted old-fashioned loyalty, not of the stupid and slavish kind, but proper, grown-up, stand-by-your-man kind of loyalty."

He's right. Such loyalty, such unquestioning devotion, is not fashionable these days, especially not among intelligent, high-achieving, independent young women such as Ffion. But somehow it fits in with what we know of the young Ffion, an earnest, swotty, decent little girl, who always wanted to do the right thing; a talented child who wanted to please her family and live up to their ambitions.

Even when she was at primary school she took life very seriously indeed. When other girls were kissing boys behind the bike sheds and listening to Wham!, Ffion Jenkins, dressed in folksy long skirt and prissy blouse, was performing at the Eisteddfod or playing clarinet (brilliantly) in the South Glamorgan Youth Orchestra and the National Youth Orchestra of Wales. "Ffion was really quiet, really coy and very, very square. Relentlessly square," says Hannah Griffiths, who played in both orchestras with her. "She was mousy brown and a bit goofy, but she was incredibly genuine. If you were upset because you couldn't get off with the trombone player you fancied, she would be very nice to you. She's a bit prim, but she's all right, Ffion."

The younger of two daughters, Ffion Jenkins grew up in the comfortable Cardiff suburb of Rhiwbina. Her family are at the heart of the Welsh establishment - the crachach, or Taffia, memorably described by Kim Howells MP as "probably the most effective backscratching organisation outside of Sicily". Her father, Emyr, a former TV presenter, director of the Eisteddfod and chief executive of the Arts Council of Wales, is a leading light in the Welsh-speaking cultural elite. Her mother, Myra, was a Welsh tutor and magistrate.

Childhood friends remember Ffion as likeable, hard-working and clever. "She was possibly the most intelligent person in the school," says Richard Grigg, now a prospective parliamentary candidate for Plaid Cymru, who was at Bryntaf primary school with Ffion. "There was never any doubt she was going to do well for herself." From Bryntaf, both Grigg and Ffion went on to Ysgol Gyfun Glantaf, a high-achieving Welsh-speaking comprehensive, where again Ffion was a model pupil. From an early age she was ambitious and serious-minded. In the third form, when her classmates were discussing where to go for a school trip - London or Alton Towers - a straight-faced Ffion suggested a visit to the National Library in Aberystwyth. She left school with three As and a B at A level, plus distinctions in special papers in English and Welsh.

It was at Jesus College, Oxford, where she read English, that she began, for the first time, to enjoy a social life that did not revolve solely around her musical and cultural interests. "She was certainly not a party animal, but in contrast to the goody-goody, swotty image she had before then, she was good fun," says one of her contemporaries. She got involved with the Welsh Society and on one now legendary occasion had to be taken to hospital for stitches in her leg after a drunken incident with a ceremonial sword. The soubriquet Jolly Jenkins came after that - compounded by her later membership of a London-based Welsh society called SWS (the Welsh word for kiss and an acronym for Social Welsh & Sexy), which probably sounds saucier than it is.

She remained independent and self-contained; she sang in the choir, she had a boyfriend, she studied hard (at Oxford, the view was that she was very bright, but not in the superleague), and after her first degree went on to do a postgraduate course at Aberystwyth university, where she wrote her thesis on the 18th-century poet Thomas Gray.

She was - is - an utter perfectionist. She wants to excel; everything she attempts, she does to the best of her ability. In 1991, she joined the fast track of the civil service, where she quickly impressed her bosses, and at the age of 27 became private secretary to the then secretary of state for Wales, John Redwood. She was considered to be so good at her job that she was seen as future permanent secretary material. It was then that she transformed herself from mousy brown to blonde. Her make-over was effective, but not dramatic; look closely at her today - she's attractive, but there's still a slight schoolgirl goofiness about her face, and it's all the more interesting for it.

It wasn't just Ffion who excelled in the Jenkins family. Her older sister, Manon, was a tough act to follow. "There was some competition between them," says an old family friend. Both were talented musically; Manon went to Cambridge, where she subsequently did her PhD; Ffion went to Oxford. Emyr Jenkins, proud of his high-achieving daughters, would say a bit pompously: "Let's put it this way, it doesn't matter in our house who wins the boat race." To his delight, at one stage while Ffion was working for the secretary of state for Wales, Manon was working for the Prince of Wales as his assistant private secretary. Between them they pretty well had Wales sewn up. When Ffion said she was getting married to Redwood's successor at the Welsh Office, Manon reportedly said to her parents, "Oh well, that's the end of sibling rivalry." The story of Ffion and William's courtship tells you something about both of them.

It began with a gorgeous day in the hot summer of 1995, on the wall of a churchyard in the shadow of Snowdonia. They were on a tour of Wales, it was just starting to get dark, and for two hours Ffion sang the Welsh national anthem to him, over and over and over again in order to avoid him suffering the embarrassment Redwood had experienced by not knowing the words. It took Hague a year to ask her out; they conducted their relationship in secret and within four months, to many people's surprise, they were engaged.

There's an entertaining story about how Hague hosted a drinks party at the Welsh Office before their relationship was public knowledge. At the end of it, Ffion was naturally keen to find out what friends of hers attending the party thought of him. They told her they liked him very much, particularly one gay friend, who confided: "He's obviously batting from my side." Shortly afterwards, the engagement was announced, much to the friend's embarrassment. Ffion took a sabbatical; she never returned to the civil service but made a career change, pursuing her passion for the arts as a director of Arts & Business. And the couple got married.

Kate Jennings, Ffion's boss at the Welsh Office, offered an insight shortly before the marriage: "I can say candidly that she is ambitious as well as clever. She is not a naive girl who has been swept off her feet. I don't believe this was a passionate affair. They like each other, but it would be a bit much to describe their relationship as a great love match.

"Ffion is charming, a very nice woman - extremely capable and not to be underestimated. Her political judgment was not particularly developed at the Welsh Office. Even so, she did not strike me as a natural Tory. She's a Blairite more than anything else. England offers her more than Wales did, and marriage to William Hague offers even more. She finds this terribly exciting."

It's hardly the stuff of great romance, but neither are many other marriages. Nevertheless, the relationship has been dogged by rumour and speculation. It's not helped by Ffion's obsessive privacy and the spinning that goes on, the anecdotes about Ffion and William, wrapped around each other in a smoky corner of a London jazz club; passionate kisses in the gardens surrounding their Dolphin Square flat, around which - journalists are told repeatedly - they pad barefoot, glasses of red wine in hand, laughing ceaselessly. It may all be true, but to those with suspicious minds it all sounds a little staged.

Yet everyone I spoke to who had some degree of intimacy with the Hagues testified to the genuineness of the relationship. Those who did not know them well were the ones who voiced doubts. Metcalf, who spent months filming them, was convinced by what she saw. "She thinks he has the most fantastic brain. They are very, very similar. They have a very similar sense of humour. They have very similar interests. They are real soul mates. All the time we were filming, they could not wait to see each other. They're quite touchy-feely. Always, in the back of the car, they were giggling and whispering. I think they're like brother and sister. They just really, really like each other." The brother-sister analogy was echoed by others who have seen them from close quarters. Another one-time friend of the couple said: "The relationship I witnessed was a full-on, affectionate, jealous relationship. She was jealous of the people who reduced the amount of time she spent with her husband."

Unlike most senior political figures, Hague sets aside Sundays to spend with his wife at their home in Catterick, north Yorkshire, and no one is allowed to interrupt that time without very good reason. They try to spend as many evenings a week together as possible, they take more holidays than most - they travel to America at least once a year and have recently discovered Spain. Another journalist unexpectedly came across them in an otherwise deserted hotel in the Brecon Beacons where they were weekending - they looked engrossed, involved, deep in conversation.

"Whatever one says about this marriage - that it's a kind of show marriage, or cover for other things - they really do seek out a lot of time to be together," says Metcalf. "If it was a show marriage, there wouldn't be any need to be going off constantly for weekends in Spain or to Yorkshire." On one occasion, Metcalf recalls Ffion spending eight hours travelling to Yorkshire just to spend a single day with him.

Filming was a tricky business - interestingly, it was Ffion who did all the negotiating, not William. "There were so many rules. At the beginning there was no way she was going to be in it at all. It was a matter of slowly, slowly, slowly convincing her to do it. She did not want any filming of her on her own. If you overstep the line, she can be very frosty. She's very calm about it. Quite icy."

In one hilarious scene, the Hagues were filmed on a country walk dressed in identical hiking gear. "I came down from my hotel room and there were Pinky and Perky with their walking sticks. Part of you wants to weep, but it's really sweet in another way." And there was an extraordinary moment when Metcalf asked Ffion whether it had been love at first sight. "It seemed to me an absolutely anodyne question," says Metcalf. "But she really, really resented it." Plainly taken aback, Ffion replied frostily: "You can't ask questions like that." Hague tried to placate her, patting her affectionately on the knee but it was hard for them to disguise how upset she was by the intrusion. "She did look a little ill at ease and a bit cross on occasions during the film," agrees McDonough. "There were awkward moments. She will not discuss her private life. She's frankly too private and too dignified a person to want to go into all that."

But not too dignified to play along with an ill-conceived Tory central office stunt in July 1999 involving a £1,500 diamond-encrusted pendant in the shape of a pound sign. It was supposed to be a gift from a husband to his wife - but was exposed as a crass attempt to exploit William and Ffion's relationship to improve his public image, while simultaneously using her as a walking advertisement for his campaign to keep the pound ahead of the European elections. The pendant was commissioned by the head of the Conservative media unit and Hague's chief spindoctor, Amanda Platell - who is also a friend of Ffion. Platell even had to pay for the pendant after the jeweller complained the bill had not been settled and the romantic Mr Hague had to pay her back. Not nice. The debacle did little to subdue speculation that the marriage was less a love match than one of political expediency.

Ffion's friends play down the incident. "She still wears it," one girlfriend told me. "She says people are disappointed if she doesn't get it out occasionally. In any case, she ended up with some very nice diamonds." But it's hard to imagine Ffion dismissing such a tawdry little mess so easily. This is someone who takes herself and her image very seriously. She will know how damaging such publicity can be - not just for William and the Tory party but for her, too. Professionally, she has a lot to lose - she will not want her career prospects damaged by the ineptitude of either her husband or the Tories' media machine.

Similarly, two years earlier, at the Tory party conference, she came a cropper when over-excited spindoctors briefed the media that the then Ms Jenkins would be wearing a stunning, diaphanous dress by a top designer. The waiting press corps were expecting something akin to that Liz Hurley safety-pin moment; instead, Ffion appeared in a nice, but rather ordinary, black lace dress which led to unflattering observations about her figure. It wasn't the dress that was the mistake, it was the spinning - without it, photographers would have taken some pictures of Mr Hague's fiance and would have left quite happy.

That seems to have been a turning point for Ffion in her role as wife of the leader of the opposition. Stung by the personal criticisms, she seemed to disappear from public view, re-emerging with much greater control of her image. If she makes mistakes, she wants to make her own. "She certainly does have a good angle on the press and how she wants to control the people around her," said one former friend. "She's slightly prima donna-ish about the way her image is preserved, in the way you imagine Princess Diana to have been. She almost cultivates that not-being-seen image. It's probably quite well thought out. She wants to create a mystique."

The same acquaintance, who did not want to be named, also alluded to Ffion's influence over Hague. "It was always made clear that in order to get things past William you kind of had to have a passport from her. If you were trying to convert William to think about things, you had to be acceptable to her."

The female "power-behind-the-throne" theory is seductive, but unlike Hillary and Cherie, Ffion is not a political animal. She may have been involved in Operation Hague to overhaul her husband's fuddy-duddy image, but she has no political record of her own; she was never involved in student politics (which at the time of their engagement was seen by senior party officials as a stroke of luck), and you can't imagine her discussing with her husband into the wee small hours the finer points of the Tories' health policy.

It's hard to imagine what they discuss at all, but just by virtue of her background and Welshness, it's easy to see there may be political differences - for example, Hague opposed devolution, which she must have been bound to support. Contemporaries who were with her at Oxford find it hard to believe that the liberal-minded undergraduate they knew feels comfortable with some of the more extreme views of the modern Tory party and its leader. And a couple of sources suggested that at one time Ffion considered becoming a Liberal Democrat. "It's complete rubbish," a close friend said. "It was a friend who approached her. She considered it out of courtesy. But her instincts are very much like William's. She's a small c conservative. Her instincts are Tory."

What of the future? What of Ffion and William if the Tories are crushed at the election; what happens if Hague fails to eat into Blair's majority in any convincing way and is ousted in a leadership battle? "There are people who don't think she'll stick with him after the election," said one friend from Cardiff.

"I think there's more to the relationship than the chance of a ticket to number 10." So do I. Professionally the clever Mrs Hague has been planning ahead. She has already had two successful careers, in the civil service and the world of arts and business sponsorship. She is now on to her third as a head-hunter, is earning mega-bucks (reportedly anything up to £250,000 a year) and is said to be thriving. It is in her work that her talent for organisation, her decisiveness, her charm person-to person, are most effective; it is the public performer aspects of political life that suit her less well. "She's found a new spring in her step and a new confidence and certainty about herself," says her friend McDonough. And it isn't just something she has stumbled into as a career - every step Ffion Hague takes, whether it's professionally or personally, is carefully considered. You can count on it. "She's quite a serious and thoughtful person who would look at her own career development and personal growth quite intensely, more intensely than a lot of people might. The steps she has taken have been part of a quite carefully thought out progression," says McDonough.

Politically, however, the future is grim for the Hagues. She can only hope that her own stock is not damaged by her husband's fate at the polls. "She must have taken a fairly realistic look at what's likely to happen," saysMcDonough. "She's mature enough and confident enough, both in herself and in her relationship with William to be quite philosophical about the changing fortunes of politics. It might reduce the extent of her public profile, but I think she would probably be quite relieved to be able to get on with her own life without people looking at where she bought her last dress or suit or whatever." And presumably she won't miss the weekly call by lobby correspondents enquiring whether she is pregnant yet."

Whatever happens to William, Ffion Hague's future looks bright, but then it always did - long before that late summer's evening, in the foothills of Snowdonia, singing to the young politician who looked set for stardom. At the time of their engagement, it might have looked as if the ambitious, young civil servant from Cardiff was bettering herself. These days, it's the other way round and William Hague will be desperately hoping that his wife's golden touch might rub off on him.

As the faces of modern conservativism were presented grandly to the audience (the biggest cheer reserved, as always, for Ann Widdecombe) the genuinely modern Mrs Hague slipped in unannounced through a side-door, her entry as carefully stage-managed as her husband's - his for maximum impact, hers for minimum. During the ovation, she stood stiffly alongside him holding his hand, her smile sticking drily to her teeth. Then they walked out, hand in hand like children, exchanging pleasantries with party members, and back to the Range Rover, in which they were whisked away like royalty. What did it all reveal? That she is fiercely protective of her own privacy; that she is uncomfortable in front of cameras; that she can work a room like she's been doing it all her life - charming everyone she meets, making middle-aged men go weak at the knees; and that, despite her social ease, three years down the line she is still struggling with her role as political wife. And what an unenviable role it is - all that smiling and deferring to your husband. At one meeting in Harrogate, as Hague addressed Conservative Future (a rowdy group formerly known as the Young Conservatives), Ffion stood on the stage like a reluctant beauty queen, two paces behind William's right shoulder. She did not look happy. It is said that it is Tory central office keeping Ffion reined in. They don't want her doing interviews in case she drops a clanger, or taking centre stage in case she outshines her husband. But everything I heard suggested that it is Ffion who sets the rules for her involvement in the party - no interviews, no speeches, but she will buy an expensive frock and go on William's arm to some dinner. Is that a triumph for feminism? I don't know. Ffion might have maintained her independence in many ways - she has her own professional life and earns perhaps double what her husband makes - but the role she has assumed of glamorous, silent, supportive, adoring wife is still regarded by many as demeaning. She's unwilling to have a voice or develop an independent public role, but still allows herself to be used as a rather intelligent clothes horse to humanise Hague and make him more attractive to voters. The Tories must therefore have been delighted with a recent survey among students which suggested that 70% of heterosexual males would prefer to have a relationship with Ffion than Cherie Blair. (On the other hand, of the gay men questioned, 80% preferred Blair to Hague - but maybe that's a good thing.) "She's seen as some sort of Conservative-party glamour figure, whose clothes and hair are worthy of comment as if she was Liz Hurley," says one old friend. "I would imagine that for a girl who had very high credibility in terms of intelligence and work and culture, to be portrayed as some sort of blonde bimbo, whose views have not been sought on anything, is the exact inverse of what she had spent most of her life trying to achieve." Charlotte Metcalf, who spent months filming the Hagues for her Channel 4 documentary Just William - And Ffion, says Mrs Hague clearly does not feel at ease with this aspect of her role. "You can see as the car arrives at any event, her face starts to change. One of the reasons she doesn't like it, is she resents having to be the smiling wife, as opposed to being a person in her own right. No one is interested in her as Ffion. They are only interested in her as William's wife. I would hate it. Any modern woman would hate it." And with the general election coming up, the pressure on her to support the party effort has increased. After taking advice from friends and colleagues, she is now very much Mrs Ffion Hague, rather than Ms Jenkins, as she used to be known professionally. It has also been announced that she will accompany her husband around the country during the election campaign - last year it was reported that she intended to stay at her desk at Leonard Hull International, the head-hunting company she works for. "They've worked this out between them," says a friend within the Tory party. "She wants to support him and be with him whenever he needs her, but she's not interested in having a separate political existence. She's much more in the role of Norma Major and Denis Thatcher. Not like Cherie Blair or Hillary Clinton, who have their own political agendas, Ffion sees her role much more as one of support." David McDonough, director of Bell Pottinger Consultants, who came to know Ffion when she worked for the arts sponsorship organisation Arts & Business between 1997 and February 2000, and has remained a close friend, was one of the two people I was put in touch with by Ffion's advisers. So this clearly is what she wants people to hear. "Her view of her role in life - whether it's as a head-hunter or as a politician's wife - is, if it helps and pleases William, then it's right. If it does not help and please him, then it's wrong." Which is an interesting statement. Most of us would want to be supportive of our partners, but the idea that something is wrong if it doesn't please or help them seems extreme. McDonough adds: "I've never seen such unvarnished, undiluted old-fashioned loyalty, not of the stupid and slavish kind, but proper, grown-up, stand-by-your-man kind of loyalty." He's right. Such loyalty, such unquestioning devotion, is not fashionable these days, especially not among intelligent, high-achieving, independent young women such as Ffion. But somehow it fits in with what we know of the young Ffion, an earnest, swotty, decent little girl, who always wanted to do the right thing; a talented child who wanted to please her family and live up to their ambitions. Even when she was at primary school she took life very seriously indeed. When other girls were kissing boys behind the bike sheds and listening to Wham!, Ffion Jenkins, dressed in folksy long skirt and prissy blouse, was performing at the Eisteddfod or playing clarinet (brilliantly) in the South Glamorgan Youth Orchestra and the National Youth Orchestra of Wales. "Ffion was really quiet, really coy and very, very square. Relentlessly square," says Hannah Griffiths, who played in both orchestras with her. "She was mousy brown and a bit goofy, but she was incredibly genuine. If you were upset because you couldn't get off with the trombone player you fancied, she would be very nice to you. She's a bit prim, but she's all right, Ffion." The younger of two daughters, Ffion Jenkins grew up in the comfortable Cardiff suburb of Rhiwbina. Her family are at the heart of the Welsh establishment - the crachach, or Taffia, memorably described by Kim Howells MP as "probably the most effective backscratching organisation outside of Sicily". Her father, Emyr, a former TV presenter, director of the Eisteddfod and chief executive of the Arts Council of Wales, is a leading light in the Welsh-speaking cultural elite. Her mother, Myra, was a Welsh tutor and magistrate. Childhood friends remember Ffion as likeable, hard-working and clever. "She was possibly the most intelligent person in the school," says Richard Grigg, now a prospective parliamentary candidate for Plaid Cymru, who was at Bryntaf primary school with Ffion. "There was never any doubt she was going to do well for herself." From Bryntaf, both Grigg and Ffion went on to Ysgol Gyfun Glantaf, a high-achieving Welsh-speaking comprehensive, where again Ffion was a model pupil. From an early age she was ambitious and serious-minded. In the third form, when her classmates were discussing where to go for a school trip - London or Alton Towers - a straight-faced Ffion suggested a visit to the National Library in Aberystwyth. She left school with three As and a B at A level, plus distinctions in special papers in English and Welsh. It was at Jesus College, Oxford, where she read English, that she began, for the first time, to enjoy a social life that did not revolve solely around her musical and cultural interests. "She was certainly not a party animal, but in contrast to the goody-goody, swotty image she had before then, she was good fun," says one of her contemporaries. She got involved with the Welsh Society and on one now legendary occasion had to be taken to hospital for stitches in her leg after a drunken incident with a ceremonial sword. The soubriquet Jolly Jenkins came after that - compounded by her later membership of a London-based Welsh society called SWS (the Welsh word for kiss and an acronym for Social Welsh & Sexy), which probably sounds saucier than it is. She remained independent and self-contained; she sang in the choir, she had a boyfriend, she studied hard (at Oxford, the view was that she was very bright, but not in the superleague), and after her first degree went on to do a postgraduate course at Aberystwyth university, where she wrote her thesis on the 18th-century poet Thomas Gray. She was - is - an utter perfectionist. She wants to excel; everything she attempts, she does to the best of her ability. In 1991, she joined the fast track of the civil service, where she quickly impressed her bosses, and at the age of 27 became private secretary to the then secretary of state for Wales, John Redwood. She was considered to be so good at her job that she was seen as future permanent secretary material. It was then that she transformed herself from mousy brown to blonde. Her make-over was effective, but not dramatic; look closely at her today - she's attractive, but there's still a slight schoolgirl goofiness about her face, and it's all the more interesting for it. It wasn't just Ffion who excelled in the Jenkins family. Her older sister, Manon, was a tough act to follow. "There was some competition between them," says an old family friend. Both were talented musically; Manon went to Cambridge, where she subsequently did her PhD; Ffion went to Oxford. Emyr Jenkins, proud of his high-achieving daughters, would say a bit pompously: "Let's put it this way, it doesn't matter in our house who wins the boat race." To his delight, at one stage while Ffion was working for the secretary of state for Wales, Manon was working for the Prince of Wales as his assistant private secretary. Between them they pretty well had Wales sewn up. When Ffion said she was getting married to Redwood's successor at the Welsh Office, Manon reportedly said to her parents, "Oh well, that's the end of sibling rivalry." The story of Ffion and William's courtship tells you something about both of them. It began with a gorgeous day in the hot summer of 1995, on the wall of a churchyard in the shadow of Snowdonia. They were on a tour of Wales, it was just starting to get dark, and for two hours Ffion sang the Welsh national anthem to him, over and over and over again in order to avoid him suffering the embarrassment Redwood had experienced by not knowing the words. It took Hague a year to ask her out; they conducted their relationship in secret and within four months, to many people's surprise, they were engaged. There's an entertaining story about how Hague hosted a drinks party at the Welsh Office before their relationship was public knowledge. At the end of it, Ffion was naturally keen to find out what friends of hers attending the party thought of him. They told her they liked him very much, particularly one gay friend, who confided: "He's obviously batting from my side." Shortly afterwards, the engagement was announced, much to the friend's embarrassment. Ffion took a sabbatical; she never returned to the civil service but made a career change, pursuing her passion for the arts as a director of Arts & Business. And the couple got married. Kate Jennings, Ffion's boss at the Welsh Office, offered an insight shortly before the marriage: "I can say candidly that she is ambitious as well as clever. She is not a naive girl who has been swept off her feet. I don't believe this was a passionate affair. They like each other, but it would be a bit much to describe their relationship as a great love match. "Ffion is charming, a very nice woman - extremely capable and not to be underestimated. Her political judgment was not particularly developed at the Welsh Office. Even so, she did not strike me as a natural Tory. She's a Blairite more than anything else. England offers her more than Wales did, and marriage to William Hague offers even more. She finds this terribly exciting." It's hardly the stuff of great romance, but neither are many other marriages. Nevertheless, the relationship has been dogged by rumour and speculation. It's not helped by Ffion's obsessive privacy and the spinning that goes on, the anecdotes about Ffion and William, wrapped around each other in a smoky corner of a London jazz club; passionate kisses in the gardens surrounding their Dolphin Square flat, around which - journalists are told repeatedly - they pad barefoot, glasses of red wine in hand, laughing ceaselessly. It may all be true, but to those with suspicious minds it all sounds a little staged. Yet everyone I spoke to who had some degree of intimacy with the Hagues testified to the genuineness of the relationship. Those who did not know them well were the ones who voiced doubts. Metcalf, who spent months filming them, was convinced by what she saw. "She thinks he has the most fantastic brain. They are very, very similar. They have a very similar sense of humour. They have very similar interests. They are real soul mates. All the time we were filming, they could not wait to see each other. They're quite touchy-feely. Always, in the back of the car, they were giggling and whispering. I think they're like brother and sister. They just really, really like each other." The brother-sister analogy was echoed by others who have seen them from close quarters. Another one-time friend of the couple said: "The relationship I witnessed was a full-on, affectionate, jealous relationship. She was jealous of the people who reduced the amount of time she spent with her husband." Unlike most senior political figures, Hague sets aside Sundays to spend with his wife at their home in Catterick, north Yorkshire, and no one is allowed to interrupt that time without very good reason. They try to spend as many evenings a week together as possible, they take more holidays than most - they travel to America at least once a year and have recently discovered Spain. Another journalist unexpectedly came across them in an otherwise deserted hotel in the Brecon Beacons where they were weekending - they looked engrossed, involved, deep in conversation. "Whatever one says about this marriage - that it's a kind of show marriage, or cover for other things - they really do seek out a lot of time to be together," says Metcalf. "If it was a show marriage, there wouldn't be any need to be going off constantly for weekends in Spain or to Yorkshire." On one occasion, Metcalf recalls Ffion spending eight hours travelling to Yorkshire just to spend a single day with him. Filming was a tricky business - interestingly, it was Ffion who did all the negotiating, not William. "There were so many rules. At the beginning there was no way she was going to be in it at all. It was a matter of slowly, slowly, slowly convincing her to do it. She did not want any filming of her on her own. If you overstep the line, she can be very frosty. She's very calm about it. Quite icy." In one hilarious scene, the Hagues were filmed on a country walk dressed in identical hiking gear. "I came down from my hotel room and there were Pinky and Perky with their walking sticks. Part of you wants to weep, but it's really sweet in another way." And there was an extraordinary moment when Metcalf asked Ffion whether it had been love at first sight. "It seemed to me an absolutely anodyne question," says Metcalf. "But she really, really resented it." Plainly taken aback, Ffion replied frostily: "You can't ask questions like that." Hague tried to placate her, patting her affectionately on the knee but it was hard for them to disguise how upset she was by the intrusion. "She did look a little ill at ease and a bit cross on occasions during the film," agrees McDonough. "There were awkward moments. She will not discuss her private life. She's frankly too private and too dignified a person to want to go into all that." But not too dignified to play along with an ill-conceived Tory central office stunt in July 1999 involving a £1,500 diamond-encrusted pendant in the shape of a pound sign. It was supposed to be a gift from a husband to his wife - but was exposed as a crass attempt to exploit William and Ffion's relationship to improve his public image, while simultaneously using her as a walking advertisement for his campaign to keep the pound ahead of the European elections. The pendant was commissioned by the head of the Conservative media unit and Hague's chief spindoctor, Amanda Platell - who is also a friend of Ffion. Platell even had to pay for the pendant after the jeweller complained the bill had not been settled and the romantic Mr Hague had to pay her back. Not nice. The debacle did little to subdue speculation that the marriage was less a love match than one of political expediency. Ffion's friends play down the incident. "She still wears it," one girlfriend told me. "She says people are disappointed if she doesn't get it out occasionally. In any case, she ended up with some very nice diamonds." But it's hard to imagine Ffion dismissing such a tawdry little mess so easily. This is someone who takes herself and her image very seriously. She will know how damaging such publicity can be - not just for William and the Tory party but for her, too. Professionally, she has a lot to lose - she will not want her career prospects damaged by the ineptitude of either her husband or the Tories' media machine. Similarly, two years earlier, at the Tory party conference, she came a cropper when over-excited spindoctors briefed the media that the then Ms Jenkins would be wearing a stunning, diaphanous dress by a top designer. The waiting press corps were expecting something akin to that Liz Hurley safety-pin moment; instead, Ffion appeared in a nice, but rather ordinary, black lace dress which led to unflattering observations about her figure. It wasn't the dress that was the mistake, it was the spinning - without it, photographers would have taken some pictures of Mr Hague's fiance and would have left quite happy. That seems to have been a turning point for Ffion in her role as wife of the leader of the opposition. Stung by the personal criticisms, she seemed to disappear from public view, re-emerging with much greater control of her image. If she makes mistakes, she wants to make her own. "She certainly does have a good angle on the press and how she wants to control the people around her," said one former friend. "She's slightly prima donna-ish about the way her image is preserved, in the way you imagine Princess Diana to have been. She almost cultivates that not-being-seen image. It's probably quite well thought out. She wants to create a mystique." The same acquaintance, who did not want to be named, also alluded to Ffion's influence over Hague. "It was always made clear that in order to get things past William you kind of had to have a passport from her. If you were trying to convert William to think about things, you had to be acceptable to her." The female "power-behind-the-throne" theory is seductive, but unlike Hillary and Cherie, Ffion is not a political animal. She may have been involved in Operation Hague to overhaul her husband's fuddy-duddy image, but she has no political record of her own; she was never involved in student politics (which at the time of their engagement was seen by senior party officials as a stroke of luck), and you can't imagine her discussing with her husband into the wee small hours the finer points of the Tories' health policy. It's hard to imagine what they discuss at all, but just by virtue of her background and Welshness, it's easy to see there may be political differences - for example, Hague opposed devolution, which she must have been bound to support. Contemporaries who were with her at Oxford find it hard to believe that the liberal-minded undergraduate they knew feels comfortable with some of the more extreme views of the modern Tory party and its leader. And a couple of sources suggested that at one time Ffion considered becoming a Liberal Democrat. "It's complete rubbish," a close friend said. "It was a friend who approached her. She considered it out of courtesy. But her instincts are very much like William's. She's a small c conservative. Her instincts are Tory." What of the future? What of Ffion and William if the Tories are crushed at the election; what happens if Hague fails to eat into Blair's majority in any convincing way and is ousted in a leadership battle? "There are people who don't think she'll stick with him after the election," said one friend from Cardiff. "I think there's more to the relationship than the chance of a ticket to number 10." So do I. Professionally the clever Mrs Hague has been planning ahead. She has already had two successful careers, in the civil service and the world of arts and business sponsorship. She is now on to her third as a head-hunter, is earning mega-bucks (reportedly anything up to £250,000 a year) and is said to be thriving. It is in her work that her talent for organisation, her decisiveness, her charm person-to person, are most effective; it is the public performer aspects of political life that suit her less well. "She's found a new spring in her step and a new confidence and certainty about herself," says her friend McDonough. And it isn't just something she has stumbled into as a career - every step Ffion Hague takes, whether it's professionally or personally, is carefully considered. You can count on it. "She's quite a serious and thoughtful person who would look at her own career development and personal growth quite intensely, more intensely than a lot of people might. The steps she has taken have been part of a quite carefully thought out progression," says McDonough. Politically, however, the future is grim for the Hagues. She can only hope that her own stock is not damaged by her husband's fate at the polls. "She must have taken a fairly realistic look at what's likely to happen," saysMcDonough. "She's mature enough and confident enough, both in herself and in her relationship with William to be quite philosophical about the changing fortunes of politics. It might reduce the extent of her public profile, but I think she would probably be quite relieved to be able to get on with her own life without people looking at where she bought her last dress or suit or whatever." And presumably she won't miss the weekly call by lobby correspondents enquiring whether she is pregnant yet." Whatever happens to William, Ffion Hague's future looks bright, but then it always did - long before that late summer's evening, in the foothills of Snowdonia, singing to the young politician who looked set for stardom. At the time of their engagement, it might have looked as if the ambitious, young civil servant from Cardiff was bettering herself. These days, it's the other way round and William Hague will be desperately hoping that his wife's golden touch might rub off on him.

webTitle: Hard drug seizures fall below target

fields.headline: Hard drug seizures fall below target, but more offenders are jailed
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Police and customs have fallen well short of a government target set to tackle the trade in hard drugs, official figures revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Police and customs have fallen well short of a government target set to tackle the trade in hard drugs, official figures revealed yesterday.

Seizures of class A drugs such as ecstasy, heroin and cocaine rose only by 4.3% in 1999 compared with the previous year to just over 30,000. The target set by the government as part of its much-trumpeted 10-year strategy was 10%.

The Home Office bulletin said customs officers seized only 59.4 tonnes of illegal drugs in 1999 compared with 88.3 tonnes the previous year. At the same time, the street price of cocaine and heroin fell substantially, suggesting the drugs were becoming more readily available. The drugs were also found to be increasingly pure.

There was some success. Ecstasy seizures rose by a third to 6,400, and the number of people dealt with for supply offences involving class A drugs rose by 17.5% against the 10% target. But the fall in seizures of class A drugs is a concern. A Home Office spokeswoman said that while the government was pleased with the results, some areas needed work.

The bulletin notes that in 1998 the number of drugs seizures increased by 9%. But in 1999 the figure was down by 13% to 132,000. The overall fall, the report says, could be down to the reduction in seizures involving class B drugs, especially cannabis and amphetamines, which is in line with government policy to concentrate resources on class A substances.

Another possible factor for the decrease in seizures of cannabis and amphetamines is the fall in the number of stop and searches following the publication in February 1999 of the MacPherson report on the investigation of the murder of Stephen Lawrence.

The report says the trend to import "cocktail consignments" - several different types of drugs - continued. Customs officers discovered most heroin was imported via the Balkans by Anglo-Turkish gangs. New routes for cocaine had opened in South America but Eastern Europe and the Balkans continued to be used as transit zones. However, customs succeeded in "dismantling or significantly disrupting" the activities of 138 organisations involved in smuggling class A drugs. This compared with 116 in the previous 12 months.

The report reveals that the number of seizures of heroin and crack fell by 0.5% and 2% respectively. Seizures of cocaine rose by 8%. Nevertheless the street prices of both cocaine and heroin fell per gram, the former from £77 to £63 and the latter from £74 to £65.

A tougher approach to drugs offenders in the courts is highlighted. The number of immediate custodial sentences given to offenders in 1999 was 11,380, a rise of 3% and a new record. There was an increase of 15% to 1,100 in the number of women sentenced to immediate custody. In June 1999, there were 8,150 people in jail for drug offences, an increase of 3% on the previous year.

Home office minister Charles Clarke claimed that the statistics showed that enforcement was working in line with the government's drug strategy.

webTitle: Earth warned of 'solar bombs'

fields.headline: Earth warned of 'solar bombs'
fields.trailText: Billions of tons of superheated material from the sun are heading towards the earth at millions of miles an hour, astronomers warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Billions of tons of superheated material from the sun are heading towards the earth at millions of miles an hour, astronomers warned yesterday.

The solar bombs - from sunspots big enough to hide 14 earth-like planets - will not harm anyone on the surface. But they could threaten navigation and communication satellites, shut down power supplies, light up a spectacular aurora borealis, and expose high-flying airline crews to bursts of higher radiation.

Astronomers are fond of saying that when the sun sneezes, the Earth catches a cold. The sun, 90m miles away, is a giant thermonuclear reactor which converts 600m tonnes of hydrogen into helium every second. It goes through an 11-year cycle of increasing violence, and is, right now, at or near its maximum.

At intervals, huge flares explode from its surface and head into space at speeds of from 12 to 1,200 km a second.

These crash into the magnetic field around the Earth to wreak violence on the upper atmosphere and create the Northern Lights.

Yesterday, US geological survey scientists monitoring the Earth's magnetic field warned of solar eruptions which sent billions of tonnes of plasma - torn-up atoms - flying towards Earth. One flare was expected to smash into the magnetosphere last night. The second is expected today.

European and US space agencies have a fleet of spacecraft monitoring the sun's behaviour. The hazard to commercial systems is potentially so huge that even the UK national grid is warned in advance of electromagnetic storms from space. Space weather is a much bigger problem than any ordinary weather.

In 1989, the blast from outer space made voltage sag across an entire North American network. There were automatic compensating devices, but these too were vulnerable and all failed within one minute, blacking out parts of Canada.
